DOC.HEAD: Government to Defy Lords and Reintroduce War Crimes Bill
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government has decided to defy the unelected House of Lords and reintroduce a bill to allow the prosecution of elderly suspected Nazi war criminals living in Britain. Sir Geoffrey Howe, Conservative leader of the House of Commons, announced Thursday night the government intends during the next session of Parliament to resubmit the War Crimes Bill, which was easily defeated by the Lords on June 5. The Lords' powers are limited to delaying legislation for one year. The elected House of Commons had approved a government-appointed commission's recommendation to prosecute war criminals, passing the bill last December by a 270-60 vote. But a succession of peers, including lawyers who prosecuted the top Nazis at post-war trials in Nuremberg or fought in World War II as young officers, opposed the bill, saying fair trials were impossible and dragging aging emigres before courts would only stir old hatreds. The bill was defeated in the Lords by a vote of 207-74. Howe told the House of Commons: ``The government will be seeking, whether by suggested amendments or otherwise, to secure that the bill next session may receive the support of both houses.'' If the Lords again vote against the bill, however, the government is likely to use its powers under the Parliament Act, not invoked for more than 40 years, to force it through. The Simon Wiesenthal Society, which seeks prosecution of suspected Nazi war criminals, applauded the government's decision to reintroduce the bill. ``This decision sends a strong signal that after 40 years of apathy and delay the people of Great Britain will finally stand with the victims of the Holocaust by bringing those who participated in Nazi genocide before the bar of justice,'' Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate dean of the Los Angeles-based Wiesenthal center, said in a statement issued Friday. Britain is the only World War II ally without laws to prosecute suspected war criminals. Canada and Australia recently changed laws to allow trials and the United States deports suspects for trial to Israel or other countries. The government commission, headed by a former director of public prosecutions, said there is sufficient evidence to prosecute three suspects living in Britain and 124 more should be investigated. The suspects allegedly helped round up and murder thousands of Jews in Nazi-occupied Soviet republics.

DOC.BYLINE: Miles Davis: Muse, Mannerist or Musician? ^By WILLIAM GILLEN
DOC.TEXT: Is Miles Davis a muse, a mannerist or a musician? The question's been asked in the jazz world for years. Sometimes he's more of one than the other two, but on the opening night of this year's JVC Jazz Festival he played a bit of each role. As muse, he drifted dreamily across the stage, noodling on his trumpet. As mannerist, he committed such no-nos as playing most of the set with his back to the audience. As musician, he engaged his players in conversation that ranged from intimate to vigorous. Davis and his six-piece band entered august Avery Fisher Hall cooking, and left the same way Friday night. The audience stomped and howled for more, but what they heard was what they got. Besides, Miles Davis and the Miles Davis Band had a late show to play. Davis, who's passed beyond the legend stage to the cult figure level, might appear indifferent to his audience, but never to his music. His duels and duets with saxophonist Kenny Garrett and lead bassist Joseph Foley McCreary were the highlights of the evening. Hiroshima, an American band with some Oriental affectations, played the first half of the bill at a highly amplified level that often drowned out whatever musical effects were intended. In pre-electronic media days, it might have been described as a novelty act. Hiroshima, a stadium band, had little to do with jazz. The JVC Jazz Festival, sponsored by the Japanese electronics firm, runs in New York through June 30 and then moves on to Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Offers $3 Billion Credit to Soviet Union for Reforms
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Friday it would guarantee a bank credit of about $3.1 billion for the Soviet Union to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reform his country's ailing economy. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein said the 12-year bank credit marks the start of a West German initiative to get large-scale international support for the Soviet Union. In a related development, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand called Friday for quick economic help to support Soviet reforms and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe. The two leaders held more than two hours of private talks on a boat on the Rhine River, near of Assmannshausen, west of Wiesbaden, as part of their regular German-French consultations. The 5 billion Deutsche mark bank credit, worth nearly $3.1 billion, was negotiated by the Deutsche Bank and the Dresdner Bank with the Foreign Trade Bank in the Soviet Union. The credit aims to help the Soviet Union make the transition from a centrally planned economy to a market economy, an effort that is similar to reform plans in other East bloc countries. The announcement was made as foreign ministers from the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ began two days of talks in Berlin on resolving differences over German unification. West Germany has indicated its willingness to broaden economic cooperation with the Soviet Union as part of shaping future relations with a united Germany. Bonn would also like to see Moscow drop its bitter objections to membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a unified Germany. The Soviet Union also stands to lose one of its key economic partners as East Germany unites with West Germany. Many of the East German firms with which the Soviet Union trades are likely to go bankrupt once the two Germanys merge their currencies on July 2. Others that survive will have their products priced in the new expensive marks. Kohl said his talks with Mitterrand concerned preparations for the upcoming European Economic Community summit in Dublin, the NATO summit in London and the world economic summit in Houston. He said they were convinced that decisions would be reached in Dublin and Houston about how the reform processes in Eastern Europe, and especially in the Soviet Union, could be supported. But it was not yet settled how much financial help they were talking about. The European Economic Community must understand the importance of giving ``help toward self-help because the politics of perestroika helps us all,'' Kohl said. ``We have very little time,'' he added. Mitterrand concurred, saying, ``The matter is really urgent.''
