DOC.BYLINE: U.S. Rejects Soviet Plan For 5-Year Wait For German NATO Membership ^By DEBORAH G. SEWARD
DOC.TEXT: The Western allies, led by the United States, have rejected a Soviet proposal that a united Germany wait five years before it has the right to join NATO. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made the pitch during unification talks Friday involving the four World War II Allies and the two German states. Shevardnadze also proposed pulling U.S. Soviet, British and French troops out of Berlin within six months of a German merger, which could take place by the end of year. That proposal also was rejected by the United States. The issue of a united Germany's military status has been a stumbling block in the drive to unification of West Germany, a member of the U.S.-backed North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and former Communist East Germany, which has been in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The United States wants the new country to be a member of NATO, but the Soviets have balked at that idea. Another unification hurdle was cleared Friday when the upper house of the West German parliament approved the treaty that will merge the economies of the German states on July 2. The accord had been approved a day earlier by the lower house of parliament, and by East German lawmakers. Government officials in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said an all-German election was most likely Dec. 9. Shevardnadze said he hoped agreement on unification could be reached ``by the end of the year.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters the Soviet plan for an Allied troop pullout from Berlin _ which is expected to become Germany's capital again _ would leave the city surrounded by 380,000 Soviet troops. As for all of Germany, Shevardnadze proposed a 50 percent reduction in foreign forces over five years from East and West Germany, and then over an unspecified period removing all of them except ``token contingents.'' Over a five-year transitional period, Shevardnadze said, East and West Germany would be obliged to maintain ``all concluded international treaties and agreements'' now in effect. Western diplomats interpreted this statement as a Soviet attempt to delay NATO membership for the merged Germany. Currently, West Germany is in NATO and East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. A senior West German official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters that although his government was opposed to a transition period, there might be room for a ``winding-down process.'' The ministers agreed to meet in Paris on July 17 to consider Poland's concern about its border with Germany. About one-third of Polish territory today was ceded to it from Germany after World War II. Both German parliaments this week approved a declaration that a unified Germany will respect Poland's current border at the Oder-Neisse rivers. Meanwhile, West Germany said Friday it will guarantee a bank credit of about $3.1 billion for the Soviet Union to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reform his country's ailing economy. It is also seen as an attempt to allay Soviet concerns about German unification. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein said the 12-year bank credit marks the start of a West German initiative to get large-scale international support for the Soviet Union. In a related development, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand called Friday for quick economic help to support Soviet reforms and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-AIDS Drugs and Vaccines Being Tested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TIBO's scientific name is tetrahydro-imidazo-benzodiazepin-one.
DOC.TEXT: A chemical cousin of the tranquilizer Valium and a Chinese herbal root long used to induce abortions are among dozens of drugs being tested to fight AIDS, researchers reported. Doctors described the search for new AIDS drugs Friday at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, which continues through the weekend. The Valium derivative, called TIBO, was found when scientists from the Institute for Medical Research in Leuven, Belgium, screened hundreds of compounds for potential power against AIDS. Dr. Rudi Pauwels said TIBO blocks viral reproduction at levels 100 times lower than ddC and 3,000 times lower than ddI. Those two still-experimental AIDS drugs are nearing approval for routine use. TIBO is in early stages of human testing in Europe. The drugs provide hope to infected people who cannot tolerate AZT, the only medicine approved for routine use in people infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Many doctors believe a combination of medicines, not just a single drug, will provide the best chance of keeping healthy the estimated 1 million to 1.5 million Americans with HIV. While doctors and scientists listened to highly technical talks inside Moscone Center, demonstrators outside held the latest of what have been daily, thematic protests. The focus of Friday's action by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, was a contention that women, children and minorities are excluded from research, treatment and other services. Women made up most of the more than 200 people at the march and ``die-in,'' which resulted in about 140 arrests for blocking an intersection. Among the most controversial presentations of the five-day meeting was a report on compound Q, the Chinese herbal medicine. The treatment is being tested by a community group outside the usual control of medical schools and hospitals that ordinarily evaluate new medicines. ``At this stage, we have seen a major and dramatic change in what happens to these patients,'' said Martin Delaney. Delaney is director of San Francisco's Project Inform, a group that advocates quickly giving people with AIDS any available information about potential medicines. In its experiment, the group has tested compound Q on 46 patients for 116 days. Before the treatment, their helper T cells _ the primary target of the AIDS virus _ had been steadily declining. But after treatment, the loss stopped or even reversed itself in 38 of them. Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the New England Journal of Medicine, called Delaney irresponsible for releasing his conclusion without providing data to back it. Compound Q apparently works by stopping infected blood cells known as macrophages from manufacturing new copies of the AIDS virus. Another new class of drugs, being developed at Roche Products Ltd. in England, takes a different approach. Dr. Noel Roberts said the medicine inhibits the production of viral protease, an enzyme the virus uses to cut up the proteins that it uses to build new copies of itself. At Friday's session, researchers also presented data about potential AIDS vaccines. Closest to widespread testing are vaccines that will boost the immune system of people who are already infected with the AIDS virus or help prevent infected women from spreading the microbe to their children during pregnancy. Further off are vaccines that will keep uninfected people from catching the virus. Wayne Koff, chief of the AIDS vaccine research branch at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the most promising human vaccines should be ready for large-scale testing in two or three years, and it will take two or three more years to determine their effectiveness. ``So, we're still looking at the mid-to-late 1990s as a minimal time frame for selection of a vaccine for general use,'' Koff said. ``I think there is reason to be more optimistic now, in 1990, than at any previous international AIDS conference,'' he said. Some 30 approaches toward the development of vaccines are being studied, Koff said, and half a dozen vaccines are being tested or are about to be tried in humans.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela Strikes Out on Her Own During Last Day in New York
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Winnie Mandela left her husband's side on their third day in the United States to pledge her commitment to women's rights, raise a little money on her own and chat with Phil Donahue on his television show. ``In South Africa, we believe that if the women were in the forefront, we would have long won our freedom,'' she said Friday with a smile, winning a roar of appreciation from 200 women active in civic and religious organizations. ``One of our greatest priorities is women's rights,'' she said at the gathering in a Brooklyn church. ``Unless and until we are empowered through a plan of affirmative action, our national liberation will not be complete.'' Actress Cicely Tyson was host at a tribute to the wife of apartheid fighter Nelson Mandela that included a performance by Sweet Honey in the Rock, an acapella group known for liberation songs. At the end of three rousing numbers, Mrs. Mandela embraced each of the group's six members. Mrs. Mandela reiterated her request for support of warfare if negotiations with the white rulers of South Africa break down. ``If talks fall apart and they very well might, we know you will be there to take up arms with us,'' Mrs. Mandela told a sold-out crowd of 2,000 at the tribute. Her appearances in Brooklyn raised about $60,000 for the ANC, organizers said. Among Mrs. Mandela's other separate activities was an appearance on Phil Donahue's syndicated show that aired Friday in New York and other selected cities but will not be broadcast in the rest of country until Monday. Mrs. Mandela condemned ``necklacing,'' the killing of South African government collaborators by lighting gasoline-soaked tires around their necks. Mrs. Mandela has been quoted as having said at a 1986 rally in South Africa: ``With our boxes of matches and our necklaces, we shall liberate this country.'' She said the statement was ``reported completely out of context'' and added, ``No sane person would ever approve of that.'' As for whether she approves of violence, Mrs. Mandela asserted that ``We have no violence to renounce. The method used by the oppressor determines your own reaction.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Vice President Murumbi Dies
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Murumbi, the second vice president of this East African nation who served briefly in 1966, has died following a long illness, newspapers reported. He was 79. Murumbi, who had been confined to a wheelchair since damaging a nerve in a fall eight years ago, died Friday at his Nairobi home, the papers reported. The exact cause of death was not immediately known. Murumbi was vice president under this former British colony's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, from March to November 1966 when he resigned from the office and quit politics citing health reasons. Murumbi was succeeded by Daniel arap Moi, who became president upon Kenyatta's death in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Police: General Motors Corp. Cars Easiest to Steal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 `The company...' to move up first reference to Stempel.
DOC.TEXT: Thieves can steal a General Motors Corp. car faster than the time it takes to watch a Camaro commercial, say police officials in some of the nation's largest cities. Police faced with a younger generation of thieves blame GM steering columns for making the company's cars the easiest to heist. ``Thieves are not brain surgeons,'' said Michael Graziose, a New York detective. ``It takes someone who dropped out of high school 30 seconds to steal one of those cars.'' Los Angeles Police Chief Daryl F. Gates said in a letter to GM that children as young as 12 ``are easily outwitting the present security design system of your vehicles.'' Concerned GM executives summoned police to Detroit in April to discuss the trend. After the meeting, the automaker said it would include anti-theft, electronic keys as standard equipment on nearly all 1994 cars and alter the much-maligned steering columns, which also are used in some Chrysler Corp. models. The company also plans structural changes in its steering columns, said Robert Stempel, GM's chairman-elect. He declined to be specific, however, saying technical details would tip thieves off on how to penetrate the new columns. ``It's not an end-all to the theft problem, but it helps,'' Stempel said in a recent interview. Until the changes are in place, however, GM will produce hundreds of thousands of cars police say are exceptionally vulnerable to theft. General Motors, the world's largest automaker, made 74 of the top 100 cars and trucks on a nationwide most-stolen list compiled by CCC Information Services Inc. of Chicago, which estimates the value of stolen and damaged vehicles for insurers. Ford Motor Co. had three vehicles in the top 100. The other Big Three automaker, Chrysler, had none. Last year's most popular theft target was the GM-made 1986 Chevrolet Camaro, followed by Camaros made in 1987, 1984 and 1985, according to CCC. Rounding out CCC's top 10 were five more GM cars _ the 1984 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme, 1986 Pontiac Firebird, 1987 Firebird, 1981 Cutlass Supreme and 1988 Camaro. The 1988 Hyundai Excel GL, a Korean-made car, finished in tenth place. Sixty-two percent of all cars stolen in 1989 in 15 surveyed cities were made by GM, according to the Major Cities Chiefs Association, which represents the heads of 48 police forces. Ony 35 percent of the vehicles sold in the United States last year were GMs. Thefts of cars made by all automakers were up 9 percent in 1989, the FBI said. The agency doesn't compile theft data specific to each automaker. Police and mechanics say the steering column's plastic housing is easily cracked open, exposing the ignition apparatus. ``In one fell swoop, you can unlock the steering column, unlock the shifter and start the car. Boom!'' said mechanic Bill Dobransky of Dynamics Service Center in Pittsburgh. General Motors says its design isn't all to blame. The cars are popular theft targets simply because there are more of them on the road and because of the popularity of GM parts, Stempel said. ``Auto theft is a big problem exacerbated by drug use and street crime. It's a problem for police, our dealers and our customers. But it's an industry problem _ it's not limited to GM,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 140 Arrested at AIDS Protest with Forgotten-Women Theme
DOC.TEXT: Women dominated a protest that brought 140 arrests outside the international AIDS conference to dramatize activists' complaints that research is too male-oriented. ``We're here because women with AIDS are not getting access to drug treatment trials,'' said Kate Bollard, a member of Seattle's chapter of ACT UP, the AIDS activist group. ``Women are being only looked at as people who transmit the virus, not as people who have the virus.'' The Friday arrests came after several hundred protesters blocked traffic in a downtown shopping district. They brought total arrests during four days of protest to 299 at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS at the Moscone Center, which has been shielded from protesters by tight security. The only incident inside came Friday morning when demonstrators held up a banner reading, ``NIAID: Form a Women's Committee,'' during a speech by an official with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Outside, marchers echoed the theme, chanting. A number of women tied themselves to police barricades with red paper chains as others chanted, ``NIH we think you're vile. We need clinical trials.'' The call refers to the National Institutes of Health's human testing of experimental drugs, mostly on men. Speakers also included those advocating rights for prostitutes. Carol Leigh, a prostitute from San Francisco, complained that women of her profession are unfairly perceived as AIDS carriers and persecuted. Dressed in a Gay 90s music hall dress and a red feather boa, Leigh said prostitutes help stop the spread of disease by using condoms. ``Prostitutes are safe sex educators,'' she said. The protest wound through crowded lunch-time streets, chanting and blowing whistles, finally halting for a ``die-in'' at a busy intersection. Ignoring police warnings, a group of protesters remained in the intersection. Police began the long process of arresting them as noon shoppers and other demonstrators looked on. When the arrests were completed, a second group of demonstrators ran back into the street, bringing back police for another series of arrests. All those taken into custody were charged with failure to disperse. Many shoppers were trapped on the street until police finished the arrests. Most watched patiently, but some expressed frustration with the week of demonstrations that have tied up the city. ``I was gassed at Berkeley in the 60s, so I can sympathize with them,'' said Lillian Schneiderman, a shopper from the eastern Bay area. ``But this is not focusing the issues where it needs to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Warns at U.N. of Threat Posed by South Africa's Rightists
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela warned during a speech at the United Nations against underestimating South Africa's white supremacists. Mandela received a standing ovation Friday as he and his wife, Winnie, entered the General Assembly Hall packed with delegates and guests on the couple's third and last day in New York. The United Nations' secretary general, Javier Perez de Cuellar, told the crowd that the South African black nationalist leader ``is in his own house today.'' Mandela drew a burst of applause when he offered greetings to ``the peoples of Palestine'' fighting for liberation and human rights. ``We commend their struggles to you,'' he said. The African National Congress ``will not relent or falter in the pursuit of that common vision which should result in the transformation of South Africa into a country of democracy, justice and peace,'' Mandela said in a 20-minute speech. To that end, he said ``we strongly urge that there should be no relaxation of existing measures. The sanctions that have been imposed by the United Nations and by individual governments should remain in place.'' Mandela, 71, acknowledged the United Nations' effort to do away with apartheid, South Africa's system of racial segregation, and to win the freedom of political prisoners, including himself. Mandela praised South African President F.W. de Klerk and his colleagues as ``people of integrity'' in their negotiations with the ANC toward ending apartheid. ``We have to overcome the mistrust that exists on both sides and reinforce the understanding that the only victory we should all seek is the victory of the people as a whole, and not the victory of one party over another,'' Mandela said. He said, however, that white racists in South Africa were still determined to preserve apartheid, some because they are ideologically committed to it and others because they fear black majority rule. ``We cannot afford to underestimate the threat that these defenders of a brutal and continuing reality pose to the whole process of working towards a just political settlement,'' Mandela said. In Johannesburg, South Africa, a newspaper reported Friday that police arrested and later freed 11 whites for questioning about a right-wing plot to assassinate Mandela, de Klerk and others. ``I am too busy doing what I think is constructive work to worry about threats to my life,'' Mandela said in response to a question about the plot. A spokesman for South Africa's U.N. mission, Jonathan Etienne Fourie, would not comment on Mandela's speech, saying his government chooses to stay within the framework of a ``constant dialogue with Mr. Mandela back home.''

DOC.HEAD: Tornadoes Reported in Five States
DOC.TEXT: Tornadoes forced the evacuation today of about 20 residents in a north central Ohio village and also were sighted in Wisconsin, Florida, North Carolina, Illinois and Michigan. In rural North Woodbury, Ohio, a tornado destroyed an undetermined number of houses and buildings Friday in the village of about 75 people, said Morrow County Disaster Services director Dick Williams. Tornadoes also were reported in South Mills, N.C.; Gull Lake, Mich.; Sullivan, Wis.; Germantown Hills, Ill., and east of St. Petersburg, Fla. Elsewhere, much of the nation endured thunderstorms, and hot, humid conditions Friday. Thunderstorms produced three-quarter inch diameter hail near Greensboro, N.C., and almost one-inch hail near Huffman, Ala.. Hail the size of golf balls fell on Cottondale, Ala., and Tuscaloosa, Ala. Damage from thunderstorm wind gusts was reported in Virginia, northern and central North Carolina, northwestern South Carolina, northern Georgia, northern Alabama, northern Mississippi, and southwest Indiana. Heavy rain caused flooding in several Vermont locations and Littleton, N.H. In Melbourne, Fla., 2.6 inches of rain fell between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. Friday. In Wisconsin, the Fox River closed a county road near Wrightstown, Wis., with 8 feet of water, and there were many of reports of flooding in and around Green Bay, where 2.86 inches of rain fell. Rain showers and thunderstorms fell Friday night from western New York across Pennsylvania, as well as West Virginia, Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, North and South Carolina, Florida, northern Georgia, northern Alabama, central Mississippi, southern Arkansas and Louisiana. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio and eastern Indiana. Rain showers and thunderstorms reached from lower Michigan across northwest Illinois, northeast Missouri, Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, eastern North Dakota, eastern South Dakota and eastern Nebraska. Rain showers and thunderstorms were scattered throughout northern Texas and from northwest Montana across the northern Pacific Coast. The high temperature for the nation today was 118 degrees at Laughlin, Nev. Temperatures climbed to 114 degrees in Beeville, Texas, breaking its record of 108 degrees set in August 1989. DOC.HEAD: Soprano Elizabeth Harwood Is Dead At Age 52
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Ms. Harwood...' to CORRECT opera title. Pick up 8th graf, `Returning to...'
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Harwood, one of Britain's best-known operatic sopranos in the 1960s and 1970s, has died after a battle with cancer, her family said. She was 52. Ms. Harwood, who specialized in lyric and coloratura roles and the music of Mozart, died Friday at her home in Fryerning, 20 miles northeast of London. She sang with nearly all the top British operatic companies and appeared regularly in leading roles at the prestigious annual music festival in Salzburg, Austria in the early 1970s. With her striking good looks and a radiant stage presence, Ms. Harwood delighted audiences at opera houses around the world. Her mother, a professional soprano, gave her singing lessons when she was a child, and she later studied at the Royal Manchester College of Music at Manchester in northern England. She made her operatic debut in 1960, singing Second Boy in ``Die Zauberflote'' at Glyndebourne in southern England. In 1963 she scored her first major success, as the Countess Adele in Rossini's ``Count Ory.'' In 1960, she won Britain's prized Kathleen Ferrier memorial award for singing, in 1965 was joint winner of the Verdi Competition at Busseto in Italy. Ms. Harwood first appeared at the Salzburg Festival in 1970, when she sang the role of Constanze in Mozart's 1782 opera ``The Abduction from the Seraglio'' and that of Fiordiligi in ``Cosi fan tutte.'' Returning to Salzburg in 1972, she sang the countess in a new production of Mozart's ``The Marriage of Figaro'' conducted by Herbert von Karajan. He continued to invite her to Salzburg for several years. She sang Constanze at Milan's La Scala in 1972. In the late 1970s her health began to deteriorate. Ms. Harwood's last public performance was in November 1989 at the Bath Festival in western England. She married businessmen Julian Royle in 1966. The couple had one son.

DOC.HEAD: Donors Pledge $200 Million For Initial Namibian Development
DOC.TEXT: Donors have pledged $200 million in development aid for Namibia, far short of the $800 million sought for the African nation that recently acheived independence from South Africa. The United States pledged only $10 million, but Foreign Minister Theo Ben Gurirab told a news conference after the pledges were made Friday that he is grateful and satisfied. He declined to criticize the United States and other nations for pledging more to emerging Eastern European democracies than to Africa's newest democracy, which became independent three months ago. Ben Gurirab said that about 50 countries made pledges, but further details were not yet compiled by U.N. officials. ``Obviously, we would have been happier with $800 million in pledges,'' he said. ``But we are not disappointed.'' Ben Gurirab, asked about the level of U.S. aid, ``We are aware of the disparities, but our idea has been to encourage countries to have a look at us as a government and see our development strategy and decide for themselves. ``We are not going to change policies and ideologicial perspectives, be we want the world to see us as an emerging democracy,'' he said. South Africa pledged $10 million, he said. He said his government wants to negotiate with South Africa about the debt which the Pretoria government claims is owed by Namibia to South African individuals and companies. He said his government also will negotiate with South Africa about the return of the South African Walvis Bay enclave in Namibia and insist on its return. Namibia, he said, is seeking membership in the International Monetary Fund and other lending institutions, but he said that Namibia's currency still is based on the South African rand and it has no independent monetary policy. He said he expected Namibian currency to be based on the rand for about two years and said that Namibia would not involve itself in borrowing until it has its own currency.

DOC.HEAD: `Robin HUD' Asks for and Receives Stiff Sentence
DOC.TEXT: ``Robin HUD,'' the former real estate agent who bilked federal housing programs of about $6 million, requested and got a stiff sentence, but her lawyer plans to appeal anyway. Marilyn Harrell was sentenced Friday to a 46-month prison term by U.S. District Judge Herbert Murray, who said he did not believe her claim that she turned over most of the money to charity. Harrell said of the sentence, ``I asked for it because I deserve it.'' Her lawyer, Anthony Gallagher, said he will appeal. Harrell, 46, pleaded guilty in January to stealing money from the sale of houses owned by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and filing a false tax return. In addition to prison, she was sentenced to three years probation and 624 hours of community service and ordered to pay $600,000 in restitution. She was also ordered to serve a concurrent one-year sentence on the tax charge. Harrell will not be eligible for parole. Prosecutors convinced Murray to refigure the federal sentencing guideline formula used to determine her sentence, from 30 to 37 months to 37 to 46 months. In doing do, Murray agreed with prosecutors that Harrell actually gave less than a fifth of what she stole to charity. Gallagher asked for a 16-month sentence with half of that to be served in a halfway house. Harrell, who had asked the judge for the maximum under the sentencing guidelines, emerged from the courthouse smiling. ``I think it's fair and I'm delighted, which is what Tony told me not to say,'' Harrell said. Earlier, Harrell told the judge just prior to sentencing: ``I have never said what I did was right. In fact, if a person steals 5 cents then they should be done with whatever the court sees fit.'' ``We got what we asked for. You have to be satisfied with that,'' assistant U.S. attorney Gary Jordan said. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has called the case the largest theft of federal funds by an individual. Harrell became a symbol of mismanagement at HUD during the Reagan administration. The actual size of the theft and how much Harrell gave to charity were not resolved Friday. Harrell has admitted stealing $5.7 million and claimed she gave more than $5 million away. Prosecutors said she failed to turn in to HUD's Washington office about $6.6 million from the sale of 99 properties between 1985 and 1988, and gave about $1.1 million to charity. About $490,000 worth of property she owned has already been forfeited to HUD. She now owes about $110,000. Several witnesses testified Friday to Harrell's generosity. ``I had been in contact with several homes and every one turned me down except Marilyn,'' said Carol Ann Swift, a double amputee who lived at a women's home that Harrell supported with government funds. ``She gave me a house and went and got me clothes because I had lost over 88 pounds.''

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Unveils Futuristic Jet Fighter
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. unveiled its version of a futuristic jet that can dogfight at supersonic speed and hide from radar, but it may get shot down by congressional budget cutters. The twin-tail, twin-engine YF-23 prototype was rolled out Friday before a crowd of cheering Northrop workers. The Air Force wants to build a fleet of the 750 Advanced Tactical Fighters, or ATFs, that will fly into the next century. A corporate team led by Northrop is competing against Lockheed Corp., but the issue may be moot if Congress decides the aircraft is not needed because of easing world tensions. U.S. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has suggested upgrades of the F-15 and F-16 fighters instead. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in a cost-cutting move, recently delayed the requested start-up of production for the ATF until 1996. Air Force officials argue the need for a modernized air fleet. Although East-West tensions have eased, the world situation remains fluid and potentially dangerous, the Air Force argues. The sophisticated attributes advertised for the ATF include radar-evading stealth capability combined with high maneuverability and the ability to cruise at supersonic speeds for extended periods of time. The ATF contract would translate to thousands of jobs and a more secure financial future for whichever team of companies wins it. Northrop is teamed with McDonnell Douglas against Lockheed and Boeing in a competition for the contract. Lockheed's version, the YF-22, will be unveiled later this summer. The team of Lockheed and Boeing would produce the airplanes in Georgia. The Northrop and McDonnell Douglas team would build the planes in California. The ATF would replace the Air Force's current air superiority fighter, the McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle. Each team has spent about $600 million on producing two prototypes apiece and the Pentagon has matched the funding of each team. Kent Kresa, chief executive officer and president of Northrop, hailed the aircraft as ``an example of America's leadership in aviation ... in an era when American competitiveness is being tested continually worldwide.'' Estimated cost of the ATF is $51 million per plane. Fighters such as the F-15 cost a little more than half that to build. Air Force officials contend the aircraft is necessary because of the advancing age of its current inventory of fighter aircraft and because they say the ATF, along with the B-2 stealth bomber, is a revolutionary aircraft. General Ronald W. Yates, commander of the Air Force Systems Command, said the fighter prototype unveiled Friday represents the world's most advanced technologies in engines, avionics and materials. He noted the F-15 Eagle would be nearly 30 years old when ATF planes enter service. The Air Force program manager for ATF said that a quality edge helped safeguard national security. ``We've never fought a war where we didn't enjoy air superiority,'' said Brig. Gen. James A. Fain Jr. ``I don't think America would stand for sending its sons and daughters to a war where we didn't have air superiority.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We cannot afford to underestimate the threat that these defenders of a brutal and continuing reality pose to the whole process of working towards a just political settlement.'' _ Nelson Mandela, of white racists in his native South Africa in a speech at the United Nations.
``In South Africa, we believe that if the women were in the forefront, we would have long won our freedom.'' _ Winnie Mandela, wife of Nelson Mandela, before 200 women activists in New York.

``Women are being only looked at as people who transmit the virus, not as people who have the virus.'' _ Kate Bollard of Seattle's chapter of ACT UP, the AIDS activist group, during a protest at the international AIDS conference in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: `Zodiac' Gunman: I Am San Francisco Killer
DOC.TEXT: The ``Zodiac'' gunman picked his latest victim because of his astrological sign and claims to be the serial killer who operated in the San Francisco Bay area for 19 years, police say. Despite that claim, which came in a letter received Friday by the New York Post, investigators said the gunman is not believed to be the San Francisco Zodiac killer who took responsibility for up to 40 murders and was never captured. Police confirmed the letter was written by the same person who is believed to have shot four men in New York on recent Thursday mornings, including a 30-year-old homeless man wounded as he slept on a Central Park bench, the Post said. The three other men also survived. The Central Park victim told detectives Friday he was befriended days before the shooting by a stranger who asked him his birth date, Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said. The wounded man's description of the stranger matches an earlier description of ``Zodiac'' _ an unkempt black man between the ages of 30 to 35, about 6 feet tall, with a moustache and possibly a beard. The San Francisco killer was described as a white man, 25 to 40 years old, with blond or red hair. Police also say the handwriting in the San Francisco letters is different from the New York letters. The letter the Post received Friday was mailed Thursday and was postmarked in Brooklyn. In the letter, the gunman disputed reports suggesting he wasn't the San Francisco zodiac killer, said Jerry Nachman, the Post's editor. The letter read in part ``Fourth sign dead shoot in Central Park, white man sleeping on bench with little black bag shoot in chest, june 21, 1990 3:52 a.m.,'' Nachman said. In fact, the latest victim was black, and he did not die, police said. The cryptic letter was emblazoned with a drawing of the crosshairs of a gunsight and a circle with four pie-shaped wedges marked off, each containing a crude astrological sign. The gunman had also scrawled the name ``Faust'' on the lined, white looseleaf paper, a reference to the philosopher of legend who sells his soul to the devil in exchange for knowledge and power. In previous notes, the gunman claimed responsibility for three other shootings on the Brooklyn-Queens border since March. The birth dates of the other three victims correspond to astrological signs scrawled in notes written by the gunman, Borrelli said. In an earlier note to police, dated Nov. 19, 1989, the gunman threatened to terrorize the city by killing 12 people _ one for each astrological sign. Borrelli said detectives were concerned the gunman may choose future victims by their astrological signs and urged anyone who had been asked their birth date by a stranger matching the gunman's description to call police. Fifty detectives are now working on the case, the Daily News reported today.

DOC.HEAD: Police Commissioner Threatens to Break Up Opposition News Conferences
DOC.TEXT: Kenya's police commissioner has threatened to halt opposition figures' news conferences as illegal gatherings and make arrests without warrants, a newspaper reported today. Police commissioner Philip Kilonzo made the remark after being asked about plainclothes policemen's disruption on Thursday of a news conference called by lawyers representing two former Cabinet ministers. The two former ministers, Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, have been attacked for their campaign to legalize opposition parties. They called the news conference after being told police were looking for them. ``We do not need to wait around wasting time waiting for a warrant of arrest while these people go on with their illegal meetings,'' The Standard newspaper quoted the commissioner as saying. ``From now on, police will be left to determine ... those press conferences that are genuine and those that constitute an illegal meeting,'' the English-language newspaper quoted Kilonzo as saying. On Friday, police confiscated notes, cameras and press cards from journalists at the separate offices of Matiba and Rubia. Kilonzo's office said today he was not available for comment on the newspaper report.

DOC.HEAD: Abbas Says His Faction Will Accept PLO Discipline Over Raid
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrilla leader Mohammad Abbas said today he and his faction are prepared to accept any disciplinary action by PLO chief Yasser Arafat for the raid they staged on an Israeli beach last month. The raid _ and Arafat's refusal to condemn it _ led to this week's suspension of U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Abbas, better known as Abu Abbas, said in a statement distributed to international news agencies in Baghdad that he had given Arafat a complete file on the attack plans to show it was aimed at military targets. The Tel Aviv shore was crowded with holiday beachgoers at the time of the May 30 seaborne attack by 16 guerrillas of Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front. Israeli forces foiled the raid, and there were no Israeli casualties. Abbas said he had agreed that Arafat could ``take any measure he sees as necessary to protect the national achievements of our people.'' He accused the Bush adminstration of using the raid as a pretext to cut off the 18-month dialogue Wednesday with the PLO and ``humiliate'' the organization and its leaders. Abbas, who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro in which a disabled American was killed, said his group would continue its armed struggle against Israel. ``I hereby declare that we are insisting on confronting the Zionist enemy and fighting for the freedom of our people,'' he said. ``Nothing will stop us but martyrdom or freedom.'' Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia urged the Bush administration to reconsider its decision. ``The kingdom of Saudi Arabia expresses its deep regret at the suspension of the dialogue and appeals to the government of the United States of America to revise its declared decision in this connection and continue its efforts for negotiation and dialogue for settlement of conflicts,'' said a statement carried by the official Saudi Press Agency. Egypt and Jordan have made similar appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Welcomes German Border Resolution But Presses For Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Poland has welcomed a German resolution this week recognizing Poland's post-war borders but says a treaty formalizing it should be written before Germany unifies. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said Friday the resolution, adopted by both German parliaments, is ``an important step in the solution of this matter.'' But Poland wants a treaty setting the rivers Oder and Niesse as Poland's western border with Germany. ``It has been and still is important for us that the treaty should be agreed upon before unification and signed after it,'' Ms. Niezabitowska said. Technical work on the pact has begun. The resolution gives up all German claims to the one-third of modern Poland forfeited by Germany after World War II. The territory was meant to compensate Poland for an even larger territory to the east annexed by the Soviet Union. The rapid drive toward German unification has caused some alarm to Poles, the victims of German aggression during World War II. At first, Poland was not included in the negotiations between the two Germanys and the victorious World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Great Britain. Poland protested, and was invited to the unification talks in Paris in July to present its border concerns. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl had initially refused to address the border issue, saying only a united Germany could discuss it.

DOC.HEAD: Former Jazz Vocalist for Stan Kenton Orchestra Dies
DOC.TEXT: June Christy, known to Big Band era and jazz fans as that ``misty Miss Christy'' for her interpretation of ballads during her years with the Stan Kenton Orchestra, has died at age 64. The singer, also called the ``grande dame of modern jazz singing,'' died Thursday from complications of kidney failure at her Sherman Oaks home, the Los Angeles Times reported in today's editions. Miss Christy, who became famous in the '40s singing with the Stan Kenton Orchestra, stopped performing five years ago because of her illness, said her husband, Bob Cooper, who played tenor saxophone in the group. In 1945, her career was made when she recorded ``Tampico'' with the orchestra. She was named ``best female vocalist with a big band'' by Down Beat magazine four years straight. During a prolific career, Miss Christy toured the United States, Europe and Australia with the Kenton Orchestra. On her own, she recorded more than 20 albums, including ``Something Cool.'' Los Angeles Times jazz critic Leonard Feather dubbed her the ``grande dame,'' writing that ``to the extent that the term connotes professional prestige, it certainly applies.'' Miss Christy, an Illinois native who began her career at 19, was praised by critics for her distinctive vocal styling, influenced by Sarah Vaughan and Dinah Washington. ``Her breathy, husky sound and narrow vibrato,'' the New Grove Dictionary of Jazz noted, ``were ideally suited to the cool jazz of the 1950s.'' Miss Christy married Cooper in 1947, two years after she joined the big band. Along with her husband, she is survived by their daughter, Shay Cooper of Long Beach, and a brother, Jack Luster of Edwardsville, Ill. A memorial service was planned Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Man Commits Suicide, Note Cites Egypt's Elimination in Cup
DOC.TEXT: An Egyptian government employee committed suicide in apparent grief over Egypt's elimination in the first round of the World Cup games, two Cairo newspapers reported today. The state-owned Akhbar el-Yom and Al-Gomhouria said Sayed Abdel-Aal, 40, hanged himself in his apartment at the Mediterranean town of Damietta, 120 miles north of Cairo. The newspapers quoted police sources as saying Abdel-Aal left a suicide note saying that his life ended with Egypt's elimination and wishing the national team success in the next World Cup competition. The suicide followed Egypt's defeat by England Thursday night. The 1-0 game eliminated the Egyptian team. The sources said Abdel-Aal, who lived alone, had been suffering from depression.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MANILA
Typhoon Slams into Taiwan; 35 Reported Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with typhoon hitting Taiwan, 35 dead, 84,000 reported fleeing homes in the Philippines. Pickup 5th pvs, `The hardest...'
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Ofelia slammed into eastern Taiwan today with 86 mph winds and heavy rain, killing at least five people after claiming 30 lives in the Philippines and forcing tens of thousands to flee their homes. The storm cut a swath of destruction through the Philippines' central Luzon island, then gained strength as it crossed the Luzon Strait and struck Taiwan's eastern province of Hualien. Police in Hualien, 200 miles southeast of Taipei, said five people were killed when they were swept away by floods in a village. They said four people were reported missing in nearby villages. Officials said the Panamanian-registered freighter Juliana broke its mooring in the port of Hualien and ran aground. All 28 sailors aboard were rescued but three of them sustained minor injuries, they said. Forecasters said the typhoon was moving northward in Taiwan at 14 mph and was about 70 miles south of Taipei, the capital, at 7 p.m. today. All domestic flights were canceled in Taiwan as a precaution. In the Philippines, the Red Cross and other relief agencies said at least 30 people died and at least 84,600 fled their homes as the storm cut through Luzon island. The hardest hit province was La Union, about 150 miles northwest of Manila, where at least 22 people drowned or were killed in landslides. Forecaster Alan Mescallado said another tropical storm was spotted about 430 miles south-southwest of Guam. It was heading west-southwest in the general direction of the Philippine island of Mindanao. But Mescallado said even if the second storm stays on track, it would be at least another 24 hours before it reached the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Sets Up Commission On Missing U.S. Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia has set up a commission to help the search for the remains of U.S. soldiers killed there during the Vietnam War, Cambodian state radio said today. The broadcast said the Cabinet recently established the five-man commission led by a deputy interior minister, Khim Pom. The commission's task, it said, is ``to get in touch with concerned authorities in the provinces and to cooperate with U.S. delegations and specialists in the search for remains of American soldiers reported missing in Cambodia.'' The Vietnam War spilled over into neighboring Cambodia in 1970 as U.S. forces moved to cut off supply routes for Vietnamese Communist fighters. About 80 Americans are listed as missing in action there. The war ended in 1975 with Communist victories in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos. There has been virtually no work on resolving the cases in Cambodia because the United States does not recognize the current government, which Vietnam installed after invading in late 1978. The United States backs guerrillas fighting the government. Cambodia's prime minister, Hun Sen, has said his country has remains of U.S. soldiers and is ready to turn them over and cooperate in joint searches for other remains. But he has insisted that an official U.S. delegation come to retrieve the remains. Washington appears to have refused that demand.

DOC.HEAD: Midway to Return to Sea Soon; Investigation Continues
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. aircraft carrier Midway, its firefighting equipment replenished and crew members rested after a shipboard explosion that killed two, will return to sea in the next few days, a Navy official said today. The Navy was conducting routine investigations to determine whether foul play caused Wednesday's blast, which seriously injured nine crew members, said Cmdr. Mark D. Neuhart, public affairs officer for the 7th Fleet. ``We expect she'll be under way by early next week,'' Neuhart said, but he denied Japanese press reports quoting unidentified Navy sources saying the 67,000-ton ship would leave the U.S. Navy base at Yokosuka on Monday. He declined to say what the Midway's mission would be. The Midway docked Thursday at Yokosuka, 28 miles southwest of Tokyo, after its crew spent most of the night cooling down the small storeroom where the explosion occurred. The blast came after noon Wednesday as a firefighting crew opened the hatch to investigate smoke. All the casualties were among the firefighters. Neuhart said two small teams of investigators were looking through the debris and interviewing witnesses among the crew of 4,500. One team is trying to find out the cause of the explosion and steps taken after the blast. The other is looking into the possibility of foul play. ``But there's no indication of (foul play) _ it's just routine,'' he said. An unidentified crewman interviewed on Japanese television said a fuel pipe near a steam line beside the storeroom cracked and leaked fuel, which then ignited. Navy officials earlier said the steam, connected to the ship's catapult system for launching planes, was heated to 850 degrees Fahrenheit. ``There's all kinds of possibilities,'' Neuhart said. ``We know there was heat, steam and smoke. No flame was seen, but that doesn't necessarily mean there wasn't a fire.'' Results of the investigation probably won't be known for several weeks, he said. Dozens of protesters have demanded the Midway leave Japan because they contend nuclear weapons are aboard. Neuhart said he would not ``confirm nor deny the presence or absence of nuclear weapons.'' Six seriously burned sailors were flown Friday to the Brooke Army Medical Center burn unit in San Antonio, and a seventh was too ill to be moved. He remained in the naval hospital in Yokosuka, along with two others in serious condition. The Navy has identified the dead sailors as Ulric Patrick Johnson, 20, of Martinez, Calif., and Jeffrey Allan Vierra, 20, of Nevada City, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Kohl to Bring Aid to Moscow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with report that Kohl will visit Moscow with massive economic aid program, denial by gov't spokesman, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to travel to Moscow in late July bearing a multibillion-dollar economic aid package for the moribund Soviet economy, West Germany's leading news magazine reported today. The Hamburg-based Der Spiegel said the ``generous'' Western economic credit would total between $15 billion and $19 billion. Most of that would be guaranteed by the West German government, the weekly said in its Monday edition, portions of which were made available to other media today. A government spokesman in Bonn denied the report. Der Spiegel's reports have on occasion proven correct after being denied by the government. On Friday, the government confirmed it would back a West German bank credit of $3.1 billion to help the Soviet economy shift from central planning to free-market rule. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein said the 12-year bank credit marked the start of a West German initiative to urge large-scale international support for the Soviet Union. Der Spiegel said Kohl hoped to ease Soviet concerns about NATO membership for a united Germany, which Moscow has opposed despite pressure from the Western allies. The strategic stance of a united Germany is one of the biggest obstacles remaining to be worked out before German unification. Der Spiegel said Kohl's visit to Moscow would probably be either July 24 or July 25. It would be Kohl's second meeting this year with Gorbachev. In February, the two met in the Soviet capital. ``The chancellor has no such plans for such a journey,'' the government spokesman in Bonn said on condition of anonymity. The spokesman also called the billions in Western economic credit cited by the magazine pure speculation. ``That's too much for a country like Germany, though we have a strong economy,'' he said. Kohl meets with the 11 other leaders of the European Economic Community in Dublin Monday and Tuesday. In July, the World Economic Summit will be held in Houston, where Kohl and other leaders of the seven major industrialized democracies will gather for annual talks. The West German leader said Friday after meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand that international economic support for the Soviet Union was desperately needed and that he would seek such support at the summits. Mitterrand agreed, but neither leader specified how much was being considered.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Trains To Ban Smoking
DOC.TEXT: The government and the national railroad have agreed to ban smoking on all suburban commuter trains within the next few months, railroad officials said Saturday. The ban will not extend to long-distance trains, but the percentage of no-smoking cars on them will rise from one-half to two-thirds under an agreement to be signed Monday by railroad officials and Health Minister Claude Evin. The main region to be affected by the ban is the Paris area, which is served by about 3,000 commuter railroad cars. Smoking now is allowed on 40 percent of these cars.

DOC.HEAD: Cafe Owners Call Off Boycott After Concessions From Coke
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Bordeaux restaurant owners have called off a three-month boycott of Coca-Cola after the soft drink company agreed to remove streetside vending machines. About 500 establishments in France's fifth-largest city joined the boycott, contending that the sidewalk vending machines posed unfair competition. Bottles from the machines cost 5 francs, or 90 cents, _ one-half to one-third the price charged at cafes. Coca-Cola executives argued that they were trying to spread the popularity of Coke, not steal customers from cafes. But at a meeting Friday with leaders of the restaurant industry, the company agreed to stop deploying streetside vending machines in Bordeaux and to remove existing machines within two months. The restaurant and cafe owners reiterated their acceptance of vending machines placed inside business premises. Coca-Cola had chosen Bordeaux as the site for a test marketing program aimed at boosting Coke sales throughout France. The average French citizen reportedly drinks only a fifth as much Coke as a German or Belgian.

DOC.HEAD: Voices from the Epidemic: `Not a Simple Thing To Live With'
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The thousand of voices in the halls and the streets around the Sixth International Conference on AIDS resonated with passionate humanity, human compassion and intense dedication, love, anger and grief. The conference ends on Sunday, but the sound of those voices _ a few of which are recalled here _ linger in the memories of those who listened.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jeff Monforti pulled his wallet from his hip pocket and flashed a photo of his family as it once was and might have been. ``I'm not a Ph.D. or an M.D. _ I am a D-A-D,'' he said. ``And I'm a dad that's infected with the virus. My wife is also infected. I'm a dad who's lost two children.'' Monforti and his wife found out they were infected with the virus after the death of their son three years ago. The child was diagnosed with cancer, but Monforti demanded that the doctor test the boy for HIV antibodies. They discovered the truth a month after his death. ``At the time, my wife was pregnant with our third child,'' he said. ``Annalisa was born in December (1987). She was diagnosed with full-blown AIDS at 6 weeks.'' She has since died, but his 7-year-old son, Jonathan, is healthy. ``I have to deal with the fact that I could die. And what happens to my son?'' Monforti wants to create a support network for families with AIDS through his Atlanta-based Federation for Children with Special Needs. ``The loss of the child and the guilt and the idea of losing your wife or your husband along with your children is not a simple thing to live with. ``There are families out there who don't have the support, they don't have the respite they need. You don't have time to rest because your child is ill,'' he said. ``You're dealing with the fact that you're infected, your spouse is infected and your child is infected. You don't have the time to be sick.''

Illness has yet to find Louis Grant in the eight years since he was diagnosed with AIDS. He doesn't know the reason, but he survives and thrives. ``Eating well, vitamins. I've had to learn to manage stress in my life. I lead a rather hectic life,'' said Grant, a lifelong civil rights activist who is assistant director of the Center for Constitutional Rights. ``I still earn a living, still pay taxes. I'm up at 5 o'clock in the morning and off to my office by 7 o'clock.'' He adds, ``But I have my garden. ``I plant seeds and bulbs and other flowers in my garden every year and wonder whether I'll see them next spring and next summer. It used to be something I was really very anxious about in the early days when I was not sure I'd survive more than a year or two. And it's still there. I still think about it, still wonder if I'm going to see those flowers.''

When Lisa Capaldini was in medical school, they taught her all about curing, and they talked about conditions that were curable. It was only after she began working with HIV disease that she learned the value of healing. ``I'm often asked by friends and fellow health providers how I can manage my practice with people with HIV disease,'' said the soft-spoken physician, who divides her time between indigents and people with AIDS in San Francisco's Tenderloin District. ``Don't I have a sense of futility? And given that right now we don't have a cure for AIDS, isn't all the stuff I'm doing simply pouring my energy into a leaky bucket? ``I certainly don't feel that way. I feel that every time someone comes to see me, hopefully there's an opportunity for me to find some way to help them. And that helping may be nothing more than respectful listening, and acknowledging that things are difficult and frustrating. ``When someone comes to me ... I always have this feeling that isn't this man or woman going to be mad at me that I can't cure them, I can't fix them. That's what they came here for, and here I am telling them, I don't think we can do something about this, and I'm sorry. ``I'm amazed to say no one has ever expressed anger to me about that. Instead, what I've heard back is thank you for listening, or thank you for being honest.''

Tom Tull doesn't have AIDS yet, and he has no control over the course of the virus in his body, or his weekly T-cell count, or the toxicity of the AZT he has taken for three years. ``So there's a lot of questions I have coming up with my partner,'' said the computer educator. ``What's it going to be like when, if, either one of us or both of us get sick? How's that going to manifest itself? I don't have a lot of control over that. ``But I do have control in the paradox of life over myself and the way I approach it. And I have control over my emotions,'' he said, and he began to cry. ``And sometimes I need to let them go. ``We need to let go, at least that's my experience, to let go, in order to be,'' Tull said. ``To let go, in order to experience the presence of God. To let go of our control, in order to have more. ``We have holes in our hearts,'' he said, quoting a friend. ``And sometimes, they need to flow.''

DOC.HEAD: Catamaran Sets Atlantic Crossing Record
DOC.TEXT: Hoverspeed Great Britain completed a record-breaking sprint across the Atlantic Saturday, lowering the best time for a passenger ship by two hours and 48 minutes, the owners said. The ship passed the Bishop Rock light off the Isles of Scilly at 14 seconds after 8:25 a.m. local time, or three days, seven hours and 52 minutes after departing from New York, said Brian Reese, a spokesman for the Hoverspeed project in London. The record had been held by the S.S. United States, which made the crossing in three days, 10 hours and 40 minutes in July 1952. John Lloyd, captain of the 242-foot craft, said he expected to claim the Hales Trophy despite controversy over the ship's design. Hoverspeed project spokeswoman Lynn Harvey said the Hales Trust, keeper of the trophy, had confirmed last year that Hoverspeed Great Britain was eligible. However, she said, the curators of the Mercantile Marine Museum on Long Island, N.Y., where the trophy is kept, maintain it was not valid because the catamaran will not operate a trans-Atlantic service and had no passengers aboard for the record run. Hoverspeed Great Britain made its crossing with a 10-man British and Australian crew. The Tasmanian-built catamaran, propelled by diesel engines and water jets and capable of 40 knots, averaged 36.6 knots on the crossing, Reese said. Hoverspeed Great Britain was designed to carry 90 cars and 450 passengers across the English Channel between Portstmouth, England and Cherbourg, France. The first of five of the design, it is expected to cut the five-hour travel time in half. Hoverspeed is a subsidiary of Sea Containers Ltd.

DOC.HEAD: Last Prisoner Held Under Internal Security Act Released
DOC.TEXT: The government has released the last of 22 political detainees held without trial for more than three years under security measures that date to British colonial rule. The 22 were arrested in May 1987 for allegedly forming a ``clandestine Communist network'' aimed at overthrowing the government and establishing a Marxist state. Authorities accused them of infiltrating an opposition party, a lawyers' association, the Roman Catholic Church and an amateur theatrical company. The last of the detainees, 43-year-old Vincent Cheng, was given his conditional release from prison Tuesday. But Cheng and at least 15 other former detainees are still subject to restrictions on their freedom of expression, association and movement. Cheng and the others were arrested under the Internal Security Act, which allows for arrest without charge and indefinite detention without trial. No evidence has to be made public against those detained. British colonial authorities introduced the security act in 1948 to deal with a Communist insurrection in what was then Malaya. Singapore was part of the independent Malaysian federation until it withdrew in 1965. The Internal Security Act can still be used by authorities in Malaysia and Singapore to detain anyone considered to be a risk to national security. Opposition members in the parliaments of both countries say the need for such sweeping powers has long passed. Some contend that authorities have used the Internal Security Act to suppress legitimate dissent. Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, who is scheduled to take over from Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in November, said, ``I know that the ISA is a powerful tool, and in the wrong hands can do harm. But I also know that Singapore cannot be governed without the ISA.'' Human rights groups in Britain and the United States have said that arrests in recent years under the security act have been politically inspired. The Communist insurgency formally ended Nov. 26 when cease-fire agreements among the guerrillas and the Malaysian and Thai governments were signed at Hat Yai in southern Thailand. At that time, Singapore's Home Affairs Minister Shunmugam Jayakumar told Parliament that even with the end of hostilities, the security act was still needed to deal with other potential threats, including religious extremism, espionage, international terrorism and subversion. In Kuala Lumpur, the Malaysian capital, Home Affairs Minister Megat Junid told Parliament on Thursday that Malaysia still held 86 people under its Internal Security Act. Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said recently he had no plans to abolish the security act because it was very useful in a multiracial society.

DOC.HEAD: New Mayor Daley Steps From Father's Shadow, Wows His Peers
DOC.TEXT: For a moment, the shadow was gone. Mayor Richard M. Daley strode to the Comiskey Park pitcher's mound to the cheers of some 30,000 fans, a sun-drenched welcome witnessed by dozens of fellow mayors from around the nation. He tossed out the ceremonial first pitch to more applause and then joined his mayoral peers in the stands to watch as his city's White Sox dropped a close game to the Oakland A's. It was a sharp contrast to the last time the U.S. Conference of Mayors met in Chicago in 1968, when Daley's famous father, Richard J. Daley, was mayor and the city was bubbling with Vietnam-era social unrest. As this year's meeting unfolded last week, the younger Daley emerged from his father's shadow even as Richard J. Daley's legacy was everywhere to be seen. When the new mayor was honored by a company that ranks America's most liveable cities in cooperation with the mayors' conference, the award was named after Richard J. Daley. And when Daley was introduced as a conference speaker, he was billed as a veteran of dozens of mayoral conferences even though he has attended just two as mayor _ the rest he attended as the son of Richard J. Daley, onetime conference president. ``You kind of get used to saying Mayor Daley in this town,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat and ally of two generations of Mayor Daleys. Daley's father was mayor from 1955 until his death in 1975, controlling a renowned political machine that earned him the nickname ``Boss.'' As the son made his climb to power, critics warned that he would try to replicate his father's machine. His political successes, as a prosecutor and now mayor, were attributed to his name, not his abilities. But now, 14 months after becoming mayor, Richard M. Daley is putting a stamp of his own on Chicago. He is not without critics and his city is not without problems, including racial tensions that were a major issue in the mayoral race to succeed the late Harold Washington, who was black. But Daley has named minorities to several top posts, silencing some of his critics. And during last week's mayors meeting, he not only wowed his guests with a string of social extravaganzas costly $1 million but he also emerged as one of the group's most vocal advocates for more federal aid. At one event he spoke bluntly but forcefully about the burden cities face in caring for cocaine-addicted babies. ``I'm supposed to treat these people,'' he said. ``I'm supposed to educate these people. I'm supposed to give them a job. ... We can't do it alone. It's impossible.'' And in a city known for its toughness _ ``the city where people never walk away from a possible fight,'' Rostenkowski says _ Daley looks and plays the part. He travels with a large security contingent and usually arrives late. He won't win any awards for public speaking, but he gets his point across. During the mayors gathering he appeared equally fearless in taking on his critics or walking under the watchful eyes of his peers onto the ballfield _ where even popular politicians can get booed by fiesty fans. ``He's comfortable now, coming into his own,'' said a Daley political aide who asked not to be identified by name. ``There will always be critics because he is a Daley, but I think he's convinced most people that this isn't going to be a sequel.'' Daley has to run for a full term next year and appears a heavy favorite. He has considerable support in the city's business community, which bankrolled many of the receptions and other events held for the mayors. These included an exclusive showing of a Monet collection, impressive nightly dinners and a barbecue before the ball game. The guests had high praise for Daley and his city. ``Richard's got politics in his blood,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, a college classmate of Daley's. ``He loves this place.'' ``Simply outstanding,'' said Joseph Riley, mayor of Charleston, S.C. ``How can you not be impressed.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Emerge as Lobbying Force on Capitol Hill
DOC.TEXT: Police these days are patrolling the corridors of Capitol Hill and not merely to keep order. They're coming to Washington as lobbyists _ on handgun control; semiautomatic assault rifles; on labor issues. No bill to curb assault weapons or regulate handguns is unveiled without a gaggle of lobbyists from police groups to stand behind the sponsors and assure television viewers that the measure is urgently needed to preserve the peace. And while police groups do not give out campaign contributions, they can be a help in countering the slashing direct-mail campaigns against firearms regulation that have become a trademark of the National Rifle Association. The point is not lost on members of Congress. ``When I'm in Illinois, I will frequently say that I have a choice of being on the side of law enforcement or being on the side of the gun lobby, and I'm going to stick with law enforcement,'' says Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. He says that is a help ``because the majority of the American people are on the side of law enforcement, and they're sympathetic to the police.'' According to Jules Bernstein, legislative counsel of the National Association of Police Organizations, the groups can be more help than that. He says the association's president, Robert Scully, appeared in a political ad on behalf of Rep. Louise Slaughter, R-N.Y., assuring voters that she was a firm supporter of law and order issues. Bernstein says he now shows up at eight to 10 news conferences a year to put his seal of approval on gun legislation. ``I think the coming together of all these police groups on Capitol Hill is a very healthy development,'' says the former labor lobbyist. Labor issues involving police are crucial to many of the dozen or so police lobbying organizations at work on Capitol Hill. Federal legislation that would give collective bargaining rights is one that Bernstein's group backs. It also wants educational grants for police, opposes mandatory medicare, backs regulation of the sale of body armor, dislikes taxing employee benefits and scorns a proposed ``police corps'' that would provide $40,000 in reimbursed college expenses following four years of police work. The number of police groups has grown gradually over the last few years. They include the Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association, the Fraternal Order of Police, the International Association of Chiefs of Police, the International Brotherhood of Police Officers and the Major Cities Chief Administrators. Also, the National Association of Police Organizations, the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives, the National Sheriffs Association, the Police Executive Research Forum, the Police Foundation and the Police Management Association. With labor and management both on the list, not all of the organizations agree on every issue, but they are virtually unanimous in calling for curbs on military-style assault weapons and a national seven-day waiting period before buyers can obtain handguns. The idea of the so-called Brady Bill, named for former White House press secretary James Brady who has been campaigning for approval, is to give lawmen time to run background checks on the buyers. Gun backers acknowledge the police as being powerful political opponents. ``What you've seen over the past four or five years, is the emergence of the leadership of the police fraternal organizations and the city police chiefs as effective spokesmen and cover for those who would like to vote for some kind of restrictions on semiautomatic assault weapons,'' says Jim Baker, director of federal affairs for the National Rifle Association. As a result, the gun group has been forced to fight not only the traditional liberal advocates of gun control but national spokesmen for police themselves in the dispute over assault weapons. Police groups and gun-control advocates have not always been on such close terms. Thousands of police officers belong to the NRA and even the firmest supporters of the Brady bill and assault-weapons curbs concede they run into plenty of street cops who take a dim view of them. But the two sides have coalesced over the years with the Washington-based lobbying group Handgun Control Inc. playing a key role. Indeed, in the early 1980s it retained a former Fraternal Order of Police president, Richard Boyd, as a consultant to cement ties with law enforcement officials. He is no longer with the group. But the spadework paid off. Since then, gun-control advocates and lawmen have fought side by side in efforts to ban the sale of armor-piercing bullets _ ``cop killer bullets,'' Handgun Control calls them _ and defeat a 1986 measure designed to ease firearms regulation. The alliance has been such a success that the NRA a year ago was moved to bring hundreds of ordinary street cops to Capitol Hill to show there is another side of the story. And NRA's Baker says gun-control forces have made so much hay of their ties to the lawmen that it may be time for another such demonstration. ``In the short term,'' he says, ``we'd like to bring some 300 to 500 rank and file police officers from around the country to have another press conference ... This issue is far from over.''

DOC.HEAD: Flag Burning Issue Likely to Remain Hot on Campaign Trail
DOC.TEXT: Like it or not, Americans are going to hear a lot more about flag burning. It's proving irresistible to hungry Republican challengers facing entrenched opponents and a shortage of biting issues. Flag-waving candidates are well armed as a result of last week's House vote killing a proposed constitutional amendment against flag desecration. They'll have even more ammunition after a scheduled Senate vote this week. Whether the tactic will work is another matter. ``It's ultimately going to be a dud,'' predicts John Buckley, a Republican consultant. ``The flag is the political equivalent of Chinese food. You can get hungry for something else very fast.'' By all reports, public outrage over flag burning has subsided since the issue first erupted last year. And high-profile talk about how politicians can use the flag issue to their advantage in 30-second attack ads has raised public skepticism and increased the possibility of a backlash against political opportunism. ``Late in the 1988 presidential campaign, some of George Bush's flag factory politics were becoming a little bit of a joke,'' said conservative maverick Kevin Phillips. ``They (the GOP) have to watch out for that again.'' In 1988, Bush used a disagreement over the pledge of allegiance to raise questions about the patriotism of Democrat Michael Dukakis. Democrats are determined not to let that happen again. Today they are as vocal and emotional in defending their chosen symbol _ the Constitution _ as Republicans are in pleading for flag protection. There are plenty of ways to do that in 30 seconds or less, say the experts. Democratic media consultant Bob Squier suggested a TV spot showing the Constitution in flames. Democratic pollster Harrison Hickman recommends that candidates invoke the founding fathers: ``I'm not sure what George Bush knows about free speech that James Madison and Thomas Jefferson didn't ...'' The Republican camp, meanwhile, is less united on how to use the flag issue in this year's campaigns. President Bush, for example, has stayed above of the fray while Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas and House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia have taken on the attack-dog role. The Republican National Committee describes flag-burning as ``an American issue'' rather than a partisan one. The chief of the House GOP campaign committee says Democratic ``flag-waverers'' will pay in November. The flag-protection amendment already is surfacing as an issue in campaigns around the country. In Illinois, for example, Rep. Lynn Martin said she would use the flag issue to define differences between herself and Democratic Sen. Paul Simon, whom she hopes to oust in November. ``I won't call him names but I think he is out of touch,'' she said. Buckley, a former GOP spokesman, said early in the controversy that Republicans who exploit the flag issue ought to be consigned to ``intellectual hell.'' ``There are people who know better who try to use this as an issue because there are so few other issues that separate Democrats from Republicans,'' he said. Most political observers agree that the flag furor has been magnified by the absence of other cutting issues. The collapse of communism deprived conservatives of one key theme, they say. Howard Schloss, a spokesman for the Democratic House campaign committee, maintains the Republicans are clinging to the flag to avoid more substantive issues such as the economy, the environment, education and health care. ``The Republicans are on the losing side of these issues so they're desperate and grabbing onto things like the flag,'' Schloss said. Republicans who back a constitutional amendment apparently are in step with popular sentiment, which many of them use as a rationale for their stand. Two recent national polls by Gallup and USA Today found at least two-thirds of Americans favor a constitutional amendment to protect the flag. Yet almost no one, even on the GOP side, believes voters will choose candidates based on this issue alone. The best hope for Republicans will be if Bush decides to put his clout, prestige and visibility behind the failed flag amendment as he stumps for candidates this year, analysts say. Democrats can only hope Bush continues to keep a low profile. Their best bet is fading interest on the national level and an eventual return to the local concerns that generally shape House and Senate races. ``Voters at some point are going to tell these politicians to knock it off and talk about jobs, family and day-to-day life,'' said Democratic Party spokesman Mike McCurry. For the Democrats, that day can't come too soon.

DOC.HEAD: African National Congress, Now Legal, Faces Tough Scrutiny
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While Nelson Mandela is cheered abroad as the symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle, South Africans debate whether his organization can or should run the country. Shortcomings often were overlooked when the African National Congress was an outlawed underdog, fighting the white government from exile for three decades. Since it was legalized in February, South Africans have begun considering how it would govern the continent's most developed and sophisticated nation. Potential supporters, newspapers, rival groups and citizens of all races are asking questions about the accountability, principles, morality and efficiency of the ANC as it changes from an underground liberation movement to a functioning political party. Rallies, polls and political pundits indicate the ANC has majority support among South Africa's 28 million blacks, but it also has many rivals and has not had the opportunity to prove itself in an election. Many people wonder what the ANC would stand for in a South Africa ruled by the black majority. Socialism, democracy and nationalization seem to mean different things to different ANC leaders. Some of their statements send conflicting messages to young and often poorly organized supporters. Mandela and other leaders appeal for peace among warring black groups in the townships, but the ANC still supports a bombing and sabotage campaign against the government. Harry Gwala, the group's leader in Natal province, suggested May 1 that people who have fought the ANC, such as black policemen, could face firing squads under an ANC government. Gwala's statement ``reveals the extent to which his so-called future `people's government' will be autocratic, dictatorial and barbaric,'' said a statement from Inkatha, the ANC's chief rival in Natal, where more than 600 people have been killed this year. ``Inkatha is not the enemy,'' Mandela said on two trips to Natal. ANC leaders in the province publicly disagree. On the eve of his international tour, Mandela said: ``The only type of violence that we accept is organized violence in the form of armed action which is properly controlled and where the targets have been carefully selected.'' The main targets continue to be black policemen and black township officials and their families, however, not government buildings and military installations. A 1984-89 urban bombing campaign by the ANC military wing killed or wounded three times more blacks, Indians and mixed-race people than whites. Satch Nhlabathi, who supports the Pan Africanist Congress, said its military wing ``does not bomb toilets, railroads and shopping centers'' as the ANC's wing does. Mandela acknowledged in May that the ANC had tortured dissident members, but said it was not the organization's policy and that the leadership had dealt with those responsible. A few days later, Steve Tshwete, an ANC guerrilla commander, said those tortured were mutineers ``dealt with just as any army would do when faced with a mutiny.'' Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu recommended an independent inquiry, and declared: ``I'm as firmly opposed to that kind of activity by the ANC as I am of it being perpetrated by the government.''
