Several prominent supporters have said that, because of years of exile when the leaders could not consult the people they wished to represent, the ANC's operating methods became undemocratic. ``Democracy became a useful cliche, with little organizational relevance, as so many activists would wait for `the line''' from ANC headquarters in Zambia, said Farid Esack, a leading anti-apartheid figure in the United Democratic Front, an ANC affiliate. Fatima Meer, Mandela's biographer and friend, said a year ago: ``Repeated states of emergency have driven our political organizations into secrecy. ... Secret control also means manipulations.'' The influence of the Communist Party in the ANC leadership unsettles the government and its white constituency. Most analysts say at least half the members of the ANC leadership are Communists, but neither organization will be specific on the numbers. Mandela said the government's policy for 30 years of jailing ANC leaders, forcing them into exile and banning them from being quoted meant ``there has been nobody to explain the policies of the organization or to instill discipline.'' His pleas for an end to black-on-black violence, and for black children to return to school, have gone unheeded. Many speakers at ANC rallies preach tolerance and discipline to youngsters who have hijacked cars and buses to get there. When the young people leave, they often harass people who chose not to attend. Columnist Jon Qwelane of The Star newspaper and other respected black commentators have begun to dismiss explanations and demand action. ``I believe the measure of true leadership would be when leaders get together, discard their personal and ideological differences for the time being, and grasp the problem fearlessly and honestly,'' Qwelane wrote June 17. ``Up to now, they have not done that.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Face Possible Prison Terms In Alleged Contra Aid Bid Rigging
DOC.TEXT: A medical consultant and a former Agency for International Development official face possible prison terms after pleading guilty to charges related to alleged rigging of contracts to supply nonlethal aid to the Nicaraguan Contras. George F. Kraus, who was awarded $2.6 million in federal contracts, pleaded guilty in federal court Friday to bribing an AID official. He was president of Kraus International in New York. The Washington Post, citing court documents, reported that Kraus had agreed to cooperate in the government's investigation after an undercover agent videotaped him handing over cash last January for confidential information. The former AID official, John Massey, pleaded guilty to supplying Kraus with insider information and receiving more than $11,000 in return. Massey drafted and reviewed contract proposals while with AID, from 1987 to 1989. The investigation began after the AID office in Honduras received a tip in 1988 that contracts to supply Nicaraguan rebels with nonlethal aid were being fixed, according to court records. Kraus also implicated Donald F. Enos, the No. 2 AID official with the Contra project, who was sentenced in May to a year in prison and fined $5,000 for taking $93,000 in bribes from Kraus. Kraus and Massey are scheduled to be sentenced in September. Kraus faces a maximum prison sentence of 15 years; Massey faces up to five years. Each can be fined $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned `Black Widow' Killer Wins Execution Stay
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for ``Black Widow'' killer Judi Buenoano won a stay from a federal appeals court today to block her Monday execution, claiming that Florida's electric chair may malfunction and ``burn her at the stake.'' A three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta issued an indefinite stay this morning and agreed to hear arguments later, which means the death warrant will expire Monday without an execution. The judges on the panel were Gerald B. Tjoflat, Phyllis A. Kravitch and Emmett R. Cox, according to court spokeswoman Wendy Mason. A clerk at the Atlanta court called the governor's office to inform the state of the stay, said Michele Russell, a spokeswoman in Tallahassee. Late Friday, U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett in Orlando had rejected the arguments over the electric chair, and the governor's office immediately announced a new execution time of 9:01 a.m. Monday. Ms. Fawsett had granted a temporary reprieve Thursday to hear testimony about the chair and allegations of ineffective legal counsel. But she found after a two-day appeal hearing that lawyers had not proved their contention that Ms. Buenoano would suffer cruel and unusual punishment during her execution. That issue will now be considered at the appellate level. The defense claimed that the May 4 electrocution of Jesse Tafero had tortured and burned him before the third of three jolts of electricity finally killed him. They contended the problem was a faulty electrode in the headpiece placed over Tafero's skull, and that it had not been fixed. ``We are still concerned that our client may literally be burned at the stake,'' Nolas told reporters after Ms. Fawsett's ruling. Ms. Buenoano, 47, is known as the ``Black Widow'' killer because of the fatal poisoning of her husband, the drowning of her paralyzed teen-age son and attempted car-bombing murder of a boyfriend. She was present for the hearing and listened and watched attentively but showed no emotion at any of the testimony or the judge's ruling. Ms. Fawsett rejected as ``pure speculation'' the testimony by defense expert Fred Leuchter that the problems in the Tafero execution would probably be repeated. Officials for the state Department of Corrections testified that an artificial sponge in the headpiece caused the problems. They said it had been replaced by a natural sponge and called an electrician as an expert witness who testified the equipment was working properly. Ms. Fawsett judge also rejected arguments of ineffective legal counsel during Ms. Buenoano's 1985 trial in Orlando for the arsenic poisoning death of her husband, Air Force Sgt. James E. Goodyear, in 1971. Only one woman has been executed in the United States out of 130 persons put to death since the U.S. Supreme Court lifted its ban on capital punishment in 1976. North Carolina executed Velma Barfield in 1984 for poisoning her boyfriend.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Out-Invests the United States for First Time
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT Saturday; Time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Japan out-invested the United States in 1989 for the first time as Americans again failed to keep pace their major trading partners, according to a report on competitiveness released Saturday. The report, prepared by the Council on Competitiveness, tracks U.S. economic performance since 1970 compared with Japan, West Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada and Italy. ``America is looking like an aging athlete _ still on top but trying to ignore all the younger talent that is breaking into the lineup,'' said Kent Hughes, president of the council. In 1989, Japan spent $549 billion to modernize and expand its industries, compared with $513 billion for the United States, even though the U.S. economy is more than twice the size of Japan's. ``This marks the first time that any country has out-invested the United States in plant and equipment in absolute terms since World War II,'' the report said. ``In effect,'' Hughes said, ``Japan is putting twice the tools in the hands of the Japanese worker.'' The group's index, being released in advance of the July 9-11 economic summit of the Group of Seven industrial powers in Houston, tracks economic performance in four areas: living standards, worker productivity, trade and investment. On the positive side, the United States regained its position as the world's largest exporter, supplanting West Germany, which had held the No. 1 spot since 1986. U.S. exports totaled $364 billion, compared with $341.4 billion for West Germany and $273.9 billion for Japan. However, Americans are also the world's biggest importers and the United States ran a $108.6 billion deficit, the sixth year in a row the gap topped $100 billion. Americans continued to enjoy a higher standard of living than residents of all of the other countries except Germany. However, the other countries are catching up, having increased their standard of living 50 percent since 1972, compared with a 34 percent improvement in the United States. The council, founded in 1986, is composed of officials from business, labor and higher education. Its goal is to improve the ability of American companies to compete in world markets.

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery Opens Show of Old Master Drawings
DOC.TEXT: Eighty-six old master drawings from Italy, France and the Netherlands, including works by Raphael and Rembrandt, went on display Sunday at the National Gallery Art. The show was selected from the drawings collection of the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh and will be seen here through September 23 before it appears at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Texas, from Nov. 3 through Jan. 13. One of the highlights of the exhibition is Raphael's ``Nude Woman Kneeling,'' a red chalk drawing dated 1518 which the Scottish gallery bought recently from a private English collection. Andrew Robison, senior curator at the National Gallery, said other outstanding works included Giovanni Battista Piranesi's 18th century ``An Imaginary Prison'' and Jean-Honor Fragonard's humorous ``An Animal in the Moon,'' which turned out to be a mouse trapped in a telescope. Hugh Macandrew, keeper of prints and drawings at the National Gallery of Scotland, said his institution houses the most important collection of old master drawings in Britain and is especially strong in works from Italy and the Netherlands. Its ``Landscape with the Temptation of Christ'' drawn by Cornelis Massys in 1541 is one of the earliest dated Netherlands landscape drawings. Macandrew also praised Nicolas Poussin's ``A Dance to the Music of Time.''

DOC.HEAD: A Year After Being Purged, Zhao Ziyang Still A Missing Man
DOC.TEXT: The red double doors of No. 6 Fuqiang Lane are closed tight, and knots of police eye those who pass by the reported home of China's most famous political prisoner, former Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang. ``I can't talk here,'' said one Chinese woman, glancing nervously at the walled compound where Zhao and his family are said to reside. Zhao, China's former premier and the man once mentioned as the leading contender to replace Deng Xiaoping as China's senior leader, has not been seen for 13 months. Sunday marks one year since the party Central Committee met to purge the reform-minded Zhao of all party posts, accusing him of ``splitting the party'' and ``supporting the turmoil.'' He was replaced byShanghai bureaucrat Jiang Zemin, a political hard-liner. The ``turmoil'' referred to the student-led pro-democracy movement that the military crushed June 4, 1989. Zhao opposed the military intervention, but was overruled by Premier Li Peng and other conservatives who used the dispute to drive Zhao and his supporters from power. Zhao's last public appearance was on May 19, 1989, when he had a tearful meeting with student hunger strikers on Tiananmen Square. The next day, Li declared martial law in Beijing. Since then, his only known contact with the world came recently when former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said Zhao responded to a personal letter. His comfortable prison on Fuqiang Lane was once the home of Hu Yaobang, his predecessor as party chief who was also purged, in January 1987, for showing sympathy to pro-democracy student demonstrations. Hu's death in April 1989 led to the mass rallies that propelled the spring movement for democratic reforms. In the weeks after Zhao's purge, party leaders hinted strongly that Zhao would face criminal charges for supporting the democracy movement, or ``counterrevolutionary rebellion.'' Members of his family were also said to be under investigation for corruption. Zhao was maligned in the official press as a man who had ``vilified and repudiated the fine traditions'' of the party. Zhao, now 70, may have avoided a trial so far because he has long been a favorite of Deng. For nearly a decade, Zhao administered Deng's market-oriented reforms, which brought new levels of prosperity to China. The conservatives may be treading cautiously because party reformers, while in retreat the past year, are still a popular and formidable force, particularly in areas of the country that have benefited from the reforms. ``Zhao may have made some mistakes but we shouldn't blame him for everything,'' Guo Shuyan, governor of the central Hubei province said in a recent interview. Unable to reach a consensus, the party has left Zhao in limbo. His old rival, Li Peng, said in April that Zhao was a ``free man'' who was still a member of the Communist Party and enjoyed ``quite good living conditions.'' Li said Zhao _ reported to have suffered from heart trouble late last year _ was in good health, and he joked that Zhao received a bigger salary than he did. According to Hong Kong news reports, Zhao was summoned before members of the party Politburo in March and accused of seriously violating party discipline. But Zhao reportedly refused to admit any guilt. Overt public criticism of Zhao has largely abated. With the investigation into his case apparently going nowhere, the man still officially referred to as ``comrade'' faces an indefinite period of house arrest. Some talk wistfully of a comeback when political fortunes change. After all, Deng was 74 when he made his last return to power in 1979. But China watchers say Zhao has no political future unless China's leadership acknowledges it was wrong in its bloody suppression of the Tiananmen demonstrators _ an unlikely prospect soon. The government has also undermined Zhao's power base by arresting some allies, removing others from provincial governments and breaking up political institutes linked to him. Deng has proclaimed that new party leader Jiang is now the ``core'' of the leadership. Jiang has learned a lesson from Deng's former proteges, Hu and Zhao. He has carefully toed the rigid line set down by the aging leaders in their own walled compound not far from Fuqiang Lane.

DOC.HEAD: More Aftershocks Terrify Survivors; Relief Supplies Pour In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to move up details of conflicting death tolls, UPDATES with more countries sending aid and messages of condolence, trims. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK2,3,5
DOC.TEXT: Strong aftershocks struck northern Iran before dawn today, terrifying survivors of an earthquake two days earlier that some officials say killed 40,000 people and injured 100,000. Foreign emergency aid poured into Iran, but the Islamic government was balking at allowing international medical and rescue personnel into the affected region on the Caspian Sea, about 125 miles northwest of Tehran. The task of rescuers grew grimmer today, as hopes faded for finding anyone else alive in the rubble of dozens of towns and villages in the devastated provinces of Gilan and Zanjan. Attention also turned to finding shelter for an estimated 400,000 people left homeless by the disaster. There were conflicting death tolls. Hossein Zeineddin, second secretary with Iran's U.N. Mission in New York, said late Friday that according to the latest estimates from the region, at least 40,000 people were killed and 100,000 were injured. The official Islamic Republic News Agency reported 28,950 people killed, 25,241 in Gilan province and 3,709 in Zanjan province. The toll surpassed that of the quake that killed 25,000 people in nearby Soviet Armenia in December 1988, and a quake in Iran in 1978 that also killed 25,000. It was the worst quake since July 28, 1976, when an estimated 200,000 people were killed in China by a quake measuring 7.8 to 8.2 on the Richter scale. More than 200 aftershocks have hit since Thursday's predawn earthquake, which registered at least 7.3 on the Richter scale. IRNA, monitored in Cyprus, said one aftershock jolted the northern provincial capital of Rasht early today, ``making panic-stricken residents take to the streets.'' Three hours later another shock, measuring 4 on the Richter scale, hit the town of Roodbar in the heart of the quake zone, where workers were pulling bodies from the rubble, it said. IRNA said Friday that 6,000 survivors had been rescued, but by today, workers were mainly finding the dead. ``Rescue workers are becoming less optimistic,'' IRNA said late Friday. ``The number of those taken out alive has dropped sharply.'' In Tehran, the capital, the government ordered that 20 percent of all beds in private hospitals be set aside for quake victims. An official announcement said six major airports have been designated as centers for the shipment of supplies to the quake area in northern Iran and the transfer of injured to hospitals out of the area. The government appealed for international help, and nations all around the world responded with offers of aid _ including the United States, Britain and Israel, all regarded by Tehran as enemies. Iran reportedly said it would accept assistance from all countries except Israel and South Africa. The United States and Iran have not had diplomatic ties since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. Britain and Iran severed diplomatic relations in March 1989 after the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered Moslems to kill British author Salman Rushdie for his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' The European Community promised to donate $2.4 million, Japan $1.5 million, and Sweden $820,000. Other countries, including Jordan and China, planned to ship tons of supplies. Messages of condolence also continued to arrive, the latest from Libya and Saudi Arabia, which has accused Iran of terrorism and broke ties in April 1988. While the Iranians welcomed emergency supplies and cash donations, the government discouraged the presence of foreign rescue workers and medical personnel. However, some international teams, including a group of French doctors, had already arrived today. The British Broadcasting Corp. quoted a Briton who arrived with a British aid shipment as saying the Iranians indicated they did not want foreigners operating in the quake area. But he said they were allowing them to set up medical treatment units and supply-distribution points in Tehran. In the crucial hours after the quake, landslides blocked rescuers' routes on the ground and bad weather hampered airborne efforts. ``If you had come earlier, you could have saved my daughter-in-law. I was talking to her until a few hours ago,'' IRNA quoted an elderly survivor as telling rescuers in the village of Jamalabad in Zanjan province. Iranian television, monitored in Cyprus, showed masked rescuers in white aprons pulled dust-covered bodies from under concrete slabs. Corpses were laid on blocks of ice in open trucks. The television showed scenes of devastation, including the remains of an entire row of hillside village houses that collapsed and slid down the hill. President Hashemi Rafsanjani flew to the village of Roodbar in the heart of the affected region Friday and told Iranian television that ``everyone is helping, but with a calamity this disastrous, nothing could be enough.'' Farhad Shad, a spokesman for the Geophysics Center at Tehran University, told IRNA that 140 aftershocks were registered after the killer earthquake, which measured 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, according to geological stations in Tehran, Edinburgh, Scotland, and Golden, Colo. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: Television Picture Tubes Getting New Wide Look
DOC.TEXT: Television picture tubes, like so many of us, are getting wider. Not just bigger but stretched out sideways so they look more like movie theater screens. These new tubes being developed for the much-ballyhooed high-definition televisions of the future will have screens nearly twice as wide as they are tall. They'll also have higher-quality pictures _ and breathtaking prices. An international standards-setting group, the International Radio Consultative Committee, last month adopted the new wide-screen tubes as the world standard for HDTV, whenever it finally arrives. The future cathode ray tubes will have a 16 by 9 ``aspect ratio,'' or screen width versus height. That compares with the relatively boxy 4 by 3 shape of today's tubes. In today's system, a screen 4 inches wide would be 3 inches tall. In the same fashion, a screen 24 inches wide would be 18 inches tall. Under the new system, a screen 32 inches wide would be 18 inches tall _ a much wider, rectangular shape. TV sets incorporating wide-screen CRTs will be available in Europe this fall for use in a new TV system that is an interim step towards the crystal-clear pictures promised by HDTV. Wide-screen sets should be available in the United States by 1993. But they won't be cheap. Estimates of the initial prices of these sets generally range from $3,000 to $5,000. As with other modern electronic gadgets, though, prices are expected to fall dramatically once a mass market develops. Will the typical couch potato like these sets? ``We're going to have a real consumer survey starting this fall,'' says D. Joseph Donahue, a senior vice president at Thomson Consumer Electronics, which has joined with Philips Consumer Electronics to introduce wide-screen TV in Europe. But Donahue, like most other TV manufacturers, say the 16:9 system ``is the wave of the future.'' ``The only issue is the hour and the day'' they'll arrive, Donahue said in a recent interview. The wide-screen sets are part of a worldwide trend towards larger screens. Donahue said eight TV manufacturers have invested $1 billion in U.S. facilities to crank out 4:3 tubes in the 27-inch to 36-inch range, and they could retool quickly to produce 16:9. The half-dozen companies competing to have the Federal Communications Commission adopt their HDTV systems as the U.S. standard all will undergo testing in the 16:9 aspect ratio. ``The strong trend is in acceptance of 16:9,'' says Peter Fannon, executive director of the Advanced Television Test Center, an industry-supported center that will help the FCC decide on a U.S. HDTV system. Proponents of wide-screen TVs claim viewers will find the wider aspect irresistible. Imagine, they say, being able to see a quarterback hand off the football to a running back, and at the same time see blockers doing battle down field. Wouldn't it be nice, they add, to be able to see the full image of theatrical motion pictures when they're shown on TV, instead of having the sides cut off by the squarish-shaped sets in use today. The higher resolution of these screens will allow viewers to sit relatively closer to the their sets without seeing the lines that make up the picture, says William Connolly, president of Sony America Corp.'s advanced systems division. This will enhance the feeling of being ``inside'' the action on the large screen. A number of manufacturers have demonstrated these new picture tubes over the past year or so, but they're not expected to be introduced in the United States until after the Federal Communications Commission sets the technical standards for HDTV, about three years from now. However, European viewers will get a look at wides-screen tubes this fall when Thomson and Philips roll out sets for use with a satellite-delivered TV format known as D2-MAC. D2-MAC is a so-called extended-definition television (EDTV) system that offers improved pictures, digital sound and wide screens _ without being full high-definition TV. A true HDTV system is scheduled to be introduced in Europe in time for the 1992 Olympics. Japan could begin regular HDTV satellite broadcasts in 1993. Companies such as Thomson, which manufacturers RCA TVs, are betting the FCC also will approve EDTV in order to cushion the multibillion-dollar costs of converting existing TV networks, stations and cable TV systems to full HDTV. Thomson, Philips, NBC and the David Sarnoff Research Center have proposed an EDTV system in which existing sets would continue to receive the current U.S. TV signal, while EDTV sets would receive the enhanced picture and wide-screen format. But some TV industry executives question whether improved pictures and wide-screen views will be enough to persuade customers to plunk down big bucks for a new TV. Jerry Pearlman, president of the only remaining U.S. TV manufacturer, Zenith Electronics Corp., thinks viewers may balk _ particularly if TV programmers are slow to adopt the new wide-screen format. ``For many years, the new HD receivers will be primarily used to receive current low-resolution programming because most programming will continue to be low resolution,'' Pearlman said in a recent address to industry executives. ``TV manufacturers selling hardware always prefer to have something that looks new. That's why many of them overpromote the wide-screen concept,'' Pearlman said. Pearlman predicted some TV manufacturers will market 4:3 tubes that can display HDTV pictures at significantly lower cost than wide-screen tubes.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Given Colorful Welcome in Boston
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela arriving in Boston, quotes from Mandela and Dukakis. Changes byline. Picks up 3rd graf, ```I'll miss ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela was given a jubilant welcome this morning in Boston, a city cloaked in the colors of the freedom fighter's banner of black, green and gold. Mandela and his entourage arrived at Logan International Airport as a throng of supporters chanted and screamed a welcome. He was greeted by Boston dignitaries and presented with flowers by two young girls, natives of South Africa now living here. An enthusiastic crowd danced a traditional South African dance. Mandela, showing little signs of weariness, joined in with a few steps. Before being wisked to his next stop, Mandela praised Boston for its role in the American Revolution and in the anti-apartheid movement. ``On a personal note, the city of Boston has been responsible for looking after my children, my daughter and son-in-law,'' he said. Zenani Mandela and her husband live in Boston, and Mandela said while in jail he worried about them here so far from their family. But the city ``stood behind our family and took over the task of parents to my children.'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was among the throng waiting for Mandela's plane. ``We were the first state to say we wouldn't put our pension fund money in South Africa. Mr. Mandela knows this and appreciates this,'' Dukakis said. Boston has been eagerly anticipating Mandela's one-day stay. The black, green and gold African National Congress flag flew at City Hall Plaza. Green and gold billboards placed at strategic locations welcomed Mandela and his wife, Winnie. Banners were raised and traffic blocked on selected streets in preparation for the visit. Mandela left New York earlier today, after he outshined Eddie Murphy, Robin Williams and dozens of other celebrities at a big-money fund-raiser that capped his historic visit. Before leaving from John F. Kennedy International Airport, Mandela told reporters he hopes to come back to New York. ``I'll miss you. I wish I could have been with you for a time longer,'' said Mandela, with his wife Winnie beside him. ``We have had a most marvelous time in New York. We have been made to feel at home in almost every way, and the response to our mission has been beyond our wildest dreams.'' The African National Congress leader told the luminary-sprinkled crowd Friday night that the cultural boycott against South Africa is as important as economic sanctions in keeping pressure on the government. ``We're with him,'' said rock 'n' roller ``Little'' Steven Van Zandt, who helped organize the fund-raiser to benefit Mandela's cause and is a leader of the anti-apartheid cultural boycott. In 1985 Van Zandt recruited performers such as Miles Davis, Bruce Springsteen and Run-DMC to record ``Sun City,'' an album on which they promised they ``ain't gonna play Sun City,'' a southern Africa resort. ``We'll do everything he wants us to do. We're working for the South African people,'' Van Zandt said. Earlier Friday, Mandela spoke at the United Nations and talked privately with business leaders at the World Trade Center. His message was the same everywhere on his three-day visit to New York: ``Keep the pressure on'' until apartheid is abolished. Mandela's wife, Winnie, made a separate trip Friday to a gathering of women in Brooklyn, where she declared: ``One of our greatest priorities is women's rights.'' Mandela's 12-day U.S. tour is part of an around-the-world trip to cement support for his cause and raise money to continue the fight. From New York, Mandela will take with him about $1.5 million, according to the mayor's office. About two-thirds of the money was raised at Friday's celebrity bash, held at actor Robert DeNiro's Manhattan film production center, and at a reception at the home of movie executive Arthur Krim. Guests at each affair paid a minimum $2,500 and some stars, like Madonna and Oprah Winfrey, sent checks even though they couldn't attend. Mandela, 71, who was released from prison four months ago after 27 years, and his wife received an outpouring of love and adulation during their New York stay. More than 1 million New Yorkers turned out to see them and many more followed their every move on television. ``We admire you, we respect you, and above all, we love you,'' Mandela told throngs of exuberant supporters at a Brooklyn high school, his first stop after arriving Wednesday. That sentiment was echoed everywhere Mandela went, from a ticker-tape parade up Broadway's ``Canyon of Heroes,'' to a spiritual homecoming in Harlem to a sold-out concert and rally at Yankee Stadium. However, spokesmen for the American Jewish Congress criticized Mandela on Friday for what they called his continued embrace of enemies of democracy and promoters of terrorism _ Yasser Arafat, Moammar Gadhafi and Fidel Castro. The Miami City Commission dropped a planned welcome resolution for Mandela, and some Cuban exiles there called for protests Thursday when Mandela is scheduled to address a labor convention in Miami Beach. In New York, by contrast, Mayor David Dinkins called Mandela his personal hero and was at his side at every stop. ``I've seen people crying and shouting, but never anything like this,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said after the first day's activities. ``It was the single most memorable thing I've ever witnessed.'' Mandela began his day Friday at the World Trade Center, where he met privately with 150 representatives from Fortune 500 companies to relieve their doubts about investments in his troubled homeland. Out of that meeting came a proposal for a South African Development Bank to be ready to channel international investment into a newly democratic South Africa, an idea Mandela called, ``constructive and imaginative.'' Moving on to the United Nations, where he received a standing ovation, Mandela called apartheid ``an indelible blight on human history'' and a ``crime against humanity. ``The sanctions that have been imposed by the United Nations and by individual governments should remain in place.'' South Africa, a U.N. member, was ousted from the General Assembly in 1974 and was not represented when Mandela spoke.

DOC.HEAD: President Says His Gov't Never Promised a Rose Garden
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello says he never promised his government would be a ``rose garden'' but his harsh anti-inflation plan has given the country renewed hope in the future. ``How would this country be if my government had not had the courage to take drastic measures to lower inflation?'' the 40-year-old president said in a 15-minute nationally televised address Friday night. On the 100th day of his administration, Collor said the country could ``commemorate a great victory'' by cutting inflation from 84.3 percent in March to about 8 percent in May. The March 16 reform plan, which froze about $115 billion in bank and money market deposits, fixed prices and created the new cruzeiro currency. But it also propelled Brazil into a recession. Private companies laid off 400,000 workers and put some 700,000 on paid holiday. Unions say buying power has plunged 100 percent sinch March, and some private economic institutes claim the real inflation rate was as high as 40 percent last month. Collor, the first popularly elected leader since 1960, said only ``selfish people'' and ``non-patriots'' spoke fondly of the past, and he renewed his promise to fight tax cheats and speculators. ``I never promised a rose garden adorned with irresponsible and opportunistic speeches,'' he said. ``I took hard measures because Brazil could not go into the 21st century with a mentality and structure of the 19th century.'' ``We were all tired of a nation without hope, of the two Brazils, the eternal country of the future,'' Collor said. Collor said his government ``would comply with each of the promises it has assumed with the nation.'' Critics say Collor has demanded sacrifice from the private sector but cut back little on government waste. Without mentioning specific cuts in spending or dates, he said his administration would follow ``the example of modern, developed countries to cut government spending.'' ``We reduced by half the number of ministries, we are liquidating 50 more state enterprises and we are doing away with government employee priviledges in a radical way,'' said Collor, who has promised to fire or transfer 25 percent of the 1.4 million government employees.

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Satellite's Owners `Flawlessly' Send Up Another
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4rd graf, `The uninsured...', to UPDATE with quotes from news conference. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Browne said...'. Should stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: A launch company embarrassed over the stranding of a communications satellite launched a Titan rocket early today carrying a replacement satellite. The Titan 3 blasted off on schedule at 7:19 a.m. from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The satellite separated from the rocket 25 minutes later, and an on-board motor successfully boosted it to higher orbit within an hour after that, launch officials said. ``Everything went just flawlessly,'' said Edward M. Browne, president of the Denver-based Martin Marietta Commercial Titan Inc. The uninsured Intelsat VI satellite, valued at $150 million, is to replace an older Intelsat satellite 22,300 miles above the Atlantic. That satellite was to have been replaced by the stranded craft, which failed to separate properly from its booster March 14. Vic Whitehead, a Martin Marietta Commercial vice president, said there was ``great relief'' when the satellite separated from the rocket, as the previous one had not. Cheers and applause erupted from the mission control room at that point. ``When that thing went off (separation), we were all very happy, and we naturally let our emotions show that,'' Browne said. Browne said a wiring problem that led to the failure has been corrected in the rocket that went up today. Marietta Commercial has gone through ``exhaustive reviews'' preparing for the launch with help from Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the satellite, he said. ``They have not attempted to rub our nose in what we did,'' Browne told reporters Friday. The stranded spacecraft is orbiting about 345 miles above Earth, 22,000 miles lower than intended. Intelsat's board of governors agreed last week to pay NASA for a rescue mission. ``We're embarrassed over that failure. We don't like to have failures,'' Browne said. The newest satellite is expected to be working in early September and will join 14 others. It will be capable of transmitting three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. So far, there has been no service disruption to the 119 countries that constitute Intelsat, or the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization. But some short-term service likely will have to be denied because the stranded satellite would have begun operating about now, said Frederick Ormsby, spacecraft mission director for the Washingon, D.C.-based consortium. The craft became stranded when it failed to separate from the second stage of the booster. A rocket motor that was to propel the satellite to high orbit remained attached to the booster, and both fell back to Earth two weeks later. NASA plans to have space-walking astronauts attach another motor to the satellite during space shuttle Endeavour's inaugural 1992 flight. Ormsby said the satellite is believed to be in good condition except for the deterioration of some silver connectors on the solar panels. Intelsat expects to pay NASA about $90 million for the rescue attempt, Ormsby said. The consortium is negotiating with Hughes Aircraft Co., which made the satellite, for the 20,000-pound motor that will boost the spacecraft to its proper, stationary orbit. Martin Marietta has not been approached by Intelsat to help pay for the rescue mission, Browne said. ``We believe that we fulfilled the contract,'' Browne said. ``We've had no communication from them to the contrary.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: The Myth Becomes a Man
DOC.TEXT: On Nelson Mandela's U.S. first stop, he emerged as a stoical, single-minded revolutionary who takes his friends where he finds them, be it Libya, Cuba or the unrealized state of Palestine. Out of the mist of myth stepped a real man who led his anxious bodyguards on an early morning walk, who kept asking to meet Mike Tyson, who donned a New York Yankees baseball jacket and cap. ``Now you know who I am,'' a beaming Mandela told 55,000 people at a fund raiser at Yankee Stadium. ``I am a Yankee.'' To most Americans, Mandela was something of a blank slate, albeit a famous one, when he stepped off his plane Wednesday morning at John F. Kennedy International Airport. By the time he left Saturday for Boston, he had become like an old friend to New Yorkers. On his first day it became apparent, amid the endless cheers of ``Man-del-a!'' and ``Keep the pressure on,'' that Mandela had a simple message and would not change it for journalists in need of a fresh news angle. Accordingly, his two requests _ maintain economic sanctions against South Africa and support the African National Congress _ were enshrined in newsprint and videotape. Mandela also refused to cater to the sensibilities of those who differ with some of the ANC's allies. ``Yasser Arafat, Colonel Gadhafi, Fidel Castro support our struggle to the hilt,'' he said in response to a question during the taping of a televised ``Town Meeting'' with Ted Koppel. ``There is no reason whatsoever why we should have any hesitation about their commitment to human rights in South Africa. They are placing resources at our disposal to win the struggle.'' This shocked New Yorkers accustomed to political candidates who climb over each other to denounce the PLO and praise Israel. It became clear Mandela's love of human rights in general was subordinate to his love of human rights in South Africa. ``One of the mistakes the Western world makes is to think that their enemies should be our enemies,'' he said. ``We have our own struggle.'' When Koppel pressed him, Mandela told the renowned interviewer, ``You have not listened to my answers.'' If Mandela was more feisty than the statue some expected, he also seemed more human _ partly because of a frailty from age, medical problems, jet lag and 27 years in prison. The 71-year-old Mandela's arrival from Canada was delayed for several hours by his need to rest, and soon organizers were lopping some events from his schedule and curtailing others. Organizer Roger Wilkins said Wednesday night Mandela had ``reached the limit.'' Columnist Murray Kempton wrote that Mandela's tired face evoked a spirit ``that has endured much and must endure much to come.'' But Mandela kept undercutting concerns about his health with signs of vitality. An hour after he had remained seated while speaking to religious leaders at Riverside Church _ doctor's orders, he apologized _ he stepped confidently up the altar steps, looking like the former boxer and guerrilla whose daily exercise regimen got him through the prison years. He rose early Thursday morning at the mayor's house and went for a stroll along the East River. He was as curious as any tourist _ asking about the pollution in the river, the distance between Washington and New York. He told reporters he felt ``on top of the world.'' He also had time for children. The last person Koppel called on was 8-year-old Bernard L. Charles III, who told Mandela, ``Just send us a post card, and we'll do anything we can do _ even raise money.'' Mandela laughed, gave the boy a hug, and promised never to forget him.

DOC.HEAD: He Came, He Saw, He Collected $1.6 Million
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Amid the emotional cheers, the swirling ticker tape and the three-day hero's welcome, Nelson Mandela had work to do _ and the African National Congress leader did it very well _ collecting more than $1.6 million for his cause. ``The minute he touched ground in New York, the ground moved,'' said Suzanne DuBose, who handled the fund-raising chores in New York. ``We sold 20,000 tickets for Yankee Stadium in 24 hours. The phone lines were all lit up. It was a tremendous outpouring.'' Organizers of the trip had hoped to raise $1 million during Mandela's first stop on his 12-day U.S. tour. But DuBose said that figure was easily surpassed during Mandela's three days in New York, with the total climbing toward $2 million. ``It's been tremendous. We're really pleased the ANC will get so much money,'' she said. Organizers had not set a fund-raising goal for the entire trip. The majority of the money was collected Friday night at a pair of Manhattan fund-raisers featuring power brokers and star power. An estimated 200 business executives, at $2,500 a pop, met Mandela at the Upper East Side townhouse of film executive Matthew Krim. A short time later, Mandela headed downtown to Robert De Niro's new film center for a fund-raiser with by Spike Lee, Eddie Murphy, De Niro and musician ``Little'' Steven Van Zandt as hosts. Each of the 252 guests paid a minimum of $2,500, although singer Michelle Shocked signed a $50,000 check and others contributed $5,000, $10,000 and $20,000. ``That $50,000 check put us all in tears,'' said Robin Chambers, De Niro's personal assistant. ``We're pretty proud, since we've never done anything like this.'' The Krim event meant around a half-million dollars for ANC coffers, while the De Niro crowd donated more than $600,000. Support came from the unknowns, too: The Yankee Stadium speech, where tickets were priced as low as $5, was expected to produce more than $250,000 to fight apartheid, DuBose said. Shopping bags passed around a Harlem rally were filled with cash. One hundred Black Men, a service organization, passed the hat and collected $1,000 at their annual boat ride around Manhattan. An undetermined amount of money was collected at a Riverside Church Service. Winnie Mandela got in the act as well, collecting $50,000 at a Brooklyn Academy of Music rally. While the Mandelas were making money, the city was busy spending it. Police overtime for the trip's heavy security totaled $2 million, although the State Department promised to cover those costs, said mayoral spokesman Stanley Davis. The total cost to the city for playing host to Mandela would not be determined until after the South African freedom fighter's visit ends, Davis said. But he expressed optimism that much of the cost would be covered by corporate donations. Mandela's visit attracted support from sources strange and divergent. New York Yankees owner George Steinbrenner _ a Nixon-era Republican whose name elicited massive booing at Mandela's Yankee Stadium appearance _ donated the $90,000 rental fee for the show. Van Zandt, the political antithesis of Steinbrenner, organized the fund-raiser at DeNiro's place. Singer Billy Joel donated the stage and sound system for the stadium show. A coalition of religious leaders presented Mandela with a $200,000 check for the Nelson Mandela Fund, a humanitarian aid organization run by the ANC. The owner of eight McDonald's franchises provided $5,000 for ANC office supplies. The ANC leader also received a guarantee of future financial backing from 8-year-old Bernard L. Charles III during a television taping in Harlem. ``If there is anything any of us can do, just send a postcard and we will do it, even raise money,'' the boy promised Mandela on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Secord Agrees To Drop Iran-Contra Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra defendant Richard Secord is dropping an appeal of his conviction on charges of lying to a congressional investigator, a federal prosecutor's office said Saturday. Secord agreed to drop the appeal in court papers filed Friday, said Mary Belcher, spokeswoman for independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. The retired Air Force general had pleaded guilty last year to one felony count as part of a plea bargaining agreement under which Walsh agreed not to pursue 11 other felony charges against Secord. Walsh said Secord's appeal violated the spirit of the plea bargaining agreement and he threatened to put Secord on trial on all 12 original charges. The two have reached a second agreement under which Secord's conviction will stand and Walsh will not pursue the other charges, Belcher said. Secord was placed on probation for two years for telling congressional investigators that he was unaware of any Iran arms sale money that benefited former National Security Counsel aide Oliver North.

DOC.HEAD: Precede JERUSALEM
Four Wounded In Explosion At Dead Sea Beach
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with police blaming Palestinians, details. No pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb exploded today in a trash can on a crowded Dead Sea beach, wounding four people including two tourists, police and witnesses said. Police blamed Palestinian terrorists for the attack and said they had rounded up more than 50 suspects. The explosion occurred at the Ein Gedi campgrounds, a popular beach area frequented by tourists and run by the Ein Gedi collective farm, or kibbutz. The area is just south of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Shalom Ben Hemo, police spokesman for the Negev Desert area, said four people were hurt in the blast. He said three victims, including a German tourist, were sent by ambulance to Jerusalem's Haddasah hospital. A second German tourist received first aid at the kibbutz infirmary, Hemo said. At Jerusalem's Haddassah hospital, spokeswoman Ruth Mekel said two Israelis and a German tourist were brought there with leg, arm and back injuries. She gave no further details. Immediately following the explosion, police set up roadblocks north of the beach area and stopped all Arab cars that passed. Arab families with small children on weekend outings sat in the hot sun for an hour waiting for their identification to be checked. The incident occurred three days after the United States suspended its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization because PLO chief Yasser Arafat failed to adequately condemn an abortive raid on the Tel Aviv coast May 30. Palestinians and Israelis both have predicted an escalation in violence. Yohai Ross, who works at the beach restaurant, said in a telephone interview that police closed the beach, crowded with Sabbath visitors, after the incident and searched the area. Nissim Uzana Edrian, a witness interviewed on Israel army radio, said the explosives were inside a black bag thrown into a garbage can. ``I helped the wounded that were losing a lot of blood until the ambulance arrived,'' Edrian said.

DOC.HEAD: After Finance Office Massacre Big Question Remains _ Why?
DOC.TEXT: James Edward ``Pop'' Pough was known as a reliable working man with a sometimes-violent temper, but the rage that turned him into a mass murderer remains a mystery. After the shooting spree last Monday that killed eight random victims and wounded five more, investigators were left with one big question _ why? ``It is probably a question that no one will be able to answer,'' police Sgt. Steve Weintraub said Friday. Experts say a split with his wife and having his car repossessed likely helped spur the shooting spree in an auto finance office, even though both setbacks occurred months earlier. Pough, 42, entered the General Motors Acceptance Corp. office workers armed with a .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle and a .38-caliber pistol and without warning began shooting employees and customers alike. After coldly stalking workers cowering under the desks and firing at them point-blank, Pough put the pistol to his head and killed himself. Initially, authorities though the auto repossession was the sole motive for the attack, but then Pough was linked to the shootings of four people, including two who died, in his neighborhood the weekend before the finance company rampage. The motive for those shootings is unknown. ``What really drives homicidal behavior is rage,'' said Helen Morrison, a psychiatrist who heads the Evaluation Center in Chicago, which studies the psychology of violent behavior. Criminology experts say deep rage, coupled with frustration over jobs, relationships or life in general, is a common denominator to most mass killing. Jack Levin, co-author of ``Mass Murder: America's Growing Menace,'' said the shootings probably were triggered by the loss of his wife and car in the same month _ January. His car was repossessed and GMAC had sent him a bill for $6,394, but finance company officials said they last had contact with Pough in March. Levin said the triggering event, ``doesn't have to be immediately before the massacre and doesn't even have to be tragic from the casual observers point of view.'' ``It may just be the straw that broke the camel's back,'' said Levin, a sociology professor at Northeastern University in Boston. ``Most of these mass killings look more random than they actually are.'' ``He may have been trying to kill GMAC as a corporate entity,'' Levin said, or striking out at society at large by launching the attack on the office in the city's suburban Baymeadows area. ``We don't know what sort of crazy, maniacal fantasies were going through his mind,'' said Dr. Ernest Miller, a psychiatry professor at the University of Florida School of Medicine. ``We do know that he was selective in going to GMAC. ... He picked a place where he would probably not be opposed.'' Pough, a black man who held down a steady job, does not fit the model of mass murderers in the United States, most of whom have been white and unemployed, experts said. He was the type of employee ``we tried to keep,'' said Fred Houser, executive vice president of W.W. Gay, a contracting company where Pough earned $9.95 an hour as a construction laborer. Pough had a good attitude and hardly ever missed work, Houser said. ``He was always willing to work and wanted to keep his job. Obviously, something went wrong,'' Houser said. Despite his good work record, he had a background of violent behavior. Pough was fined $75 in 1968 for displaying a knife in a threatening way and had other arrests on minor charges. In 1971, Pough was arrested for investigation of murder, but was allowed to plead guilty to aggravated assault and was given five years' probation. Because his record was erased after he completed his probation, Pough could legally buy guns in Florida even though in most cases felons may not do so under state law. His wife, Theresa, won a protective order in March to keep Pough away from her for a year. In her petition, she said Pough had thrown a glass at her and had tried to hurt her. ``You better not get him mad,'' said Vanessa Gadsen, 35, a neighbor of Pough's for 10 years. ``Especially about things like money or his car. He would lend people money, but don't cross him and not pay him back.'' Other neighbors said something clearly was bothering Pough in the weeks preceding the killings. Quitaji Davis said he had been firing a gun at night for two weeks. ``A woman who had lived with him told us about two weeks ago that he said he was going to kill a lot of people,'' Ms. Davis said. Ms. Gadsden recalled: ``He always said, when he leaves this world, he was going to take someone with him.''

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Tells Nation He's `Deeply Disappointed'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Mulroney comments. Pick up 4th pvs, `The accord...' Minor editing thereafter to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XSTJ1, NY4
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney told Canadians today he is ``deeply disappointed'' by the failure of a constitutional amendment that would have accorded special status to French-speaking Quebec. ``We have missed the opportunity to turn the page and start a new chapter'' in constitutional history, Mulroney said in a nationwide television broadcast. But he reached out to the people of Quebec, saying that ``Quebec emerged from these negotiations with its dignity and its principles intact.'' ``Today is not the day to embark on new constitutional negotiations,'' he said. ``It is a time to heal wounds, to reach out to fellow Canadians. '' The agreement required ratification by the provinces by midnight tonight. By this week, Newfoundland and Manitoba still had not done so. The agreement failed Friday when Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells decided to adjourn debate on the issue indefinitely. The accord would have made Quebec a willing partner of the country's 1982 constitution had its five conditions been met by the nine other provinces. The conditions were: recognition of Quebec as a distinct society; a say in the appointment of Supreme Court justices; increased powers over immigration; the right to opt out of certain federal programs and a veto on future constitutional amendments. The agreement had strong symbolic significance in the province _ Canada's largest, with one-fourth of the country's 26 million people. Most experts believed there would be a period of reflection before Quebec's provincial government decided how to respond. But Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa, informing his legislature of the death of the accord, indicated the prevailing sentiment in his province. ``English Canada must clearly understand ... that Quebec today and forever is a distinct society, capable of its own development and its own destiny,'' he said. While Quebec officials made no attempt to hide their displeasure, they made no immediate threats of secession by their province, which has twice the land area of Texas. Some Canadians feared that the failure of Meech Lake would lead to a separation of Quebec from Canada _ a move that could have serious political and economic consequences for Quebec and Canada as a whole. In a 1980 referendum, Quebecois rejected a proposal to open talks with the federal government on a plan allowing Quebec political autonomy. The 1987 Meech Lake agreement, named after the government retreat near Ottawa where it was originally worked out, needed the ratification of the federal Parliament and the legislatures of all 10 provinces by midnight tonight. Wells' move scuttled a desperate last-minute federal plan to have the Supreme Court extend the time available to the Manitoba legislature, where Cree Indian legislator Elijah Harper buried the agreement under a barrage of procedural delays. Harper, who held an eagle feather in his hands during legislative sessions, blocked the necessary unanimous agreement to introduce the measure quickly. He later used other ploys to delay a vote until, by law, the legislature was required to adjourn its session. Then he prevented the unanimous vote needed to extend the session. That meant the Manitoba legislature could not meet again until Monday, after the deadline for approval of the agreement. Because Manitoba's problem was strictly a need for more time for procedural reasons, the federal government came up with a complicated scheme to get the time extended. When Newfoundland put off the vote, though, the federal move for Manitoba question became moot and Sen. Lowell Murray, Mulroney's chief constitutional adviser, declared Meech Lake dead. Many in English Canada feared that the agreement would have given Quebec extra powers. But constitutional experts such as John Whyte, dean of Queens University Law School, said the ``distinct society'' clause would have had few practical effects. Under the clause, the Canadian Supreme Court would have been given a guideline to take Quebec's special character into consideration when ruling on challenges to laws under the constitution. Some Quebec residents considered the accord's death a slap at their French character. ``They have showed us we have no place in Canada,'' said a grey-haired woman drinking coffee in a Montreal cafe. ``That's why I'm so sad.'' On a political level, many believed Mulroney was to blame for having waited to the last minute to work out a final agreement with the provincial premiers.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi King Donates $20 Million For Palestinian Uprising
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd on Saturday made a personal donation of $20 million to support the Palestinian uprising, the official Saudi Press Agency reported. The check was received by Prince Salman, governor of Riyadh and chairman of ``the popular committee for support of the Palestinian strugglers,'' the news agency said. The committee is in charge of collecting donations for the Palestinian refugees and those living in Israeli-occupied lands. The agency quoted Prince Salman as saying ``this personal gesture of support from King Fahd is to affirm his concern and following up of the Palestinian problem and the intefadeh of the Palestinian people against the Zionist enemy.'' Intefadeh is the Arabic term for the uprising that began in December 1987 against Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank. Israel captured the territories from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The Saudi government is already the leading aid donor to the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian uprising. The PLO is fighting for an independent homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Guards Charged After Undercover Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: Seven guards at a prison operated by the District of Columbia have been charged with distributing crack, powdered cocaine or marijuana to inmates. The officers were named in six indictments unsealed in U.S. District Court in Alexandria, Va. Their arrests were the result of a six-month undercover FBI investigation in which an inmate was an informant, officials said. Federal prosecutors said Friday that the probe revealed how guards at the Lorton Correctional Complex in Fairfax County, Va., enlisted inmates to make drug sales and arranged payments from outside the facility. They also alleged that the guards took bribes. U.S. Attorney Henry E. Hudson added, however, that the officers were not believed to be involved in a coordinated drug trafficking effort. ``What we have here are a number of isolated instances, all occurring at about the same time,'' he said during a Friday news conference. The investigation uncovered no widespread drug abuse by Lorton officers, said Walter B. Ridley, director of the District of Columbia Department of Corrections. His department runs the complex. The FBI launched the investigation because Lorton inmates appeared to have continual access to illegal drugs, said Thomas E. Duhadway, director of the FBI field office in Washington. Officials said charges against the officers ranged from possession with intent to distribute to introduction of narcotics into a prison. Each faces at least three counts. A civilian also was charged with possession of marijuana and cocaine. All those charged were released on personal recognizance bonds and ordered to appear for arraignments Monday in the Alexandria court.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Capsizes in Nile, 81 Feared Dead
DOC.TEXT: A ferryboat sank in the Nile in central Sudan, killing 29 people and leaving 52 missing and presumed dead, the Sudan News Agency reported Saturday. It said the accident happened near Kosti, a river port 168 miles south of Khartoum. The boat was traveling from Kosti to Aba island across the Nile, but the report did not specify when the accident happened. ``Search is still under way to find the remaining bodies,'' the news agency said. It gave no further details, other than to say the victims included men and women. Aba is an island northeast of Kosti. It is the stronghold of the Ansar sect, the largest religious group in Sudan. Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi, who was ousted by the army one year ago, is a senior member of the Ansar sect.

DOC.HEAD: Painting Stolen from Venetian Church
DOC.TEXT: Thieves broke into a baroque church on Venice's Grand Canal and stole a painting by 18th century master Giambattista Tiepolo, authorities said Saturday. The thieves stole ``The Martyrdom of Saint Bartholomew'' Thursday night by cutting it from its frame. They entered the Church of San Stae through a window they reached from the roof of an adjoining house, authorities said. ``This painting is one of the most important works in a cycle depicting the lives of martyrs painted by Venice's most prominent 18th century artists,'' the city superintendent of art and history, Giovanna Nepi Scire, told the Italian news agency ANSA. A custodian of an exhibit in the church discovered the theft. The pastor, the Rev. Aldo Marangoni, said the church did not have an alarm system.

DOC.HEAD: Condoms, Interactive Videos All Part Of The Show
DOC.TEXT: While scientists at the Sixth International AIDS Conference struggled with issues of genetics and clinical studies, Ray Russell-Fell was wrestling condoms onto an air pump. Russell-Fell, a ``rubber technologist'' for condom maker London International Group, is one of the big attractions among the commercial exhibitors displaying their wares. Doctors, researchers and public policy makers, on a break from weighty discussions, flocked around Russell-Fell as he inflated condoms to heroic dimensions to prove their resilience. ``I'd wait just a bit,'' he told a woman preparing to photograph the phenomenon, ``it has a way to go.'' The booth is one of four condom makers at the conference, along with nine drug companies, at least 15 companies selling AIDS virus test kits, and a variety of equipment, supply and service companies. In all, 91 companies are represented, evidence that acquired immune deficiency syndrome is also a marketing opportunity. For example, two salesmen at the Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories booth demonstrated the Philadelphia company's ``Hands Off'' Tubex Injector, a syringe-type device designed so medical personnel won't touch any part of the injector that may have come in contact with an AIDS patient. On the booth's wall, a sign with a bleeding finger reads, ``Farther From The Point of Danger.'' The promotion, said salesman Billy Walker, is drawing them in. ``Anytime you can show a person how they can save their life, they're going to be interested,'' he said. People also clustered around Magnus Communications Design Inc., a Vancouver company that produces interactive videos systems to teach students about drugs, alcohol, sex and AIDS. On its TV monitors, Magnus showed teen-age soap operas where the viewer got to choose if the actors will drink, have sex, use condoms. If unsafe sex is chosen, a dire consequence always follows. James Boyd, a Magnus vice president, showed off a handful of cards from educators attending the conference who are interested in the system. ``We're very pleased with the response,'' he said. But the real crowd-pleaser: Russell-Fell's exploding condom machine. The crowd started out small as he loaded another condom into the glass display booth. But more people wandered over as the condom grew to the size of a healthy dachshund, then an elongated watermelon. A digital readout displayed the growing amount of air in the condom. As the reading hit 40 liters, some covered their ears in anticipation of the soft pop as the condom exploded. Relieved laughter followed, and samples were handed out. Other condom exhibitors also did a brisk business. People crammed free samples into their pockets at the booth for Okamoto Industries, a Japanese company trying to break into the U.S. market. Okamoto, the booth's posters explain, is a highly regarded manufacturer of plastics for cars and shoes as well as a major producer of radial tires. But few read the information. ``Some people will stop to ask about the different brands, but mostly it's grabbing,'' said Ann McTaggart, a marketing manager. There are no samples but plenty of questions at the booth for Women's Choice, a condomlike device for women that is awaiting government approval. Still, Andy Halsey, chief operating officer of M.D. Personal Products, Inc., is bombarded with questions that would make a gynecologist blush. ``The men's questions tend to be more from the perspective of disease control and the market,'' he said. ``Women tend to ask questions on the personal side.'' Few people seemed to ask Tom Snyder anything as they swooped by his booth to snatch free cookies. But Snyder, who's selling home intravenous therapy programs, doesn't complain. ``This is the first AIDS conference I've been to,'' he said. ``The attendance is much better than the Digestive Disease Show I was at last month.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Will Meet To Speed Afghanistan Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to try to work out a compromise solution to the war in Afghanistan through a meeting of their experts in Washington, a senior U.S. official said Saturday. The meeting was set up by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in East Berlin on Friday night. ``We agreed that we are indeed getting closer on Afghanistan,'' the senior official said aboard Baker's plane on the flight home. The experts will meet in Washington and set the stage for Baker and Shevardnadze to take up Afghanistan again at a meeting in Paris on July 17. The main purpose of the meeting is to prepare for the unification of East Germany and West Germany. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev failed to resolve major differences over Afghanistan at their summit meeting in Washington at the beginning of the month. But the two sides have made headway since then to the point that Baker was able to tell the House Foreign Affairs Committee on June 14 that ``the one thing'' that continues to separate the two sides is whether President Najibullah would preside over the government in Kabul during a transitional period during which elections would be held. The Soviet Union is unwilling to oust the Afghan leader, while the Bush administration argues that elections held while Najibullah is still in charge would not be accepted by the Afghan people. The country, which borders the Soviet Union, is in the midst of a war between U.S.-armed guerrillas and the Soviet-backed government. The last of 115,000 Soviet troops left the country early last year. The senior official did not identify the Soviet experts who would be sent to Washington. He said they would ``engage with us on the nitty-gritty of where we were with respect to a possible Afghan-style election and a commission and what the role of Najibullah would be in the course of the process.'' During the final years of the decade-long Soviet military occupation of Afghanistan, U.S. officials expressed confidence that Najibullah and the Afghan army would collapse once the Red Army departed. That forecast turned out to be way off the mark. The Soviets left massive arsenals behind and are providing $4 billion in military aid and $1 billion in economic aid. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, senior military adviser to Gorbachev, remarked during the summit that the United States now fully understood that Najibullah would not be defeated militarily. Last February, Baker persuaded the Soviets to agree that elections should be part of an overall settlement to the war in Afghanistan. Najibullah's role has been a nagging problem ever since.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Concerned About Soviet Facilities
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, concerned that the Soviets might lose control of nuclear facilities in the event of ethnic unrest, have sought and received assurances from the Kremlin that they are under control, a senior U.S. official said Saturday. ``They are very conscious of that problem,'' the official said on Secretary of State James A. Baker III's flight home from a two hour and 20 minute meeting Friday night with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in East Berlin. ``This is not a problem for us,'' Shevardnadze told reporters who inquired about reports that tactical nuclear weapons were being withdrawn from restive regions in the south. ``If some weapons are being withdrawn from some zones, from some places, if weapons are being destroyed I think we should all welcome it,'' he said. The senior U.S. official, who insisted that his name be withheld, spoke guardedly but with authority about the problem. ``I can't get into a lot of detail about what we might or might not know about it,'' he said. ``Let me simply say that we have had discussions with them in the past regarding the security of their nuclear facilities in the event of civil unrest. ``They are very conscious of that problem, and that's really all I can say.'' Pressed by a reporter to say more, the official aboard Baker's plane added: ``They (the Soviet leadership) are aware of the issue. They've told us about it. We've discussed it with them, and they have assured us their facilities are adequately and safely protected. That's the assurance they gave us.''

DOC.HEAD: Religion Last Defense Against Court-Ordered Surgery
LaserPhoto FR1
DOC.TEXT: The Laotian immigrant parents of a 6-year-old boy born with clubfeet say they oppose court-ordered corrective surgery because they believe spirits inflicted the defect to punish the family. Tampering with the deformity could bring more divine retribution, say parents Ger Xiong and his wife, Houa Vue Xiong. Their son, Kou, has said he doesn't want the operation. The U.S. Supreme Court refused last Tuesday to overturn lower court rulings that ordered corrective surgery for the boy, but hospitals have declined to perform the operations without parental consent. The Hmong immigrants from Laos believe their son was born with clubfeet and a dislocated hip as punishment for a wrong committed by an ancestor, Xiong said through an interpreter in an interview. ``These people have no country any more. Basically, all they have left is their religious faith and their family,'' said Joe Reich, a lawyer representing the boy's father. Valley Children's Hospital in Fresno and Shriners Hospital For Crippled Children in San Francisco have refused to perform the operations without the parents' approval, said Ernie Velasquez, director of the Fresno County Department of Social Services. ``The orthopedic surgeons will perform the surgery if the parents want it,'' said Chris Monahan, a spokeswoman for Valley Children's Hospital. ``That's why we're here, to take care of children. We are not here to impose value systems and that's what the whole unfortunate situation has been about.'' Many Hmongs from mountainous northern Laos fled communist persecution after the Vietnam War. Many maintain Animist beliefs that include faith in a pantheon of spirits thought to control human events. The Xiongs have been advised by a Hmong shaman, or spiritual leader, that consenting to corrective surgery would continue problems they believe stopped after Xiong promised the spirits that Kou would be left as he is. He said the birth of another child with no deformities proves the spirits were appeased by his promise. Spiritual ill-will also was blamed for cleft palates that two of Kou's younger brothers were born with. The parents allowed those defects to be corrected by doctors. Social workers are searching for a hospital that will perform the surgery, but no operations would be scheduled until the agency meets with leaders of the Hmong community and family lawyers, Velasquez said. The case may be decided by doctors' refusal to participate in the controversy that pits parental rights and religious freedom against the government's desire to help the boy. ``I think if we don't find a medical facility that has the expertise in this area, I think the case should dismissed,'' said Susan Anderson, a deputy district attorney representing Kou. Velasquez said removing the boy from his parents' custody would be one way around the issue of parental consent, but no steps in that direction have been taken. Social workers got involved after school officials notified them of the boy's condition and his parents' stand against surgery. Doctors say the boy, who now is able to walk, will eventually lose movement in his legs without the operation. ``This little boy's condition is not life-threatening. The surgery is somewhat life-threatening. It's elective surgery ordered by the court,'' Reich said. ``Right now, this family is being terrorized, and they are on the verge of being shattered.'' If the surgery is done while the boy is still young, he may be able to walk with a limp, Dr. Brian Shaw testified in court. But even with the surgery, Kou still may suffer pain in his feet and require a wheelchair, he said. Shaw said that the parents allowed corrective surgery on the two children born with cleft palates highlights the contradictions of the case. ``They don't have a problem with surgery as a concept,'' he said. ``The problem is they are more afraid of what the spirits are going to do to them than what we or the law are going to do to them.'' But the Xiongs say the cleft palates could be corrected without fear of adverse consequences because those birth defects resulted from the spirits' reaction to early surgical efforts to correct Kou's defects. ``Kou is the one that God wants to be the way he is,'' Xiong said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of first item in rdp to CORRECT that towns are not in region considered `East Texas.' A version of the first item moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Texas Rangers pitcher Nolan Ryan, who less than two weeks ago nabbed a record-setting sixth career no hitter, is launching another career _ as a banker. Ryan has bought the Danbury State Bank, located 13 miles south of his hometown of Alvin in southeastern Texas. ``It's the greatest thing that ever happened to this bank. I can't imagine us working for him,'' said Annette Mandola, president of Danbury's only bank. ``The reality of it all, I don't think it hit yet,'' Ms. Mandola said. Danbury has about 1,500 residents. Ryan purchased the bank from PJD Bancshares, a group of investors in the El Campo and Louise area in Brazoria County, for an undisclosed sum. The bank has $10.9 million in assets and $9.3 million in deposits. Ryan is the sole owner. Ms. Mandola said Ryan has been interested in buying the bank for more than a year and is anxious to learn the banking business. She said he plans to oversee daily operations of the eight-employee bank once baseball season is over. Ryan was at the Arlington Stadium on Saturday and was not available for comment, said officials at the stadium. Ryan, 43, pitched his sixth no-hitter June 11.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Care To Cost Up To $10 Billion Annually By 1994
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Care for AIDS patients will cost Americans from $6.5 billion to $10.1 billion annually by 1994, a government study concludes. The figures would be much higher if they also included treatments increasingly being urged for the much larger pool of Americans infected with the AIDS virus but not yet sick, said Fred J. Hellinger of the National Center for Health Services Research in Rockville, Md. The center is an agency of the Health and Human Services Department. The costs of caring for a single AIDS patient rise with the length of the patient's survival, Hellinger said Friday in a presentation at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. For example, caring for an AIDS patient who survives 12 months costs an estimated $51,200. The cost doubles if the patient survives for two years. With the development of improved AIDS treatments, patients are surviving longer and costs are escalating, Hellinger said. ``The cost of AIDS in the United States will be greater than expected due to enhanced longevity and costly drug therapies,'' Hellinger reported. Caring for AIDS patients will cost about $4 billion this year, Hellinger said. The wide range of estimates for the cost of care in 1994 reflect doctors' uncertainty about how many cases of AIDS will be recorded in the United States then, Hellinger said. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta has projected that there will be 60,000 new cases this year, 71,000 next year and 80,000 in 1992, Hellinger said. Beyond that, the estimates become highly uncertain, he said. Hellinger estimated that there may be nearly 100,000 new cases in 1994. That number is lower than some previous estimates, because the increase in the number of AIDS cases is not occurring as quickly as it was 18 months ago, Hellinger said. Since then, the rate of increase in the number of reported cases has fallen, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Party Backs Joint German Elections in Six Months
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's second-largest political faction on Saturday endorsed joint German elections in December, greatly increasing the chances that one government will be running a united Germany in six months. Also Saturday, a leading West German news magazine reported that Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to travel to Moscow in late July bearing a multibillion-dollar economic aid package for the moribund Soviet economy. East Germany's Social Democrats had said earlier that joint elections, and full German unification, should not take place until late next year. Party chief Sabine Riebe said her party will meet with West German Social Democrats on Sept. 26 to merge their parties. She proposed all-German elections Dec. 16 to replace the West German vote, scheduled for Dec. 2. The decision came a day after the four World War II Allies that divided Germany promised to finish their negotiations on unification by year's end. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, speaking on West German radio, said that move also clears the way for joint elections before year's end. Kohl is proposing they be held Dec. 9. Under the laws of both countries, a new Parliament would have to convene within 30 days of elections. Regardless of the date, join elections and full German unity are looking increasingly inevitable by year's end. The German states are to merge their economies on July 1-2, ending East Germany's four decades of socialism. They are also working on a new state treaty that would outline the details of merging the two political systems. East Germany is expected to create a system of states to mirror the federal system in West Germany. The former Communist country will likely hold state elections in October. Until recently, it appeared likely that full political unification would not take place until late next year. But Kohl last month urged joint elections in December to replace the Dec. 2 West German elections.
