Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats believe they will stand a better chance of winning unified elections. The West German Social Democrats won three important state elections this year that were seen as a litmus test for the West German elections. The Christian Democrats of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere overwhelmingly won East Germany's first free elections on March 18. The Social Democrats in East Germany are members of de Maiziere's broad coalition government. The West German Social Democrats, however, are the main opposition group in West Germany. The left-leaning Social Democrats in both countries generally favor a more gradual approach to unification. The superpowers, meanwhile, have promised to keep pace with the moves by the Germanys. At a meeting in East Berlin on Friday, foreign ministers from the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain promised to finish their talks on the international aspects of German unity by the end of the year. They are negotiating whether a united Germany can be in NATO, which the Soviets oppose, and the status of U.S. troops in West Germany and Soviet troops in East Germany. The Hamburg-based Der Spiegel magazine reported Saturday that Kohl would travel to Moscow with a ``generous'' Western economic credit that would total between $15 billion and $19 billion. Most of that would be guaranteed by the West German government, the weekly said in its Monday edition, portions of which were made available to other media. A government spokesman in Bonn denied the report. Der Spiegel's reports have on occasion proved correct after being denied by the government. On Friday, the government confirmed it would back a West German bank credit of $3.1 billion to help the Soviet economy shift from central planning to free-market rule.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Man Gets 46 Months in Kidnap-Extortion Case
DOC.TEXT: A Detroit man was sentenced to 46 months in prison for his part in a plot to extort $75,000 from a suburban Virginia woman by claiming he could return her missing 5-year-old daughter. The man never was connected with the girl, Melissa Brannen, and she has not been found. ``It was a particularly egregious offense, yet committed by a young man who has done some very fine things and has some potential,'' District Judge Claude M. Hilton said in imposing sentence Friday on Emmett Muriel Grier III, 20. Grier pleaded guilty April 16 to conspiracy, extortion, threatening violence, possession of ransom money and illegal use of the telephone. The former Howard University student admitted calling Tammy Brannen twice in February with threats to harm her 5-year-old daughter unless the mother paid the ransom. FBI agents arrested Grier and another man Feb. 15 when an unwitting courier delivered the money to a Howard University dormitory. Also arrested was Anthony Girard McCray, 24, of Canton, Mich. McCray also was convicted in the case and is scheduled to be sentenced Wednesday. Neither of the two defendants has been connected to the disappearance of the Brannen girl, who was last since Dec. 3 at a Christmas party near her Fairfax County home. The judge acted after defense attorney David H. Hopkins urged leniency. The attorney reminded the court that Grier pleaded guilty without seeking a plea bargaining agreement, voluntarily asked that his bond be revoked and that he be jailed. He also was a witness for the prosecution at McCray's trial.

DOC.HEAD: Barber Fiddles Around in His Shop
DOC.TEXT: Gene Boyd may be a barber, but he has been known to put down his scissors in the middle of a haircut and pick up a fiddle. He warns his customers that might happen with a sign proclaiming ``We Play Bluegrass'' on the front of his Star Barber Shop. A group of musicians gathers there every Thursday and Boyd has been known to join in. ``My mother had a violin and it burned a hole in my soul until I learned to play,'' Boyd said. ``My father taught music, but I never learned to read it,'' he said. ``I just memorize a tune and play it.'' Boyd, 63, has been playing the fiddle since he was 8 years old. He also taught himself to play the guitar, bass and mandolin. He would practice by the light of a kitchen stove every evening as a child, then play for his mother. ``I'd say, `Does this sound like a tune to you?' and she'd say, `Lord no, go back to the kitchen,''' Boyd said. After a brief career in the U.S. Navy, where he was barber on a ship, Boyd returned here and started his own barber shop. He's been here for 40 years now, and has met and played with nearly every bluegrass musician that has traveled through the area. ``I just really love playing,'' he said. ``People will ask me if I'm ready to play, and I'll say, `I've got my pick in my pocket.''' He has paintings of bluegrass legend Bill Monroe throughout his shop. While playing at a Monroe music festival several years ago, Boyd fell off the stage, breaking his fiddle in 12 places and almost breaking his leg. He returned the next day with a replacement fiddle and a chair to rest the injured limb. ``My friends were afraid I wasn't going to be able to play with them the next day, but I did,'' Boyd said.

DOC.HEAD: Twin, 300-Pound Brothers Jailed Without Bond In 1986 Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A judge has denied bond for 300-pound twin brothers charged with murdering an woman, burning the body and dumping it in the Elk River. Circuit Judge Jim T. Hamilton denied bond Friday for Pete and Pat Bondurant, 35, who are being held in separate county jails for security reasons. They are charged with first-degree murder in the May 1986 death of Gwen Dugger, 26, of Elkmont, Ala. The twins were indicted in April after a witness came forward, prosecutors said. District Attorney General Mike Bottoms, who asked that no bond be set, called the case ``one of the most gruesome set of facts ever put on in this court.'' Pat Bondurant's estranged wife, Denise, testified at the bond hearing that the twins each had sex with Ms. Dugger after she bought drugs ``and got high to the verge of passing out.'' Mrs. Bondurant, who filed for divorce Friday, said her husband then clubbed the woman with an ax handle and Pete Bondurant shot her twice in the head. Ms. Dugger's body was wrapped in garbage bags and burned in a 55-gallon barrel behind the house, Mrs. Bondurant testified. She said the remains were crushed, put back in the barrel and dumped in the river. The brothers sat emotionless a few feet away at the defense table. Prosecutors said they will seek the death penalty if the two are convicted. No additional court dates have been set. Pat Bondurant also was indicted this spring in the 1986 death of a Pulaski man, whose skull fragments were discovered last month at a Lawrence County farm owned by the twins' parents.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Political Turmoil Barely Raises A Whisper in U.S. Border Town
With AM-Canada, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Canada's Meech Lake accord died Saturday and the specter of passionate Quebec nationalism gripped the nation, opinions along the border were divided by the St. John River. Most people on the U.S. side of the twin cities of Madawaska and Edmunston, New Brunswick, paid no attention. North of the river in Canada, people said a secession by Quebec now seems inevitable. They disagreed on whether that would be good. ``I went home for lunch and told my wife today,'' said Roland Picard, an Edmunston resident who has worked at Pro Photo in Madawaska for 28 years. ``It's bad. Separation of country. Have you ever heard of that without blood?'' Picard worries that New Brunswick, east of Quebec, will become isolated from the rest of Canada if Quebec becomes an independent nation. ``It will be hard for New Brunswick, for sure,'' Picard said. ``Look at the map.'' Others in New Brunswick want Quebec to drop out of Canada, saying that might let their province join the United States. ``I don't like their attitude, the Quebec people,'' said Oneil Devost, who has spent the last two years running an Edmunston nightclub, Les Prisonnier du Paradis, after working in construction for two decades in Hartford, Conn. ``I love the American way. The government gives you every break, and they let you work.'' A local Canadian newspaper, The New Brunswick Telegraph Journal, filled Saturday's entire front page with Meech Lake stories. ``Premier wants torture to end,'' said one headline. Turning on Canadian radio, listeners could hear virtually nothing but ``Meech Lake'' on the English stations and ``l'accord du lac Meech'' on the French stations. Asking passers-by from New Brunswick about the accord, designed to persuade Quebec to accept Canada's constitution by giving the French-speaking province a status as a ``distinct society,'' often elicited responses that were a mixture of French and English profanities. But people from the Madawaska side often responded to questions about Meech Lake by asking what it was. ``I wasn't aware that anything was going on over there,'' said Sharon Arnold, a worker in the Fraser Paper Co. mill, which straddles the border and is the largest employer in the twin cities. The two cities have a total population of 30,000. Maine Rep. Judy Ayotte Paradis, a Democrat from nearby Frenchville, was saddened to see Meech Lake die and saddened to see the lack of interest by local Franco-Americans who have had to fight their own battles for inclusion in the mainstream U.S. culture. ``It's just not something that they feel affects them,'' Paradis said. ``They see their battle is separate from the Quebecois. We're fighting for the same thing.'' Those following the fallout from Meech Lake can only speculate about what will happen next. But Donat B. Boisvert, the director of the Maine-Canadian Legislative Office at the State House in Augusta, said the instability could affect trade with all of the border states. The international commerce came to $302 million in Maine exports to Canada and $1.1 billion in Canadian exports to Maine during 1988, according to Boisvert's latest figures. The deadline for ratification of the Meech Lake accord was midnight on Saturday. Efforts to preserve it a day earlier had failed. ``Once everything settles, Quebec separates,'' said Gary Dube, a painter.

DOC.HEAD: Pope To Consecrate Controversial Basilica; Hospital to Be Built
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will consecrate a controversial basilica in Ivory Coast and give his blessing to a hospital to be built next to it at his request, the Vatican said Saturday. The pope will stop in the West African country on Sept. 10, at the end of a 10-day African trip that will first take him to Tanzania, Burundi and Rwanda, papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said. The Notre Dame Peace basilica in Yamoussoukro, the Ivory Coast president's hometown, cost $130 million, an expense that drew criticism in the poor country. Plans called for it to be almost as big as St. Peter's Basilica in Rome, Christendom's largest church. Last year, in a private audience with the pope at the Vatican, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny offered the pope ownership of the church as a gift, Navarro said. ``Accepting this donation, the Holy Father asked that the works carried out be integrated with other projects of assistance and social nature on the property'' next to the church, Navarro added. A hospital, envisioned to handle some 300 to 400 outpatients a day, will be built next to the church and the pope, along with consecrating the basilica, will bless the cornerstone of the hospital, Navarro said. He said other projects would be built on the church grounds but that they haven't been decided yet. Asked if the pope made building the hospital a condition of accepting the church, Navarro replied: ``I don't think it was a condition.'' When the pope received Houphouet-Boigny last year, the Vatican described the meeting as ``very cordial'' but declined to give details. Before the meeting, Vatican officials had said the pope had no intention of attending the inauguration ceremony, an attitude taken as a sign of disapproval for the massive project. The church's construction is seen as a sign of Roman Catholicism's expanding presence in Africa. Navarro said an international foundation will be established to manage the site, which is expected to draw large numbers of pilgrims from throughout Africa as well as the hospital and any future structures on the church grounds. While at Yamoussoukro, the pope will preside at a meeting of the Council of the African Synod, grouping bishops from 16 African nations, the Vatican said. Abidjan, the Ivory Coast's largest city, has a cathedral. Last February, pro-democracy student protesters occupied the church for 10 hours and were subsequently beaten and detained. The government let the students go after pressure from the Roman Catholic church. The students were demanding that Houphouet-Boigny step down and make way for a multiparty democracy. The president has ruled the nation since its independence from France in 1960. The students were angered by the reportedly lavish lifestyles of government officials while ordinary citizens have been suffering from a decade-old recession due to slumping prices of coffee and cocoa.

DOC.HEAD: Group Allows Owner To Change Miniature Horse's Racially Offensive Name
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who bought a miniature horse without knowing its registered name included a racial epithet may change its racially offensive name without affecting its pedigree, officials ruled. The executive board of the American Miniature Horse Association voted Friday to allow Linda Rose of Atacosa to modify the offensive portion of the horse's name, Nigger Boy's Little Flash. The board also voted unanimously to give the organization's registrar the right to request that any names derogatory to race, creed, color or nationality of origin be changed. Ms. Rose had purchased her miniature horse by lot number, unaware of its registered name. She had complained about being unable to change the name after finding she could not enter it in horse shows without using its full name. She had asked to change the horse's name to N.B. Little Flash.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Mulroney's Meech Lake Speech
With AM-Canada, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's televised Meech Lake address Saturday.

On June 9, here in Ottawa, the 10 provincial premiers and I reached an agreement on making the Meech Lake accord part of Canada's constitution. All of us agreed to improve Meech Lake in response to concerns that had been expressed over the past three years by women, Northerners, minority language groups and aboriginal Canadians. The premiers of New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Manitoba agreed to use every possible effort to arrive at a decision by June 23. On June 15, the New Brunswick legislature passed the accord unanimously. And in the two weeks since June 9, Manitoba tried to overcome procedural obstacles and adopt the accord. The three Manitoba party leaders spoke in favor of the agreement. With more time, there appeared to be every prospect that the accord would be passed. However, yesterday evening, the last remaining hope that the accord would be ratified was dashed when the House of Assembly of Newfoundland and Labrador adjourned without a vote. This action means the current round of constitutional reform has come to an end. Today, we must guard against two dangers; first, to despair that anything can be done and, second, to delude ourselves that nothing has happened. In saying ``yes'' to Canada in the 1980 referendum, Quebecers were promised a renewed federalism. But the Constitution Act of 1982 was not accepted by Quebec because it did not respond to the expectations raised in 1980. In particular, it did not reconcile the need to preserve the distinctiveness that Quebec brings to Canada with the need to preserve the equality of all provinces and of all Canadians. The Meech Lake accord was designed to bridge those realities. I believe sincerely that it was in the interest of all Canadians that it be ratified. But the outcome is clear; we have fallen short of the unanimous consent required and the accord has not passed. It is important that Canadians understand why this has happened. The accord, which was drafted to achieve unity, became over three years a lightning rod for discontent about budgets, interest rates, free trade and taxes. It attracted accusations of favoritism and sentiments of rejections and stimulated regional rivalries and even linguistic tensions. Much of the discontent of Canadians found expression in hostility to the Meech Lake accord. Its original purpose, as agreed to by the premiers in Edmonton in 1986, was only to bring Quebec back into the constitutional family. But the accord came to be expected to respond to all the constitutional preoccuptions of the country. That we did not succeed is, at least partly, also the failure of the constitutional amending procedures. Under the 1982 procedures, the premiers and I were required to reopen negotiations and reproduce unanimity every time a new provincial leader was elected who chose not to honor the undertaking of his predecessor. Or, in the case of Newfoundland, when a new premier was elected who chose to rescind the approval of the previous legislature. But we had created an historic consensus around the accord and, by persevering, came very close to maintaining it. It was endorsed by 10 provincial premiers representing four different political parties. It was approved by eight provincial legislatures representing 94 percent of the population, and the three political leaders of the ninth province had publicly committed themselves to passing it. It was passed by the House of Commons on two separate occasions by overwhelming majorities. Despite all of this effort, we have missed an opportunity to turn the page and to start a new chapter of constitutional development. While the world gears up for the 21th century, we have failed to resolve a debate that predates Confederation itself. That is why I am so deeply disappointed that this attempt at constitutional reform has failed. To our friends and partners abroad, I urge that this situation be kept in perspective. Canadians have always overcome challenges to our unity and we shall do so again. With a population that totals only 26 million, we have built the eighth-most powerful economy in the world, with one of the highest standards of living and one of the best qualities of life. It would be unwise for anyone to underestimate this industrious and resource-rich nation of hard working and productive people. Canada's economic prospects continue to be among the most exciting and promising of any country in the world. The government will continue to pursue policies designed to fulfill that promise. To my fellow Quebecers, I want to say how dismayed I am that Quebec has not, at this time, been able to rejoin the constitutional family with honor and enthusiasm. But Quebec emerged from these negotiations with its dignity and its principles intact. Quebec was never isolated and, in fact, was a member of the majority throughout. Quebec's concerns, as eloquently stated by Premier (Robert) Bourassa, were supported time and time again by English-speaking premiers whose sensitivity was always in evidence. For seven long days, 10 provincial premiers and I struggled to find the basis of reintegrating Quebec into the Canadian constitutional family. However, we were not successful and there are potentially significant implications for Canada because actions do have consequences. The debate over the past three years has demonstrated that Canada has changed profoundly _ and its outcome signals an era of further change. Today is not the day to launch new constitutional initiatives. It is a time to mend divisions, and heal wounds and reach out to fellow Canadians. There is much to reflect on before we try again to amend the Constitution. One thing is very clear; we simply must find a better way to do it. In the coming months and years, we must find a way to reconcile the need for public participation and open democratic process with the legal requirements now in the Constitution. I do not hide from you my great disappointment at the setback Canadians have suffered today. But there is no dishonor in having tried to overcome a serious threat to our unity. No achievement is possible without great effort. Such effort always carries with it the risk of failure. But I would rather have failed trying to advance the cause of Canada's unity than to have simply played it safe, done nothing or criticized from the sidelines. To govern is to choose. To lead is to run the risk of failure. We did not succeed but the failure to ratify the accord was not the failure of Canada. Canada is not a nation of defeatists _ and this is not a government of quitters. We will all be back at work next week. We will implement an agenda of national policy initiatives to respond to the economic and social priorities of Canadians. We will initiate programs to bring Canadians together and bridge the solitudes in which so many English- and French-speaking Canadians still live. There is more to this country than constitutional papers; Canada is more _ much more _ than dry parchment lying in a drawer in the National Archives. Canada is our inheritance from our parents and our legacy to our children. Canada is admired and respected around the world. I am not prepared to give up on all of that _ or any of that. Despite this setback, despite this great disappointment, the idea of a truly united, generous and tolerant Canada endures. And will, eventually, prevail. Thank you and good afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 26 in Attempted Protest March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with official saying right-wing whites the most likely suspect. Pick up 3rd pvs, `The attacks...' ADDS details at bottom. Adds byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday arrested 26 demonstrators who tried to march in protest of police actions in the black townships. In a separate development, two offices of the ruling National Party were bombed Friday night but no one was hurt, police said. Roelof Meyer, the deputy minister for constitutional development, said right-wing whites were the most likely suspects. No one claimed responsibility for the attacks, which occurred in a Johannesburg suburb and in Helderkruin, west of Johannesburg, police said. The attacks came hours after police released 11 whites questioned about an alleged right-wing plot to assassinate President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. In Cape Town, several dozen protesters sought to march on the Athlone police station just outside Cape Town, but police said the activists had not obtained the required official permission. Police spokeswoman Lt. Denise Brand said 26 marchers were arrested after ignoring a police warning to disperse. The protesters resisted, and some were wrestled to the ground and put into a police van. The marchers were led by Moslem leader Imam Hassan Solomons and Franklin Sonn, president of the 30,000-member Cape Teachers Professional Association. The march was organized by the Belgravia Youth Congress, which is aligned with the African National Congress. The ANC is the largest organization fighting the white-led government. More than 600 blacks have been killed this year in violence throughout the country, mostly in factional fighting in the eastern province of Natal. Dozens of protesters also have been killed by police during demonstrations in black townships. On June 8, de Klerk lifted state of emergency regulations in three provinces but left them in place in Natal. In other demonstrations Saturday: _ About 2,000 workers and activists marched peacefully through the center of Cape Town in support of striking municipal and shop workers. _ Several hundred members of Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization, marched to the British and Italian consulates in Johannesburg to demand an end to economic sanctions against South Africa. Inkatha says sanctions, imposed to protest apartheid, cause increased unemployment and suffering amongst blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Pope To Receive Ukrainian Bishops Individually
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will open the first meeting of Ukrainian bishops in more than four decades by receiving each bishop privately, the Vatican said Saturday. The change from the pope's usual opening with the entire group is a sign of special concern for the Ukrainian church, which was suppressed by Soviet dictator Josef Stalin in 1946. ``The pope wanted to begin with a human rapport,'' papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said. ``They can talk, greet each other, get to know each other.'' The meetings are scheduled for Monday and Tuesday. After the hour set aside Monday for the private talks with the 10 bishops, the pope will address the gathering, which will also be attended by Vatican officials and Ukrainian church bishops in the United States and Canada. Until the Kremlin's recent softening toward the Ukrainian church, bishops there were appointed and worked secretly. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, when he met with the pope last fall, promised passage of a law granting religious freedom in the Soviet Union. The legislation is still pending, and the Ukrainian church is still not recognized officially. Stalin forced the church to merge with the officially sanctioned Russian Orthodox Church, which took control of property of the Ukrainian church. The church wants the return of or compensation for the confiscated churches. The Ukrainian church survived by going underground. It is believed to have more than 4 million followers in the Soviet Union. The dean of the bishops coming from the Ukraine for the meeting is Monsignor Volodymyr Sterniuk of Lvov, who is in his 80s. On Sunday the 10 bishops were scheduled to say Mass with Ukrainian Cardinal Ivan Lubachivsky at a church in Rome. Named a cardinal in 1985, he is based in Rome. The 10 bishops will have lunch with the pope in his apartment Monday, after the opening session, Navarro said. ``You can say that the pope's personal intervention made it possible for these people to come here,'' Navarro said, referring to the bishops from the Ukraine. He declined to say exactly what the pope did to make their visit possible but indicated there had been bureaucratic problems. The bishops' journey to Rome follows the establishment of Vatican-Soviet relations in March and the exchange of diplomatic representatives. The envoys met Thursday at the Vatican to discuss the activity of the Catholic Church in the Soviet Union and other issues, Navarro said.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-liner Says He's Not A `Political Terror'
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Polozkov, a hard-liner opposed to many reforms and now head of the Russian republic's Communist Party, said Saturday he is not the political terror he has been made out to be. The Russian Federation elected Polozkov, an economist from Krasnodar, to the post Friday night. He gained national fame three weeks ago when populist Boris N. Yeltsin defeated him in the campaign for the presidency of Russia, the Soviet Union's largest republic. Although an outspoken critic of current reforms, Polozkov told a news conference Saturday that he would support Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as head of the national party and would try to work out differences with radical reformists. ``Some people call me a rightist conservative, some people call me a difficult person, some call me unmanageable or disobedient, some call me unreceptive to innovations,'' he said. ``I'm not as terrible as I'm portrayed to be. I'm for consolidation,'' Polozkov said, meaning that he wants members to overcome their divisions and stay together in the party. Although Polozkov has harshly attacked Gorbachev's reforms, the Soviet president backed Polozkov in his campaign against Yeltsin. Gorbachev smiled broadly Saturday as the Russian party chief strode to the dais at the party's meeting to claim the center seat as his own. In an interview with the official Tass news agency, Polozkov also said he had no quarrel with Yeltsin. ``We had no confrontation,'' he said. ``We shall simply work together.'' Polozkov rejected warnings from radical reformists at the party meeting that his election would touch off mass defections from the Communist Party. ``I do not believe that party organizations will begin acting like this in protest, unless these party organizations are provoked deliberatly by some forces,'' he told Tass. Polozkov, a 55-year-old party chief in Krasnodar, has appealed for strict party discipline and has condemned informal political groups. He also has fought cooperatives, the private businesses introduced by Gorbachev as part of his economic reforms. In a speech Wednesday, Polozkov rejected reformers' demands for the party to apologize for decades of dictatorship. ``It's immoral to blame the entire party for the mistakes of certain former and present leaders, and even to demand party repentence,'' he said. However, Polozkov appeared to take a more conciliatory line in his interview with Tass, saying he was in favor of cooperation with all democratic forces supporting Gorbachev's program of restructuring, known as perestroika. He said he would take steps to avoid a split between conservatives and reformists, echoing remarks he made before the vote Friday when he said: ``It is necessary to rescue the party from disintegration from within _ both from those who are on the left and those who are on the right.''

DOC.HEAD: Blast At Popular Beach Injures Two Israelis, Two West German Tourists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs at end with details of unrest.
DOC.TEXT: A pipe bomb exploded Saturday in a trash can on a crowded Dead Sea beach, wounding four people, including two West German tourists, officials and witnesses said. Negev police commander Shlomo Arnishkin said Palestinian terrorists were behind the attack and Negev police sokesman Shalom Ben Hemo said officers had detained dozens of Arabs. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. ``At this point, we are talking about a pipe bomb put into a plastic trash can. We think that this was a terrorist act and have detained more than 50 suspects,'' Arnishkin said on Israel army radio. The blast occurred three days after the United States suspended its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, saying PLO chief Yasser Arafat failed to adequately condemn an abortive raid on the Tel Aviv coast May 30. The decision provoked angry reaction from the PLO and threats of reprisal against U.S. targets by Palestinian groups. Palestinians and Israelis both have predicted an escalation in violence. The explosion occurred at the Ein Gedi campgrounds, a popular beach area frequented by tourists run by the Ein Gedi collective farm, or kibbutz. The area is just south of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Spokesman Ben Hemo said three of the victims, including one German tourist, were sent by ambulance to Jerusalem's Haddasah hospital. The fourth victim, the second German tourist, received first aid at the kibbutz infirmary, Hemo said. Haddassah hospital spokeswoman Ruth Mekel said two Israelis and a German tourist were brought there with leg, arm and back injuries but could give no further details. Israel army radio reported that the injured Germans were actors from the Bochoum playhouse in West Germany. The radio said the hospitalized German actor was in good condition. The condition of the Israelis was not immediately available. Following the explosion, police set up roadblocks north of the beach area and stopped all Arab cars that passed, detaining several. Arab families with small children on weekend outings sat in the hot sun for an hour waiting for their identification to be checked. Yohai Ross, from the collective farm Ein Gedi who works at the beach restaurant, said in a telephone interview that police closed the crowded beach after the explosion and searched the area. Nissim Uzana Edrian, a witness interviewed on Israel army radio, said the explosives were inside a black bag thrown into a garbage can. ``The bomb exploded when all the people were on the beach and not really aware of what was happening,'' he said.``I helped the wounded that were losing a lot of blood.'' The explosion was the second this month. A pipe bomb blast in Jerusalem's main market killed one Israeli and wounded nine others. In the east Jerusalem quarter of Silwan police arrested thirty Palestinians for rioting Friday after a curfew was imposed, spokesman Uzi Sandori said. The rioting started after police shot to death an Arab youth. The police also clamped curfews on east Jerusalem neighborhoods Abu Tor and Ras El Mud to prevent further rioting, Sandori said. In the occupied West Bank, the body of Hiam Raji, a 42-year-old Palestinian mother of two, was found in orchards near the Arab town of Tulkarm, an army spokesman said. Arab reporters said the woman was suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Her death brings to 226 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs on charges of collaboration since the start of the 30-month uprising. Some 719 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers, police and civilians. Forty-five Israelis have been slain by Palestinians. Also Saturday, a 9-year-old girl was shot in the head with a live bullet while standing in front of her home in the West Bank. She was transferred to Ramallah hospital in serious condition, hospital authorities said. The army confirmed that a 9-year-old girl was wounded in clashes, but said that only plastic-coated metal bullets were used to disperse stone-throwers.

DOC.HEAD: Bidders Take Home Pricey Souvenirs of the Savings and Loan Debacle
DOC.TEXT: It was going, going, gone for relics of a failed savings and loan's once majestic empire Saturday as banking regulators put fine china, rare books and other extravagances on the auction block. ``We're going into the ring for the taxpayers,'' said auctioneer Jim Gall, who opened the proceedings with the $1,300 sale of CenTrust Savings Bank Chairman David Paul's personal mahogany humidor. ``Every dollar raised lessens the cost of the S&L crisis for the taxpayers.'' The 11th-floor marble vestibule of the CenTrust tower was packed with more than 400 people eager to bid or just view the luxury items of the bank chairman accused by regulators of using the thrift as his ``personal piggy bank.'' Most of the items came from the failed savings bank's executive dining rooms and Paul's private office. ``You don't see something like this every day,'' said Gall, displaying a giant mutton serving dish with an 80-pound lid that drew a high bid of $3,500. Up for sale were 1,450 Baccarat crystal goblets, dozens of Limoges china sets, platinum serving plates, gold-plated ice tongs and oddities like crystal jam jar coasters and a bone holder for carving roasts. Paul, a target of thrift investigators, compiled an office library that included a 28-volume collection of H.G. Wells works signed by the author and a 166-year-old original edition of Sir Walter Scott's ``Red Gauntlet.'' The auction drew a $25,000 bid for a contemporary painting, ``Paul's Pride,'' one of the few artworks that remained after regulators earlier ordered the sale of CenTrust's art collection valued at $30 million. The works raised nearly $25 million. The paintings, including ``Portrait of a Man as Mars'' by Flemish master Peter Paul Rubens, are often cited as examples of the excesses that led to the nation's thrift debacle. Last month, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady roughly doubled his earlier estimate of what bailing out the thrift industry will cost this year, guessing between $90 billion to $130 billion will be needed. He said as much as $50 billion more may be needed in 1991. The federal Resolution Trust Corp. took control of Miami-based CenTrust in February and ousted Paul, whose spending drew criticism from regulators. Among the thrift's expenses were luxury fittings for Paul's yacht, linens from India for Paul's home, subsidized European shopping sprees for his wife and purchase of the company sailboat Bodacious. At the time of the seizure, CenTrust was Florida's largest savings and loan and the 23rd largest in the nation. The RTC announced in April it hoped to sell off CenTrust by the end of June. This week, the RTC will conduct its first open-bidding auction of real estate held by insolvent thrifts. The properties to be sold at auctions conducted in Dallas and San Antonio, Texas, range from a single-home lot to a 20.8-acre development site. ``The S&L crisis is a disaster for taxpayers but a boon for auction companies,'' said Joseph Janosik of Auction Co. of America. Before the auction, serious bidders meticulously examined items, jotting notes and looking for imperfections, while others willing to pay the $300 refundable entry fee treated it as a historical event. ``It's a happening. The S&L crisis, CenTrust, all this is just a happening,'' said Kirk Lewis. ``I'm just here to see what they have.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Promises to Hand Over Tapes of Talks Between Noriega and Castro
DOC.TEXT: The Cuban government is willing to cooperate with with U.S. prosecutors and turn over tape recordings of meetings between Fidel Castro and Manuel Noriega for use in the ousted Panamanian leader's U.S. drug trial, a top official said. In one meeting, the Cuban president and Noriega discussed the 1984 destruction of a cocaine laboratory in Darien, Panama, established by Colombian drug lords, said Ramiro Abreu, a Cuban official in charge of relations with Central America. Noriega told Castro about the destruction of the lab as an example of Panamanian efforts to fight drug smuggling, Abreu told reporters Thursday in Havana. His remarks were carried by Spain's national news agency EFE. Federal prosecutors say Castro was acting as an intermediary between Noriega and leaders of Colombia's notorious Medellin cocaine cartel, who were angered by the loss of the lab. ``It is not good to specify what is contained in those conversations of Noriega with Cuban officials because they are evidence that could be used at the trial, but we are willing to collaborate,'' Abreu said. Frank Rubino, Noriega's chief defense attorney, said Friday he welcomed public release of the tapes. ``We expect that they would be very helpful to us,'' Rubino said. ``The only thing we could be fearful of is that if the government gets them they'll hide them and won't let the truth come out.'' Rubino said Castro is willing to cooperate because he wants to combat allegations that he acted as a middleman in international drug dealings. Noriega is imprisoned in Miami awaiting trial on charges that he protected U.S.-bound cocaine shipments from Colombia that passed through Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Family Members, Co-Workers Mourn Victims of Finance Office Massacre
With AM-Office Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Eight people slain at random by a heavily armed gunman in an auto finance office were mourned by family members and co-workers at a memorial service Saturday. ``We want to remember them, not what occurred to them,'' said the Rev. Paul Estes, pastor of Beulah Baptist Church in Keystone Heights. ``As survivors, we will never forget them. We'll never get over it, but we will survive,'' said Estes, whose church was attended by one of the victims, Julia White Burgess. Mrs. Burgess, 42, went to the General Motors Acceptance Corp. office to make her son's car payment. She was the lone customer killed by James Edward Pough in the rampage Monday. Pough, armed with a .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle and a .38-caliber pistol, opened fire without warning at the office of the company that had repossessed his car. He walked close to employees cowering under their desks and shot them point-blank before killing himself. Killed were Mrs. Burgess, Janice David, Sharon Louise Hall, Denise Sapp Highfill, Barbara Duckworth Holland, Cynthia Perry, Lee Simonton and Drew Woods. Five people wounded by gunfire remained hospitalized Saturday. ``The difficult days are still ahead, but you are going to survive the first birthday, the first anniversary, the first Christmas, the first Easter without them. You don't think you will, but you will,'' said Estes, who told the mourners that his daughter was a murder victim several years ago. The Rev. Dennis Bratton of Mandarin Christian Church, where Mrs. Highfill, 36, attended services, told the 300 mourners gathered at the company-sponsored service: ``We don't have to be victimized by this tragedy.'' He said they weren't alone in their grief. ``The arms of this great city have tried to embrace you,'' he said. ``My how we hurt for you.'' GMAC president William J. Lovejoy said he was deeply saddened although he did not know any of the victims personally. ``We have a great sense of family. We form strong bonds,'' Lovejoy said, his voice choked with emotion. ``When one of us hurts, we all hurt.'' Lovejoy read a poem he said was found taped to the computer terminal used by Ms. Holland, 45, entitled ``Don't Quit.'' The poem talked about the value of perseverance. ``I think Barbara Holland would appreciate it if we all took those words to heart,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Possible Presidential Candidate is Coy About Intentions, Stumps Anyway
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder was coy about his thinly veiled White House aspirations during a campaign swing through the state where early party caucuses help determine presidential candidates. The nation's first elected black governor said he has no specific designs on the presidency yet, but described himself as an ideal nominee. Wilder's blend of financial conservatism and social activism appeals to a broad range of voters, the Democrat said. ``I think it's so important that we establish dialogue at the national level, my interest is doing just that,'' Wilder said. Ostensibly stumping for Iowa Democrats during the weekend fund-raising swing, including state House Speaker and gubernatorial candidate Don Avenson, Wilder also appeared to be testing the waters for a 1992 presidential bid. ``I have no intention, I have no apparatus in mind,'' insisted Wilder. Still, he conceded he was not saying, ``Bring the Bible and I'll put my hand on it.'' Visiting inner-city churches and schools, Wilder urged state Democrats to begin a drive to vote President Bush out of office in 1992. Wilder described the type of candidate who would be an ideal nominee and admitted ``I'd like to think I'm one of those persons.'' In the six months since he became the nation's first elected black governor, Wilder has campaigned in 11 states, including Iowa and New Hampshire, with his message that mixes conservative spending with renewed social activism. ``That's not a Virginia message, that's a mainstream message,'' he said. Part of Wilder's early rhetoric sounded much like the stance that helped Republicans retain control of the White House in 1988. ``We're not going to raise taxes,'' Wilder said. ``We're going to get rid of some taxes.'' Iowa political activists understand the early presidential maneuvering and immediately began handicapping the candidate. ``Does it sell today? I don't know,'' said Iowa Democratic Chairman John Roehrick. ``Will it sell in two years? I think so.'' Roehrick said there's a new sense among Democrats that they need to find tough-minded managers to run social programs with an eye on the fiancial bottom line. Wilder's election in a state where only 19 percent of the electorate is black shot him to national prominence _ and inevitable comparisons to Jesse Jackson were drawn. Some Democrats see Wilder as a more viable national candidate because he is less liberal in his views. Jackson is tentatively scheduled to campaign in the state early next month. Avenson chuckled at Wilder's attempts to disclaim his presidential aspirations. ``He just happened coincidentally to be in New Hampshire last week, and he just sort of stumbled through Iowa this week,'' Avenson said. ``It seems to me that's the first primary and the first caucus in the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Satellite's Owners Successfully Send Up Another
DOC.TEXT: A communications satellite similar to one that ended up stranded in a uselessly low orbit three months ago was launched to its proper altitude Saturday, officials said. The Intelsat VI satellite rode into orbit on a Titan 3 unmanned rocket, which lifted off on time from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. It was the same kind of rocket that had left the earlier Intelsat VI satellite stranded. The satellite separated from the rocket 25 minutes after liftoff, bringing cheers and applause in the mission control room. A rocket wiring problem prevented separation after the March 14 launch. ``We're all very anxious to see this mission totally successful, and we're certainly expecting it to be that way,'' said Edward M. Browne, president of Martin Marietta Commercial Titan Inc. ``When that thing went off (separation), we were all very happy and we naturally let our emotions show that.'' A little more than an hour after liftoff, an on-board motor boosted the satellite to an elliptical orbit 22,300 miles above Earth. A series of firings over the next several days will put the spacecraft in a circular, stationary orbit. Browne said the $270 million launch, which includes the cost of the $150 million satellite, was ``super ... totally flawless.'' The stranded spacecraft is orbiting about 345 miles above Earth, 22,000 miles lower than intended. That satellite and the one launched Saturday were not insured. Intelsat's board of governors agreed earlier this month to pay NASA $90 million for a shuttle rescue mission in which space-walking astronauts will attach a motor to the stranded satellite to boost it up to its proper orbit. That mission is scheduled for 1992. The satellite deployed Saturday joins 14 other Intelsat spacecraft in orbit. Once operational in early September, the 40-foot-long, 2-ton satellite will be capable of relaying the transmissions of three TV channels and up to 120,000 telephone calls simultaneously. Intelsat, a Washington-based consortium of 119 countries, plans to send up its next two Intelsat VI satellites on the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket. Both launches are scheduled for next year. The next commercial Titan launch, with NASA's Mars Observer spacecraft, is set for 1992. Saturday's flight was the third commercial launch for the Denver-based Martin Marietta and came after what company officials said were exhaustive reviews of the March failure. ``It's a good way to end what seems now like a long campaign,'' said Vic Whitehead, company vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Mourn Victims of Attack on State Council
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Thousands of factory workers stayed home and most stores and gas stations closed Saturday to mourn a union activist who was shot to death while attending a meeting of the governing Council of State. Two leading politicians demanded the resignation of civilian President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, who has been blamed for the army's failure to halt a recent crime wave. Ms. Pascal-Trouillot has governed along with the 19-member Council of State since her appointment in March. Early Saturday, sporadic gunfire rang out in the slums of Port-au-Prince, but most public buses were running and the capital of 1 million people remained busy. Street vendors sold their wares as usual. Armed police stopped cars at checkpoints in a search for the perpetrators of Thursday's attack by four gunmen, including two in army uniforms. Jean-Marie Fetiere, director of an industrial park near the airport, said about half the Saturday workforce of 9,000 stayed home. Long lines formed at the few gas stations that stayed open. Union activist Jean-Marie Montes was killed and two other men were wounded in the shooting, which occurred at a hotel where the 19-member Council of State was meeting with union and political leaders to discuss a surge in violent crime. The two wounded men _ council member Serge Villard and political activist Emmanuel Mani _ were reported hospitalized in satisfactory condition. ``Today we are mourning another victim in the long line of victims of Duvalierist terrorism,'' said Louis Dejoie Jr., president of the centrist National Agricultural and Industrial party. Until 1986, Haiti had been ruled by the brutal Duvalier family dictatorship for 29 years. Dejoie called for the resignation of Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot and urged the army to honor ``its pledge of allegiance to democracy.'' He said there is a ``lack of confidence in the armed forces to protect the voter against anti-democratic violence.'' Jean-Claude Roy, a member of the Unity Assembly political coalition that appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouilot president, accused the president of undermining the authority of the Council of State, which has veto powers over her decisions. ``In the interest of the nation and of the electoral process she has obstructed by her abuse of executive power, it is time for the chief executive to resign,'' he said. The attack was seen as an attempt to disrupt the civilian government's plan to hold presidential elections this fall. The main obstacle to elections has become the army's inability, or possible unwillingness, to crack down on the wave of armed robberies. About 20 people have died in such attacks in the capital this week. On Saturday, four assailants shot and killed a street vendor in a poor neighborhood and stole his car, independent Radio Antilles reported. Haiti's last attempt to hold independently run elections, on Nov. 29, 1987, was aborted when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. The independent Electoral Council has scheduled elections for late September but has set no precise date. However, one council member said privately that the elections could not be organized before early November. The civilian caretaker government was appointed in March to replace military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, who fled into exile after a weeklong popular uprising. Haiti, an impoverished nation of 6 million in the Caribbean, has been ruled almost exclusively by dictators since independence from France in 1804.

DOC.HEAD: Five Civilians Killed in Clash Between Policemen and Communists
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels raided a central Philippine town, and five civilians were killed during fighting between the insurgents and police, the military reported Saturday. Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque, area military commander, said the attack occurred late Friday in the town of Escalante in Negros Occidental province, about 320 miles south of Manila. Jarque said about 50 Communist New People's Army rebels went to a plantation on the outskirts of Escalante allegedly to kidnap its owner, Lucio Barcelona, considered one of the island's richest businessmen. When they failed to find Barcelona, the raiders took one of his trucks and raided an adjoining plantation to get another truck, Jarque said. The rebels then drove to town, where Barcelona owns a gasoline station and a hardware store. Failing again to find the businessman, the rebels took a shotgun from Barcelona's security guard and began to head out of town, Jarque said. However, six policemen learned of the rebel's presence and engaged the insurgents in a 30-minute fire fight, Jarque said. He said three civilians in a jeep that passed along the street where the gun battle took place and two bystanders were killed before government reinforcements arrived. The rebels escaped in the commandeered trucks, one of which was recovered a half-mile from Escalante. The rebels have been fighting for 21 years to establish a Marxist government.

DOC.HEAD: Jilted Bride Gives Reception to the Homeless
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Saturday was supposed to be Kathleen Gooley's wedding day. But when the groom backed out and she got stuck with the reception bill, the jilted bride decided to give her party to the homeless. The 41-year-old Gooley of Norwalk found herself thrust into the national spotlight when, after her fiance got cold feet two months ago, she and an intended bridesmaid decided to reorganize the event for 150 homeless people from southwestern Connecticut. ``We would have been doing this at this time anyway,'' Gooley said Saturday as she watched her guests dance to the music of a disc jockey who donated his time. ``I hope somebody else in the same situation will do the same thing.'' Busloads of homeless men, women and children from Norwalk and nearby Stamford and Bridgeport arrived at the pink-and-white decorated Canongate catering hall just after noon. Some were clad in jeans and T-shirts, others shirts and ties or dresses. Many hadn't had a hot meal in weeks. ``You're blessing us with your day,'' said Eugene Patenaude, 50, a recovering alcoholic and drug addict who sleeps in a Norwalk shelter. ``We will never be able to repay you.'' ``This is Christmas in the summer for these people,'' said Marvin Minkler, who works with the homeless in the streets and escorted a group to the party. ``This is a decent meal for them and they don't get it on a daily basis.'' Donated flower arrangements and balloons adorned each table, and the guests sat down to an opening course of fruit cup and a tossed salad. Waiters and waitresses served hors d'oeuvres: fried won tons, shrimp puffs, chicken wings, meatballs and egg rolls. The main course was stuffed chicken breast and string beans almondine, with cake, ice cream and coffee for dessert. Tara Gooley, at 11 the youngest of Gooley's three children, left a photocopied note on each plate that read, ``Hope you have a great day,'' with pictures of teddy bears. ``I've seen stories on TV about them (the homeless) and it makes me really sad,'' she said. ``I'm very fortunate to have what I have now today.'' The intended bridesmaid, Rinda Farnham, thought of giving the party for the homeless after the caterer refused to refund $4,000 of the $5,800 Gooley had paid, Gooley said. She said she agreed because she and one of her chidren, then a baby, spent a night in a shelter 23 years ago. Gooley's balance bought 118 dinners. Everything else was donated, including the buses that transported the guests. Members of the public who heard through the media walked into the reception and offered cakes, brownies and checks. Gooley and Farnham appeared on Joan Rivers' TV talk show on Tuesday _ Rivers gave $500, which paid for 16 dinners. Canongate owner Ginger Sollazzo-Raymond contributed another 16 dinners, for a total of 150. Ralph Blechner, an electrical engineer, walked into the reception and handed Gooley a $500 check. ``I saw it in the paper and I thought, now this is a great lady,'' he said. The guests swarmed around Gooley when she emerged from a back room, hugging her, kissing her on the cheek and applauding. One guest, Ralph Wayne, a 37-year-old unemployed Stamford man, stepped outside to get some air while the dancing and eating continued inside. The festivities were nice, Wayne said. But he found the event sad. ``She didn't get married,'' he said. ``But then again, it came to good use.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists, Loggers Await Administration Input On Spotted Owl
DOC.NOTE: EDS: subs 7th graf, ``Interior secretary xxx to CORRECT that Lujan did not cancel trip to New Mexico, but plans to return to Washington a day early
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists and loggers are anxious to see how the Bush administration makes good on its promise to find a balance in the struggle to save the northern spotted owl without crippling the Northwest timber industry. As officials at the Interior Department and other agencies struggled with the issue this weekend, some lawmakers said the decision could affect President Bush's political popularity in the Northwest as well as the future of the 2-foot-tall brownish owl. ``I think the president himself is in a helluva fix,'' said Rep. Les AuCoin, an Oregon Democrat. The Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management were scheduled to unveil an owl protection plan Friday, the same day Fish and Wildlife Director John Turner formally declared the owl to be a threatened species in its range of Oregon, Washington and northern California. Turner acted under the Endangered Species Act to guarantee protection for the bird. But the administration postponed its final decision, at least briefly, saying more time was needed to devise a strategy that will lessen the impact on the Northwest's timber-dependent communities. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan flew to New Mexico on Saturday to participate in an Interior Department conference on equal employment opportunities, but planned to return to Washington Monday evening, a day earlier than originally scheduled, to prepare for Tuesday's announcement. Most congressmen from the region expressed optimism the delay will result in a softening of a protection plan recommended in April by a government panel headed by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas. That proposal would cut federal timber harvests in the region nearly in half and industry officials say it could result in the loss of more than 28,000 logging industry jobs. ``My sense is the extra time that they are taking is in fact to move closer to some sort of an economic answer for the Northwest, as opposed to taking the easy path, which would be to go with the most scientific of the reports that we have, which is the Thomas plan,'' said Rep. Sid Morrison, R-Wash. ``I sense ... there is a conflict and that maybe the administration is attempting to do more on the economic impact side than some of the resource agencies are willing to accept,'' he said. ``We heard that maybe somehow magically between now and Tuesday they are going to come up with an agreement, but the Forest Service and BLM seem to be moving on two different tracks. If we don't have a consistent regional approach, both agencies may end up in court,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. Bush, who campaigned as an environmentalist in 1988, said in Portland last month that he was ``concerned about preserving and protecting our environment.'' However, he said, he rejected ``those who would ignore the economic consequences of the spotted owl decision.'' In his announcement on Friday, Turner said the White House had no attempt to influence his decision to declare the owl a threatened species. But George Frampton, president of The Wilderness Society, complained that the Bush administration might seek to water down plans to protect the owl. ``We are alarmed that a political pressure campaign is now being waged by the White House to reverse the recommendations of agency heads and the scientists, and to subvert the Endangered Species Act,'' Frampton said. ``This is what we will be watching in the next few days,'' he said. Industry leaders said it will be a mistake if administrators fail to persuade the agencies to mitigate the economic consequences of owl protection. ``Our worst nightmare will come true if federal decision-makers do not respond to our distress signals,'' said Bill Shields of the American Forest Resource Alliance. ``The Bush administration and Congress must step into this debate with both feet and fashion a long-term package that strikes a balance between the needs of the northern spotted owl, and the certain layoffs of tens of thousands in Washington, Oregon and northern California,'' he said. Forest Service spokesman Jim Sanders said the agency had not settled on a policy strategy to protect the owl. He declined to respond directly when asked if the service was backing away from comments Chief F. Dale Robertson made earlier about the agency's intention to adopt most of the Thomas recommendations. Sanders said there will be reductions in timber harvests no matter what owl strategy is adopted. ``I'm sure there is going to be some. The question is how much. We are going to try to maintain the timber flow with as little disruption as possible. But at the same time, we are going to operate under the Endangered Species Act,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Refugees Allowed Ashore After Resettlement Pact With Canada
DOC.TEXT: The government on Saturday allowed ashore 88 Vietnamese boat people rescued by a Canadian warship after receiving assurances from Ottawa that they would be resettled elsewhere by 1993. Before leaving the HMCS Provider, the Vietnamese knelt in prayer and thanked the Canadian crew for rescuing them June 19 in the South China Sea. Many of the refugees and some crew members wept and embraced. ``You have been very good to us. Thank you,'' said one woman refugee. On Friday, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus informed the Canadian Embassy that the Philippines would not accept the boat people without assurances from Ottawa that the boat people would be resettled outside the Philippines by Dec. 31, 1992. Canadian Ambassador Andre Simard said the two governments subsequently reached an agreement making it possible for the refugees to come ashore. ``We came up to an understanding ... that these people will be transferred within a period of three years,'' Simard said. ``Countries have to be given a reasonable time to act upon (applications for asylum) so that we go through these procedures,'' he said. ``They're not going to be resettled tomorrow in Canada.'' The Provider is one of four Canadian vessels touring the Far East. Its skipper, Capt. Kenneth Scotten, said the refugees told the crew they had left Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, last month. The refugees said 15 of their group had died before the Provider rescued them. Two others died shortly after being taken aboard by the Canadian ship and were buried at sea, Scotten said. Earlier Saturday, seven sick refugees and six of their relatives were allowed ashore on humanitarian grounds. The remaining 75 came ashore after the agreement was reached and were taken to a refugee-processing center south of Manila. Earlier this month, the Philippine government held up the debarkation of Vietnamese refugees from a U.S. Navy ship for several days before getting similar assurances. The Philippines and other Asian countries are threatening to stop providing temporary ``first asylum'' refuge for Vietnamese and other Indochinese boat people and to repatriate those who do not qualify as political refugees. The United States and Vietnam object to forced repatriation. Asian countries have given the United States until July 1 to arrange new options for people screened out as ineligible for resettlement. The Asian nations have been joined by Britain, which has urged the United States to drop its objections to forced repatriation or accept thousands of boat people who do not qualify as political refugees. The British colony of Hong Kong has a large community of Vietnamese refugees. Immigrants deemed to be fleeing poverty rather than political repression are not granted refugee status.

DOC.HEAD: That'll Be The Day, When You Make Me Buy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The proceeds ...,' to DELETE reference to Holly's mother, who died recently, CLARIFY that brother also benefits from sale. `Larry Holley' in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Life imitated art at an auction Saturday when actor Gary Busey, who played Buddy Holly in a film biography, paid $242,000 for an acoustic guitar owned by the late rock 'n' roll pioneer. In addition to the 1945 Gibson guitar with a cover hand-tooled by Holly himself, the 118 lots in the Holly sale included a Fender Stratocaster guitar which netted $110,000 and a pair of the rocker's trademark black-rimmed glasses which went for $45,100. The sale brought in a total of $703,615, said Laura Stewart, spokeswoman for Sotheby's auction house. The proceeds will go to Holly's family, including his widow, Maria Elena Holly, and his brother, Larry Holley of Lubbock, Texas, Stewart said. The two were among the 200 people attending the auction. Busey, who bid by telephone, was widely acclaimed for his 1978 portrayal of the bespectacled rocker in ``The Buddy Holly Story.'' His winning bid was more than six times the pre-sale estimate of $35,000. The acoustic guitar, covered with four-color leather, has the words ``Buddy Holly,'' ``Love Me'' and ``Blue Days, Black Nights'' hand-tooled across the top and ``Texas'' hand-tooled across the bottom. Holly's Stratocaster electric guitar attracted nearly double its pre-sale estimate of $60,000, and was purchased by an unidentified bidder. Holly was playing the guitar on the ill-fated tour which ended with his death. The black-rimmed glasses, which Holly wore at the end of his career, sold for $45,100 to the Hard Rock Cafe, Stewart said. The late John Lennon, another rocker who wore glasses, once said of Holly's shades, ``He made it O.K. to wear glasses. I was Buddy Holly.'' Another prominent buyer _ Pat DiNizio, lead singer of the Smithereens _ paid $14,300 for a reel-to-reel tape recorder and microphone which Holly used to compose new songs. Holly burst into prominence in 1957, reeling off a string of hits like ``Peggy Sue,'' ``Rave On,'' ``That'll Be The Day,'' ``Maybe Baby,'' and ``Not Fade Away.'' Holly, along with J.P. ``The Big Bopper'' Richardson and Ritchie Valens, died in a Feb. 3, 1959, plane crash when he was 23. ``This memorabilia from the personal collection of Buddy Holly provides a fascinating glimpse of the singer's boyhood and brief years of stardom,'' Sotheby's said in its auction catalogue. The items date back to when Holly was 11 years old. Included were family photographs, Holly's harmonica and camera, a business card from his first band ``Buddy & Bob,'' his personal collection of 45s and home movies from Christmas 1958. There was also one particularly eerie item: a 1956 Equitable Life insurance policy on Holly, with his parents named as beneficiaries. This included a handwritten receipt signed by Holly.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Socialists Win Key Regional Vote
DOC.TEXT: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez won a decisive victory Saturday in regional elections in his native region of Andalusia, according to partial returns. The balloting was seen as a test of the Socialists' strength after eight years in power in Madrid's central government and in Andalusia. The Socialists have been hit by a 6-month-old scandal involving the brother of Deputy Prime Minister Alfonso Guerra, under investigation for alleged influence-peddling in Seville. With 65.15 percent of the vote counted, the Socialists had 49.97 percent of the ballots cast, capturing 61 seats in the 109-member regional Parliament, said Andalusian regional government minister Manuel Gracia. If the results hold up, it would be a slight improvement on the Socialists' showing in the last regional elections in June 1986 when they won 46.5 percent of the vote and 60 seats in the Andalusian Parliament. However, Gracia estimated that the voter turnout was only about 54 percent, compared with 70 percent in the 1986 balloting, which coincided with national elections. Based on the partial returns, Socialist lawyer and former national Labor Minister Manuel Chaves, 44, was expected to become Andalusia's new prime minister. The final results were not expected until early Sunday, Gracia said. The polls opened at 9 a.m. and closed at 8 p.m. Gonzalez's party needed at least 55 seats to retain the majority it first won in Andalusia's Parliament in 1982, the same year the Socialists swept into power in the national government in a landslide victory. The main opposition force remained the conservative Popular Party. Gracia said the partial returns showed the Popular Party winning 20.79 percent of the vote for 24 to 26 seats. In 1986, the party took 23.4 percent and 28 seats. The Communist-led United Left coalition had 12.93 percent of the vote and 11 to 13 seats, a loss in support from 1986 when it won 17.6 percent and 19 seats. The biggest gains were registered by the populist regional Andalusista Party, which was picking up 11.54 percent of the vote and was expected to win nine seats, Gracia said. In the last election, the Andalusistas had 6.2 percent and two seats. Newspaper polls earlier this week had indicated that much of the Socialists' support was due to the region's rebounding economy, where the economic growth rate has averaged 5.5 percent over the last four years. Regional unemployment is still the highest in Spain at 24 percent, but it is down from a peak of 30 percent. Foreign investment in Andalusia has surged from $161 million in 1986 to $1.43 billion last year. In the campaign, the Popular Party and United Left coalition tried to capitalize on the Guerra scandal by accusing the Socialists of encouraging corruption. Gonzalez campaigned personally in Andalusia, denouncing the corruption allegations as false and saying they only showed the opposition lacked a program for social and economic progress. The Socialist-run central government is spending $7 billion on roads, highways and communications in Andalusia in preparation for the World's Fair, scheduled in Seville from April to October of 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Peaceful Marchers Joined By AIDS Conference Leaders
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
LaserPhoto FX6
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of chanting, whistle-blowing demonstrators marched Saturday with hundreds of delegates from an international AIDS conference in a call for more money and health care for infected people. The peaceful march, which snowballed in size and snarled traffic as it snaked up Market Street, was in marked contrast to the week's worth of protests organized by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, that resulted in 299 arrests. On Saturday, ACT UP activists were joined by leaders of the Sixth International Conference on who said they were in the battle against the disease together. ``The apparent divisions between us are not real,'' Paul Volberding, a conference co-chairman, told a crowd of about 20,000 gathered in Justin Herman Plaza at the end of the march. ``We cannot tolerate it, and hopefully, this march will help end it.'' March organizers said 20,000 people took part in the march and rally. Police put the number of people in the march at around 4,000. Marchers carried signs with such messages as ``AIDS Treatment Now'' and ``Increase Research Funding.'' The march was briefly disrupted when hundreds of demonstrators led by ACT UP's Seattle chapter rushed into the San Francisco Centre, screaming, ``We're here, we're queer and we're not going shopping!'' Some Centre shoppers applauded and others seemed shocked as protesters scattered leaflets through the atrium outside a Nordstrom department store. The demonstrators said they were protesting the dismissal of a Nordstrom employee in Seattle who tested positive for the AIDS virus. Nordstrom said the former salesman left the sales floor on his own, and that the company had offered him other jobs that might be less physically stressful. The company said he declined those job offers. Outside, marchers wore stickers emblazoned with a bloody handprint that read, ``The government has blood on its hands _ one AIDS death every half hour.'' A 12-foot death's head bobbed along at the rear of the crowd, where parents pushed toddlers in strollers and friends pushed the wheelchairs of the disabled. ``AIDS is sweeping the nation,'' said Maggie Duhl, 15, a member of a group of politically active children. ``There needs to be more education about AIDS, especially in the schools. It seems the idea about AIDS is that it's a gay disease, and that's wrong.'' ``Many of these kids have someone close to them who has AIDS,'' said her mother, Barbara Duhl, who marched with her two children and a banner that read, ``Kids Say Money for AIDS, Not For War.'' ``It's something that's going to be a part of their lives.'' Speakers at the rally blasted what they said was a lack of funding and attention by the federal government and the slow process of research aimed at finding a cure for the disease. But many of the speakers struck a conciliatory tone. ``Not everyone out there is our enemy,'' said Martin Delaney, head of San Francisco's Project Inform. ``We know who has been in the fight to save lives and who is in it to make money.'' Dr. June Osborn, chairwoman of the U.S. National Committee on AIDS, urged the various factions in the AIDS controversy to come together. ``We have much to learn from each other,'' she said. The crowd was sprinkled with foreign delegates who took time from the AIDS conference to march and listen to the speakers. ``It's very impressive,'' said Dr. John Gallwey, an Oxford University physician who treats AIDS patients. ``I wish we could get this kind of response back home.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says he Will Hold Party Together And Remain Leader
LaserPhotos MOSB2,3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 12th pvs, `The post...' to UPDATE with Ligachev Saying he will challenge Gorbachev for party leadership. Pickup pvs 13th graf, Medvedev...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised Saturday he would hold the splintering Communist Party together and remain its leader despite the growing division between conservatives and reformers. The pledge came at the Communist Party congress in the biggest Soviet republic, which elected as its leader a hard-liner who is unacceptable to many reformist Communists. Ivan Polozkov, 55, took office Saturday as the Russian republic's party chief after defeating a more moderate candidate the day before. Polozkov, who has rejected Gorbachev's appeals for the party to relinquish its control over the economy, urged party discipline and condemned informal political groups. In Krasnodar, the southern Russian town where he is party chief, he cracked down on cooperatives _ the private businesses introduced by Gorbachev. On Saturday, he told reporters that he would work to unify the party and to show that ``I'm not as terrible as I'm portrayed to be.'' One reformist party leader, Vladimir Lysenko, predicted that millions of Soviets would quit the national organization if conservatives are in control. Gorbachev spoke out against the impending national party split between conservatives and radicals, expected to erupt at a key party congress that opens in eight days. ``At this decisive stage of perestroika, it would be a gift for those who want to bury perestroika and defeat it,'' he said. Gorbachev also told the delegates that he must remain both president and head of the national party during the period that power is being transferred from the party to the government. On Wednesday, he had warned that a new party chairman could be elected at the congress. ``I'm convinced that now we must keep the situation as it is. This is the most critical time of the redistribution of power between the government councils and the party,'' Gorbachev said. The post should be divided eventually, he said. Yegor Ligachev, the most conservative member of the party's ruling Politburo, has told delegates he will challenge Gorbachev for the post, reform Communist Vladimir Lysenko said. Ligachev, an ardent supporter of collective farming even after decades of disastrous harvests, told the congress this week that Gorbachev should be replaced. Vadim Medvedev, a member of the party's ruling Politburo, expanded on Gorbachev's determination to hold the party together in a talk with reporters during a break in congress proceedings. ``We are fighting to avoid a split. I don't rule out that some people will leave. But we are obligated to ensure there will be no split,'' he said. Polozkov, a frequent critic of Gorbachev and his reforms, on Saturday declared his support for Gorbachev as head of the national Communist Party and said he would try to work out differences with radical reformers in the Russian republic. ``Some people call me a rightist conservative, some people call me a difficult person, some call me unmanageable or disobedient, some call me unreceptive to innovations,'' Polozkov acknowledged at a news conference. But he said he would immediately set to work to show that he was for party consolidation. Delegates attending the regional party congress chose Polozkov in a runoff election Friday night. He got 1,396 votes to 1,066 for civic engineer Oleg Lobov, according to official results announced Saturday morning. After his election, Polozkov, a bespectacled man who speaks with an accent similar to Gorbachev's, strode to the center seat on the dais in the congress building. Gorbachev, who has presided over the party congress, smiled as Polozkov took the seat next to him. Polozkov said he did not believe his election would further widen the developing split in the national Communist Party, and he said he expected to work well with both Gorbachev and populist reformer Boris N. Yeltsin. Yeltsin defeated Polozkov three weeks ago for the presidency of the Russian republic. Polozkov's election also could pit the republic's party leaders against its government, led by Yeltsin, who has challenged Gorbachev by demanding faster reforms and support for independence-minded republics. Lysenko of the Democratic Platform faction, the only radical among six candidates to oppose Polozkov, predicted millions of people would quit the party if conservatives remain in control. ``If it continues that way, millions will be leaving the party and (the national party) will fall apart as a totally unviable organization,'' Lysenko told the Interfax news agency, run by official Moscow Radio. Russia's Communists constitute more than half the membership of the 18-million-member national party, but until this week did not have their own republic party organization, as do the other 14 Soviet republics. The Russian party was absorbed into the national party in 1925, partially out of fear its leaders could become competitors in the struggle for power. The Russian republic, the largest of the 15 constituent republics, includes Moscow and the heartland of the country. It encompasses about half the population of the Soviet Union and two-thirds of its land.

DOC.HEAD: Friendly, Hostile Countries Send Aid To Iran
With AM-Iran Quake,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Countries worldwide, both friendly and hostile to Tehran's Islamic government, sent supplies, medical personnel and condolences to Iran, where about 40,000 people have died in an earthquake. Iran's deadliest earthquake since 1976 jolted the northern part of the country Thursday, devastating towns and injuring at least 100,000 people. The United States sent a message of condolence and expressed its willingness to provide humanitarian aid. Iran, which has had no diplomatic ties with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. Moderate Arab countries with which Iran has had prickly relations _ Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan _ also offered their support. An official statement distributed late Friday by the Saudi Press Agency said the kingdom followed with ``deep sorrow'' the news of the tragedy. ``The kingdom of Saudi Arabia ... declares its readiness to help in extending assistance to those harmed by the tragedy, wishing to help ease the pain of the afflicted from among the sons of the Iranian Moslem nation,'' it said. Jordan announced Saturday it was sending medical aid to Iran, but details were not immediately clear. King Hussein sent condolences to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on Friday in what is believed to be the first direct contact between Jordanian and Iranian heads of state in almost a decade. Jordan backed Iraq in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, which ended with a cease-fire in August 1988, and at one point sent hundreds of Jordanian volunteers to fight alongside Iraqi soldiers.
