Egypt was sending two military planes with supplies, the Middle East News Agency reported. President Hosni Mubarak offered the aid ``in the framework of Egypt's concern to provide help for brothers and friends, especially at times of natural disasters.'' The official Soviet news agency Tass reported that a professional lifesaving team from the Armenian capital of Yerevan flew Saturday to Iran. The team gained experience in the devastating 1988 earthquake in Armenia that killed 25,000 people. Thousands of residents in the predominantly Moslem Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, which borders Iran, donated tons of flour, rice and tea, and contributed more than $500,000 to a special earthquake fund, Tass said. The Italian Red Cross sent a plane to Iran Saturday with relief supplies, including tents, blankets and medicine. In Paris, the French government, which already has sent a 200-member civil defense team _ including rescuers, medical personnel and search dogs _ said Saturday it would send an entire mobile hospital unit if Iran wanted it. In West Germany, the Foreign Ministry said that it was sending tents, blankets, hospital equipment and cooking equipment to Iran. Eight tons was being shipped Saturday and the government has chartered a jumbo jet to transport 100 tons of equipment Monday. At the Vatican, Pope John Paul II sent aid to earthquake victims and a message of condolence to Iranian leaders. The Vatican said in a statement that the donation of an unspecified amount was to ``provide for the most immediate needs of the population hurt by this huge earthquake.'' John Paul also sent a telegram to the papal nuncio, or diplomatic representative, in Tehran saying the pope ``is praying fervently for the wounded and the families of the victims.'' The Indian government said it would donate medicine, blankets and other relief supplies worth more than $500,000. China's Red Cross said it was sending $106,000 worth of relief supplies, state-run television said Saturday. The Polish government was sending 5 tons of powdered milk, a ton of bed sheets, a ton of medicine and 3 tons of blankets and clothing, according to Polish media reports. Malaysia was providing more than $90,000 in relief aid. Foreign Ministry Secretary-General Ahmad Kamil Jaafar told reporters Saturday the money would be used to buy medicine, food, powdered milk, tents and other essential items.

DOC.HEAD: Execution Called Off for Husband Killer
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Saturday indefinitely stayed the ``Black Widow'' killer's execution to hear arguments that Florida's electric chair is faulty and cruel. The decision by a three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta means that Judi Buenoano, 47, will outlive her death warrant, which expires at noon Monday. But the legal debate over the state's electric chair, which sent smoke and flames shooting from the head of Jesse Tafero in Florida's last execution May 4, will continue with death warrants pending against other inmates. Attorneys for Ms. Buenoano pressed their position before U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett that the chair is faulty. The judge lifted her stay late Friday after weighing claims that an electrocution would not violate the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment. Ms. Buenoano is known as the ``Black Widow'' killer because she poisoned her husband, drowned her paralyzed teen-age son and tried to murder a boyfriend with a car bomb. She attended the hearing, listening and watching attentively but showing no emotion. Before the Atlanta court intervened, Gov. Bob Martinez' office had rescheduled her execution for her husband's murder for Monday. Judges Gerald B. Tjoflat, Phyllis A. Kravitch and Emmett R. Cox set aside the execution date and agreed to set a schedule later for attorneys to file legal briefs. State Corrections Department spokesman Bob Macmaster said Ms. Buenoano would be transferred from Florida State Prison near Starke in northern Florida, a men's prison that houses the electric chair, back to Broward Correctional Institution, the state prison for women in Fort Lauderdale. The defense claims that Tafero was tortured and burned during his execution before the last of three jolts of electricity finally killed him, and blames a faulty electrode in the headpiece. ``We are still concerned that our client may literally be burned at the stake,'' said chief defense attorney Billy Nolas. The state investigated Tafero's execution and concluded a new synthetic sponge placed on his head caused the fire. Corrections officials said the sponge has been replaced by a natural one and the 66-year-old chair is now functioning properly. ``It is clear that the use of the polyurethane sponge was improper'' and caused the sparks, smoke and fire around Tafero's head, Ms. Fawsett ruled. New tests, including one conducted at the judge's direction Friday, showed the ``electrocution equipment was in good working order,'' she added.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Hope Mandela Visit Will Boost Their Bid for Independent City
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Black community activists who want predominantly black neighborhoods of Boston to secede and form an independent city named Mandela hope Nelson Mandela's visit here will help their cause. ``His coming is going to be a tremendous boost to our campaign,'' said Sadiki Kambon, chairman of Project FATE, which means Focusing Attitudes Towards Empowerment. ``We expect to win.'' ``He is an individual of importance who came here talking about how we need to build self-dependence and our own companies,'' Kambon said Thursday. Local activists and Democratic state Rep. Byron Rushing dream of creating an independent, predominantly black city of 12.5 square miles and 150,000 residents named for the South African freedom fighter. The proposal was defeated in non-binding city-wide referendums in 1986 and 1988, and led to acrimonious debate, opening old wounds in this racially torn city noted for its pivotal role in the American Revolution. Mandela, the 71-year-old deputy head of the African National Congress who was freed this year after being imprisoned for 27 years, is a symbol of freedom to blacks around the world. In Boston on Saturday, he spoke at Madison Park High School in Roxbury, one of the neighborhoods proposed as part of the city of Mandela, along with Mattapan, Fenway, South End and parts of Dorchester. Independence, black community activists say, means taking control of land development, schools and law enforcement _ similar, Kambon says, to the struggle for self-government by blacks in Mandela's native South Africa. The 1986 referendum failed nearly 3-1 in a battle that pitted black city politicians against their white counterparts, and white residents against their black neighbors. But Project FATE also found opposition among some black residents who didn't want to secede. On the second round, the proposal lost 2-1, when Mayor Raymond Flynn's administration essentially ignored the issue. Kambon hopes Mandela's visit will give the black community courage to take risks to gain control over their own affairs, especially older people who don't experience daily life on the city's streets. ``Just the experience of the man himself will be very advantageous,'' he says. ``They (the people of these areas) will have a more personal connection with Nelson Mandela.'' Kambon said Project FATE wrote to Mandela explaining the proposal but did not receive a reply. Boston's black community, about 126,200 residents in a total population of almost 563,000, has been scarred by the violence of forced busing and more recently by redlining and police stops of suspected gang members on the street. The public schools have disproportionately few minority teachers, and the dropout and death rates among black youths has skyrocketed because of gangs and drugs. ``The bottom line is we don't get the services that we should be getting, and that's a problem here and across the country,'' says Kambon, who has lived in Boston about 15 years. ``Wouldn't people rather have teachers that live in the neighborhood teach their children, because they would care; and police officers that live there who would look out for the neighborhood and make certain it's a nurturing and healthy environment?'' Among those opposed to creating an independent city, some say the targeted communities don't have the resources to go it alone. Project FATE and Rushing plan to present a non-binding referendum asking the state Legislature to mandate that a field of experts determine whether the proposal is practical. They hope to get the referendum on the November ballot. Mandela was to leave for Washington on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Kills At Least Two Arab Guerrillas North of Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with military saying two guerrillas sighted before vessel destroyed; Pickup pvs 4th graf, `The army...'
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli patrol vessel destroyed a power boat carrying Arab guerrillas near Israel's northern border late Saturday, killing at least two attackers, the army said. The guerrilla team fired rocket-propelled grenades and automatic weapons at a Dvora patrol vessel at about 10 p.m. off Ras al-Bayada, 2 miles north of the border and near the headquarters of the U.N peacekeepng force in South Lebanon, the military said in a statement. ``It was headed to destroy targets in Israel,'' a spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The army statement said the speedboat was traveling at 30 knots in the direction of Israel's border before it was intercepted by air and ground forces. The military said at least two guerrillas were sighted in the speedboat before troops opened fire, sinking the boat. The army did not identify the guerrillas or say if they belonged to Palestinian or Lebanese groups. On May 30th guerrillas belonging to the Palestine Liberation Front faction of the PLO attempted to attack an Israeli beach south of Tel Aviv. Israeli forces foiled the raid killing four guerrillas and capturing 12. The attack prompted the United States to suspend its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization until PLO chairman Yasser Arafat condemns the atack and disciplines the leader of the PLF, Mohammed Abul Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas.

DOC.HEAD: Premadasa Says Settlement Possible as Gov't Gains in Fighting
DOC.TEXT: President Ranasinghe Premadasa said Saturday he has not given up hope for a negotiated settlement with Tamil Tiger rebels despite almost two weeks of fighting that has left at least 1,400 dead. Government forces reported gains Saturday as troops fanned out from military camps in the north and east, destroying Tamil rebel hideouts and bunkers, military officials said. About 30 rebels and 11 soldiers have been reported killed in fighting since Friday. Also Saturday, the military acknowledged it erroneously reported a day earlier that separatist guerrillas massacred 62 Moslem men, women and children. Military officials said troops discovered only three Moslems men were killed when rebels looted a village in eastern Sri Lanka. The officials reported that residents earlier said 100 rebels looted and ``hacked to death'' 62 Moslem men, women and children in Nintavur, 25 miles south of Batticaloa. ``Having reached the village late Friday, troops found only three Moslems killed,'' one official said. ``The villagers panicked and in the confusion exaggerated the killings.'' Premadasa, the architect of last year's peace overtures to the rebels that led to a 13-month cease-fire, said he has not given up hope for peace. ``I must say I have not given up my policy of conference, consultation and consensus to resolve all problems,'' he said at a public meeting in the central city of Kandy. The Tamil Tigers, claiming discrimination by the predominantly Buddhist Sinhalese who dominate government, have been waging a 7-year-old insurgency to set up a separate state in the north and east where the mainly Hindu Tamils are in the majority. The latest fighting flared up on June 11 when the rebels abrogated a 13-month-old cease-fire by attacking police stations after a Tamil civilian complained he was manhandled by Sinhalese police. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while ethnic Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population. Rebel forces were on the defensive Friday and Saturday as government forces advanced from the eastern coastal village of Kiran to Batticaloa town, a flashpoint in the war. By late Friday, troops had moved four miles destroying five rebel bunkers and clearing land mines, military officials said on condition of anonymity. In another incident, rebels killed six soldiers when they blew up a jeep with a remote control device in northeastern Sri Lanka, officials said. They said the incident occured when the soldiers were traveling from Padawiya to Pulmoddai in northeast Trincomalee district. Four soldiers were also killed and eight wounded when troops destroyed four rebel hideouts on the outskirts of northern Vavuniya district Friday, officials said. Unconfirmed reports said 15 Tigers were killed in the fighting. Fifteen more rebels were reported killed Saturday when navy gunships destroyed a guerrilla boat off Jaffna peninsula in the north, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew Lifted For U.S. Military Personnel
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military command Saturday lifted a 70-day curfew that put a popular entertainment district in Seoul off limits to U.S. personnel after midnight. Gen. Louis C. Menetrey, commander of U.S. Forces in South Korea, terminated the midnight-to-5 a.m. curfew in the Itaewon district, saying it had served its purpose of stemming anti-U.S. violence in the area. ``Since the imposition of the curfew, violent incidents and injuries involving USFK (U.S. Forces Korea) personnel have decreased dramatically,'' a command statement said. ``Citing the continuing need to safeguard U.S. personnel, the command had been satisfied with the results of the curfew and now felt comfortable, terminating it with the expectation that violent confrontation in the future can be avoided,'' it said. The command imposed the curfew on April 13, citing the need to protect ``the health and welfare'' of the 43,000 U.S. soldiers, civilian workers and their dependents in South Korea from anti-American violence. Itaewon is a popular shopping and entertainment district near the headquarters of the U.S. 8th Army. The area is frequented by many foreign tourists and shoppers as well as by U.S. soldiers and young Koreans. The curfew order was issued a day after an angry Korean mob assaulted U.S. soldiers and South Korean civilians in the area, injuring six. Anti-U.S. sentiment is strong among South Korean radicals and dissidents who have demanded the withdrawal of U.S. troops, claiming their presence hinders Seoul's unification with Communist North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Parents, Not Government, Should Exercise Control
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans believe obscenity or indecency is on the rise in the art world, but that parents, not government, should act to protect children from being exposed to it, according to a poll released Saturday. About 71 percent of the 605 adults surveyed by the Gallup Organization last month for Newsweek magazine said they felt obscenity was on the rise, 3 percent said it had decreased, 22 percent said it had stayed the same and 4 percent said they didn't know. Seventy-eight percent said it was more important for parents to take stricter measures to protect children from being exposed to obscene material. Sixteen percent said it was more important for government to take stricter measures, 4 percent said such measures weren't such needed and 2 percent didn't know. Respondents were split over whether federal funds should be used to encourage and support arts projects. Half of those asked said ``no'' and 42 percent said ``yes.'' Those results were within the margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Eight percent said they didn't know the answer to that question. About two out of three, 63 percent, said judgments about whether federally financed art is offensive should be left to experts. Thirty percent said they favored more official control and 7 percent said they didn't know. The telephone poll for the July 2 issue of Newsweek was conducted June 20-21.

DOC.HEAD: Trumpeter Brings Latin Jazz to Carnegie Hall
LaserPhoto NY18
DOC.TEXT: Dizzy Gillespie has always liked Latin jazz and he brought a dynamite night of it to Carnegie Hall, kicking off the JVC Jazz Festival with his Dizzy Gillespie United Nation All-Star Orchestra. Players came from across the Americas, mostly South, America. Three who burned up the percussion Friday night were Giovanni Hidalgo, Ignacio Berroa and Airto Moreira. Sometimes, band members laid down their regular instruments and picked up maracas or other off-beat percussion instruments to accentuate solos. Gillespie's solos were complemented by splendid solo work by two other top trumpeters, Claudio Roditi and Jon Faddis. The three ended the concert leading one of Gillespie's best-known compositions, ``A Night in Tunisia.'' Gillespie's introductions were designed to amuse. He called the finale ``a tune that's 300 years old'' and spun a tale to explain the title ``And Then She Stopped.'' James Moody played flute on ``Koosh'' and sang his famous bebop ``Moody's Mood for Love.'' Paquito D'Rivera played clarinet for ``Latin American Suite,'' by three composers, one of them himself. Panamanian pianist Danilo Perez also was showcased in the medly. Trombonist Steve Turre played conch shells as though they were French horns. Flora Purim sang a couple of songs from her native Brazil. The concert began with a set by Marcus Roberts and his sextet, all of them young and accomplished musicians. Roberts, who has been pianist in Wynton Marsalis' band for several years, played one commanding solo. They played tunes by Duke Ellington, John Coltrane, Marsalis and Roberts plus Todd Williams' ``The Cat in the Hat Comes Back,'' as musically witty as its title. Opening night began with an avant-garde concert by Roy Campbell, William Parker Duo and Jazz Passengers at Equitable Center and by ragtime pianist Terry Waldo at Weill Recital Hall. The JVC Jazz Festival runs in New York through June 30 and then moves on to Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Apologizes To Quebec, Promises To Continue Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, `Bourassa...Bourassa.' with 3 grafs to clarify that Bourassa only ruling out talks on national issues, ADDS quote; Pickup 11th, `Quebec's leader ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: A gloomy Prime Minister Brian Mulroney went on national TV Saturday to apologize to Quebec for the failure of a constitutional reform that would have recognized the French-speaking province's distinct culture. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa bitterly criticized Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells for killing the Meech Lake accord and said he would boycott future constitutional talks. There has been widespread concern that failure of Meech Lake might lead the people of Quebec to push for independence, or more likely, some sort of sovereignty-association relationship with the rest of Canada. But Bourassa indicated only that his government is studying its future options. The Meech Lake accord had to be passed by the federal government and the legislatures of all 10 provinces by midnight Saturday. But a decision by Wells on Friday to shelve debate in the Newfoundland legislature on the constitutional amendment effectively killed it. Federal opposition leaders blamed the accord's failure on what they called Mulroney's lack of leadership and urged him to resign. ``The accord, which was drafted to achieve unity, became over three years a lightning rod for discontent about budget and interest rates, free trade and taxes,'' Mulroney said in his television address. ``It attracted accusations of favoritism and sentiments of rejection, and stimulated regional rivalries and even linguistic tensions. ``Much of the discontent of Canadians found expression in hostility to the Meech Lake accord.'' Mulroney said he would begin working Monday to find another approach to constitutional reform, and he tried to calm fears of political instability by telling foreign investors not to worry about Canada's present problems. Bourassa, in a speech to his National Assembly in Quebec City, said that in the future he would only negotiate Quebec's status and other national issues one-on-one with the federal government, not with other provinces. ``The process of constitutional reform has been discredited and the government of Quebec will not agree to go back to the constitutional table,'' said Bourassa. Bourassa said that the failure of Meech Lake made progress unlikely on other constitutional questions dealing with Senate reform and aboriginal rights. Quebec's leader also said he would not take part in the annual meeting of provincial premiers and the prime minister in August in which national issues are discussed. ``In preparing its future, Quebec has important assets,'' Bourassa said, citing the province's economic strength and the strategic location. ``Quebec has the freedom of its choices,'' he said. ``And it's going to make its choices withs realism and calm. I can assure you that my only goal will be the superior interests of the Quebec people.'' Jacques Parizeau, leader of the separatist Parti Quebecois, extended his hand to Bourassa to work out a new direction for the province. Newfoundland and Manitoba were the only holdouts against Meech Lake, named after the government retreat near Ottawa where it was originally worked out in 1987. Manitoba leaders tried to bring the accord to a vote, but were blocked by a lone Indian legislator who promised to kill the accord because he wanted a similar recognition as distinct for native people. ``While the world gears up for the 21st century,'' Mulroney said, ``we have failed to resolve a debate that predates confederation itself.'' ``To my fellow Quebecers, I want to say how dismayed I am that Quebec has not, at this time, been able to rejoin the constitutional family with honor and enthusiasm,'' said Mulroney, a native Quebecer. ``But Quebec emerged from these negotiations with its dignity and its principles intact. Meech Lake, a constitutional amendment, was aimed at winning Quebec's signature on the 1982 Canadian constitution. Many in English Canada feared the accord would have given Quebec extra powers. But constitutional experts said the ``distinct society'' clause would have had few practical effects. Under it, the Canadian Supreme Court would have been given a guideline to take Quebec's special character into consideration when ruling on challenges to laws under the constitution. The clause had strong symbolic significance in the province _ Canada's largest, with one-fourth of the country's 26 million people. On Saturday, Mulroney seemed anxious that the constitutional squabble not affect Canada's economy or discourage potential investors. ``To our friends and partners abroad, I urge that this situation be kept in perspective,'' he said. ``Canadians have always overcome challenges to our unity and will shall do so again.'' Herb Gray, leader of the Liberal opposition, blamed Mulroney for the debacle. ``Most Canadians now seriously question the prime minister's moral authority to govern,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Epidemic Triggering Explosion Of TB Cases, Expert Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9, `The peaceful ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with details from march, quote; picks up 10th graf, `Now, an ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX6
DOC.TEXT: AIDS is triggering a global explosion of tuberculosis, especially in Africa, and at least 2 million people are already infected with the microbes that cause both diseases, a health official warned on Saturday. Meanwhile, a top East German health expert cautioned that the opening of the Iron Curtain is likely to speed the spread of AIDS in Eastern Europe, which has so far largely escaped it. Tuberculosis is already the world's single biggest bacterial killer, and experts fear that HIV, the AIDS virus, is likely to make the problem much worse. ``A serious epidemic of TB is occurring as a result of the HIV epidemic, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa,'' said Dr. Peter Eriki of the World Health Organization. He said Africans ``were unable to contain a relatively small tuberculosis problem before the arrival of HIV, and they are singularly ill-prepared for coping with a very large problem ahead.'' Eriki, a tuberculosis specialist who formerly directed the TB Control Program in Uganda, described the problem at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, meeting in San Francisco through Sunday. About 1,000 conference delegates on Saturday joined thousands of whistle-blowing, chanting protesters calling for more money and better health care for people with HIV disease. March organizers said 20,000 people participated in the march and rally. Police estimates put the size of the march at around 4,000. The peaceful march was briefly disrupted when a large group of demonstrators led by the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power rushed into the San Francisco Centre, chanting, ``We're here, we're queer and we're not going shopping!'' They said they were protesting the dismissal of a Nordstrom department store chain employee in Seattle who tested HIV positive. A Nordstrom store dominates the Centre. Nordstrom has said the former salesman was offered less stressful positions but he declined them. At the rally following the march, conference officials joined demonstrators to call for more cooperation between activists and scientists. ``The apparent divisions between us are not real,'' conference co-chairman Paul Volberding told a crowd that gathered in Justin Herman Plaza at the end of the march. ``We cannot tolerate it, and hopefully, this march will help end it.'' Now, an estimated 1.7 billion people _ one-third of the world's population _ is infected with tuberculosis bacilli. Most of these people suffer no outward symptoms. However, Eriki said that 20 million of the infected people are sick with TB, and 3 million die each year, most of them in the developing world. In its rapid spread over the past decade, the AIDS virus now infects an estimated 5 million to 10 million people around the world. Eriki said HIV has emerged as the single most important risk factor for active TB disease. HIV weakens the body's natural defenses against disease. This can awaken dormant TB infections that had been held in check. Eriki said that HIV-infected people are also more likely than healthy people to catch the TB germ and to spread it to others. He said that 1.5 million of the 2 million people infected with both microbes live in sub-Saharan Africa. In Burundi, 55 percent of TB patients also carry the AIDS virus. As people become more aware of the link between AIDS and TB, ``there is the potential that the diagnosis of tuberculosis will become a social stigma,'' Eriki said, ``creating fear among health care workers, who may become reluctant to work in tuberculosis programs.'' Sieghart Dittman, director of the Institute for Hygiene, Microbiology and Epidemiology in East Berlin, noted that the AIDS virus is still rare in Eastern Europe. The rate of AIDS cases is 45 times lower than in Western Europe, and the HIV infection rate in the general population is practically zero. However, he attributed this differences in large part to the Iron Curtain and the Berlin Wall and cautioned that the removal of travel barriers is likely to speed the spread of AIDS. ``Now, when borders between Eastern and Western European countries have become more open, when in Germany the walls are broken down completely, the problem of the spread of HIV infection might become far more serious, and special attention should be paid to this threat,'' he said. The international AIDS conference has drawn scientists from over the world, and has also sparked protests from AIDS activists seeking more money for AIDS research and treatment and an end to discrimination against AIDS patients. As of late Friday, the number of arrests totaled 299. Among other reports presented at Saturday's sessions: _A survey of AIDS screening labs by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control shows most do a highly accurate job of spotting AIDS-infected blood. The report by Dr. David Cross found that the labs correctly identified 99.8 percent of samples that carried the AIDS virus and 99.4 percent that were free of HIV. _Children of AIDS-infected mothers born free of HIV may still suffer developmental problems. Dr. Thomas Koch and others from the University of California, San Francisco, said their work suggests the virus in the mother's body somehow harms growth of the fetal nervous system, even if the virus is not transmitted to the baby. _A University of California, San Francisco, survey of doctors in residency training found that two-thirds did not plan to treat AIDS patients when they started their own practices. Half of them said they would not want to be known as having people with AIDS among their patients.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavia Declares Sovereignty; Ukraine Supports Similar Move
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Parliament of Soviet Moldavia Saturday approved a declaration of sovereignty, following the Baltic republics and Russia with the claim that its laws supersede those of the Soviet Union, Tass reported. In the Ukraine, the republic's Communist Party congress voted Saturday to support calls for a sovereignty resolution, Tass said. The Ukraine is the second-largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics and its agricultural and industrial heartland. Similar statements of sovereignty two years ago began the gradual march toward independence by Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Earlier this week, the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan passed a declaration of sovereignty while the Republic of Georgia formed a commission to begin working toward independence. The Russian Parliament adopted a sovereignty resolution two weeks ago, setting the stage for a confrontation with the government of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Russia contains half the population and three-quarters of the land mass of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has suggested creating a looser federation of ``sovereign states'' to defuse the crisis of local demands for sovereignty. The Moldavian sovereignty resolution also declares that all natural resources and land in Moldavia belong to the republic and not the Soviet Union, Tass said. Moldavia's Parliament also agreed to stop celebrating the anniversary of the republic's annexation by the Soviet Union just prior to World War II. Moldavia had previously been part of Romania and some activists have expressed to desire to reunify with that country.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Murderer Wants to Die Alone
DOC.TEXT: Mass murderer R. Gene Simmons wants to end his life in quiet solitude, officials say, the way he has lived his last days on death row _shunning the family of those he killed who are desperate to learn why. Simmons is scheduled to die by lethal injection Monday night for the Christmastime 1987 murders of 16 people, including 14 family members. Simmons, 49, has refused all visits, even from religious advisers and family members. ``Gene, more than anything else, I'd like to talk to you,'' said Manuel Ulibarri of Denver, the brother of Simmons' slain wife, Becky. ``You never forget,'' Ulibarri said. ``The hurt is always there. The whys are always there. If you go without telling us anything, the why will always be there.'' Charlotte May has asked to witness the execution of the man convicted of killing her daughter and grandchild. Her daughter, Renata, 22, was married to one of Simmons' sons, and they had a 1-year-old son. ``I want to see for myself that he is dead,'' said Ms. May. She said she told a prison official ``it's not going to be any harder than when I had to go to the morgue and identify my daughter and grandchild.'' Officials and family members believe that Simmons, knowing an incestuous relationship with his daughter was about to tear apart his family, methodically killed 14 relatives _ some as they got home from school; others as they arrived for a Christmas holiday. No one can say for sure why the convenience store clerk massacred the 16 people in about six days because Simmons has kept silent. But surviving family members and officials who investigated the murders have pieced together scenarios through evidence, old letters and assumptions. Prosecutor John Bynum believes that Simmons, who never changed his innocent plea, wiped out his family because they had become aware of an incestuous relationship between Simmons and his eldest daughter, Sheila, 24. ``That relationship signaled a problem between he and his wife and the end of their family relationship,'' Bynum said last week. ``Because of that relationship with his daughter, he became alienated and isolated from all these other people.'' One of Simmon's attorneys, John C. Harris of Russellville, said his client had received hundreds of requests for interviews from national television shows and magazines. They have been denied. Simmons' refusal to talk to reporters is consistent with his behavior on death row, where he has kept his distance from other inmates, said prison spokesman David White. ``He doesn't have a lot of conversation, really, with anyone. That has been his demeanor throughout his incarceration with us,'' White said Friday. ``Apparently, he wants to go this thing alone.'' Simmons has maintained that he wants to die to ``let the torture and suffering in me end.'' He has rebuffed all appeals on his behalf, and federal judges have ruled in separate decisions that a Roman Catholic priest and a fellow death-row inmate had no legal standing to intervene in an effort to block the execution. State Attorney General Steve Clark has said that only Simmons can prevent his execution by seeking an appeal. Simmons has shown no inclination to do so, prison officials and attorneys say. In March 1989, Simmons was within 12 hours of execution before the U.S. Supreme Court issued a stay. He was moved Friday from the state Correction Department's Maximum Security Unit at Tucker to a cell next to the death chamber at the Cummins Unit. It is the same cell where John Edward Swindler was housed before he died in the electric chair last Monday for the 1976 slaying of a police officer.

DOC.HEAD: More Thunderstorms But Lots of Sun
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms fell Saturday across the eastern United States after violent storms that included tornadoes in four states. Dry weather prevailed over the rest of the country. The showers and storms fell primarily over the Atlantic Coast and the Gulf Coast states during the afternoon. Morning thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in north-central Vermont; 1.52 inches of rain fell on Montpelier in a very short period, while Northfield got 1.71 inches and Brookfield 2.15. Scattered showers fell across the Ohio Valley and the upper Great Lakes region in the afternoon. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies dominating west of the Mississippi River. Heavier rainfall for the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included more than an inch in Tampa, Fla., and Albany, N.Y. Strong northwesterly winds prevailed from the middle Mississippi Valley to the upper Great Lakes in the afternoon. The low for the Lower 48 was 34 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. On Friday, thunderstorms developing along and ahead of a cold front produced severe weather east of the Mississippi River, mainly from Illinois to the middle Atlantic Coast states and from Mississippi to the Carolinas. Thunderstorms spawned sixteen tornadoes Friday, including four in Ohio, three in Illinois and three in Kentucky. One person was injured in a tornado near Pickaway, W.Va., in early evening. There were nearly 70 reports of large hail or damaging winds Friday. Thunderstorms produced winds gusting to 69 mph north of Chesapeake, Va., and to 70 mph at Carey, Ohio. Two people were slightly injured when strong thunderstorms destroyed three trailer homes south of Columbia, S.C., late Friday afternoon, while others produced golf-ball size hail at Tuscaloosa and Cottondale, Ala., and in southern McMinn County, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TEHRAN
Strong Aftershocks Rock Northern Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with earthquake scene; ADDS color; CORRECTS spelling of Rudbar; Pickup 11th, `The toll ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK2,3,5,17, WCX1-3
DOC.TEXT: Strong aftershocks sent panicked residents rushing into the streets of northern Iran on Saturday, and mass graves were dug for victims of an earthquake that some official reports say killed at least 40,000 people. Efforts continued to rescue people trapped under piles of rubble in the mountainous areas of Iran's northwestern Gilan and Zamjan provinces that were devastated in Thursday's quake. ``Today we found eight people alive, but they will probably be the last we uncover,'' said Nassir Zadeh, an officer of the Revolutionary Guard helping search and rescue operations in the flattened city of Rudbar, about 140 miles northwest of Tehran. The official Islamic Republic News Agency reported that ``with the lapse of time,'' hope was fading that more survivors could be found alive under the rubble. Thursday's quake destroyed dozens of towns and villages Caspian Sea region. Journalists flying over the area saw horrific scenes of devastation in villages where thousands of mud brick and concrete homes were reduced to rubble. No estimates of casualties were yet available from remote regions. Numerous mountain villages remained cut off because landslides blocked roads. In Rudbar, dozens of Iranian military helicopters flew supplies into makeshift airstrips on a small island in the river that flows through this agricultural center that once numbered 180,000 people. The two-lane roads leading to Rudbar and neighboring Manjil were clogged with rubble from buildings and huge boulders dislodged from the surrounding hills. Mile-long columns of buses, ambulances and flatbed trucks carrying bulldozers, cranes and other equipment had to wait for hours to reach their destinations. Foreign relief teams and supplies began arriving in the region, as the world responded to the disaster. There were conflicting death tolls. A national radio broadcast said more than 40,000 people were feared dead and 100,000 were injured. IRNA reported about 29,000 people killed. In Rudbar, earthquake victims were buried in mass graves ``without counting the bodies'' because of the heavy death toll, IRNA said. The quake destroyed the only hospital there. The quake destroyed or damaged about 95 percent of the city's buildings, and residents were reduced to living in thousands of tents pitched near the roads as temperatures soared to 105 degrees. ``Twelve members of my family died when our house collapsed,'' said a weeping woman, sitting in front of a tent pitched next to the remains of her home. Amrola Mosadei, a carpenter, said, ``I tried to grab my daughter's arm when the house started swaying, but then she was gone and the roof collapsed.'' More than 200 aftershocks have hit the region, the biggest registering 4.2 on the Richter scale and rocking the Tarom-e Olia region about 125 miles northwest of Tehran, IRNA said. Thursday's quake was at least 7.3 on the Richter scale. Another large shock jolted the northern city of Rasht early Saturday, ``making panic-stricken residents take to the streets,'' it said. There was also a third powerful aftershock in the area. ``Aftershocks, which continue in the mountainous regions, are endangering the relief operation,'' the news agency said. The toll surpassed a quake that killed 25,000 people in nearby Soviet Armenia in December 1988, and a quake in Iran in 1978 that also killed 25,000. The quake's toll was the highest anywhere since July 28, 1976, when an estimated 200,000 people were killed in China by a quake. ``Our people have learned to resist difficulties, and consider the national disaster to be a divine test,'' President Hashemi Rafsanjani told Syria's foreign minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. ``We have submitted ourselves to God's will.'' State television, monitored in Cyprus, showed injured people lying on the ground in long rows with health workers passing back and forth with medication as flies swarmed around. Army helicopters landed in a field and picked up the injured on stretchers while a woman in the traditional black chador carried a tiny child in a bundle of cloth. The television showed numerous bodies wrapped in white shrouds. Grieving women wailed nearby. Dozens of other bodies, many wrapped in carpets, lay unclaimed beside a road. A gray-haired man lifted chunks of concrete from a building with the help of younger men, then burst into tears when a body was uncovered, presumably a family member. One shot from a helicopter showed a fissure in a plowed field that gaped open at least three yards at its widest point. It was several yards deep and hundreds of yards long. A 205-member French relief team arrived in Iran Friday night, and at least 200 relief workers from the Soviet Union also traveled to the region, IRNA reported. The official Soviet news agency Tass said an Armenian team that rescued people in the 1988 Armenian earthquake went to Iran. In Soviet Azerbaijan, which borders Iran and has strong ethnic ties with much of its population, the president declared a day of mourning Saturday and black flags flew across the republic, Tass said. Iran's health department sent 100 teams into the area to prevent the outbreak of contagious diseases. Iran, at odds with the United States since the 1979 seizure of hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, said it would welcome relief from the American Red Cross and other U.S. humanitarian groups. The two nations have no diplomatic ties. ``We want to be helpful without regard for our political differences with Iran,'' said Richard Boucher, deputy State Department spokesman in Washington. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Loggers Rally For Jobs After Feds Move to Protect Endangered Owls
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of trucks adorned with yellow ribbons rolled through the heart of Oregon's timber country Saturday, honking horns to protest federal logging reductions planned to protect endangered owls. ``I'm kind of blowing off steam,'' said Joe Trimble of Roseburg, who joined a column of 434 rigs that took an hour to pass through this western Oregon town. ``For a lot of us, this might be our last show. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Director John Turner announced Friday that the northern spotted owl was given threatened species status because logging is destroying the birds' old-growth forest habitats in Oregon, Washington and Northern California. Trimble said his gripe is with federal officials, not the nocturnal bird. ``I'm not mad at the owl,'' he said. ``He's just there.'' Turner said he didn't expect to see logging significantly disrupted this summer because nearly all timber sales on federal lands have already been reviewed by his agency. Timber industry representatives have warned that tens of thousands of people stand to lose their jobs if the government puts millions of acres of timber off-limits to logging to save the owl. People lined the streets wearing yellow hats, shirts and ribbons to show solidarity with loggers as the line of trucks rolled past. Drivers threw candy to children, waved and smiled while blowing horns so loudly people couldn't hear each other talk. Among those on the sidewalk was Carol Maples of Roseburg, wearing a yellow shirt and holding the youngest of her four children, Tenille, dressed in a yellow sweater. Her husband Perry Maples is a lumberjack. She said everyone in her family either works in logging or is married to a logger. ``I'm just supporting the timber industry,'' Mrs. Maples said. ``I don't know if it will do any good. They (environmentalists) have already got what they wanted.'' ``Everything here revolves around logging,'' she said ``There ain't much to do unless you move away.'' The protest was part of Forest Celebration '90, a rally sponsored by timber industry support groups. Afterward, people gathered at Umpqua Park at the Douglas County Fairgrounds for speeches by political candidates, a forum on natural resources and a concert by Hoyt Axton. A U.S. Forest Service study called Douglas County the most timber-dependent county in Oregon. It is named for 19th century Scottish botanist David Douglas, whose name is borne by the Douglas fir, the towering staple of the timber industry in the Northwest. Environmentalists and scientists say protection is needed because the birds' numbers have dwindled to between 3,000 and 5,000 breeding pairs.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Recall Horror of Earthquake
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ambulances loaded with corpses raced through the streets of this flattened city Saturday, weaving their way through thousands of tents pitched on and near the roads. Outside the tents, dazed, hollow-eyed residents of this agricultural center recalled the horrow of Thursday's earthquake that some officials say killed at least 40,000 people in the mountainous provinces of northwesten Iran. ``Twelve members of my family died when our house collapsed,'' said a weeping woman, sitting in front of a tent pitched next to the remains of her home. A carpenter, Amrola Mosadei, remembered the moment the earthquake struck. ``I tried to grab my daughter's arm when the house started swaying, but then she was gone and the roof collapsed,'' he said. Rescue workers continued to dig through piles of rubble in temperatures reaching a blistering 105 degrees to find survivors, but hope was fading fast. ``Today we found eight people alive, but they will probably be the last we uncover,'' said Nassir Zadeh, a Revolutionary Guards officer taking part in the search and rescue operations. Clouds of dust rose over the rubble, as thousands of townspeople, soldiers and rescue workers milled about this city, once home to 180,000 people. The quake destroyed or damaged an estimated 95 percent of the buildings in Rudbar, 140 miles northwest of Tehran. A dam about a mile upriver from the city held firm during the quake, or many more lives would have been lost. The roof of a large, new cement plant caved in, and military warehouses at a nearby base were reduced to heaps of stone and mortar. Dozens of Iranian military helicopters flew supplies into makeshift airstrips on a small island in the river that flows through the city. There was massive confusion on the roads leading to Rudbar and the neighboring town of Manjil, also leveled by the quake. Detachments of police, soldiers and paramilitary volunteers struggled in vain to keep the traffic moving. The two-lane roads were clogged with rubble from collapsed buildings and huge boulders that had been dislodged from the surrounding hills. Mile-long columns of buses, ambulances and flatbed trucks carrying bulldozers, cranes and other equipment had to wait for hours to reach their destinations. Journalists flying over the region, south of the Caspian Sea, saw horrific devastation in remote villages, where thousands of mud brick and concrete houses were flattened into rubble. Large cracks in the soil, some of them more than a foot wide, testified to the power of the quake, which measured 7.3 on the Richter scale. And there were the unforgettable scenes. A group of about eight orphaned children _ no more than 8-years-old _ smiled at reporters as they were driven away in an army truck to an uncertain future.

DOC.HEAD: Crock-Pot Company Ex-President Killed; Grandson Charged
DOC.TEXT: An 83-year-old man who was president of the company that introduced the Crock-Pot electric slow-cooker was beaten to death, and his grandson was charged Saturday in the slaying, police said. Authorities said they hadn't determined what started the argument Friday night between Isidore H. Miller and his 21-year-old grandson, Michael Miller, that ended in the elder man's death. Michael Miller was charged in Jackson County Court on Saturday with second-degree murder and armed criminal action, said police Sgt. Keith Francis of the homicide unit. He was held pending an arraignment. Francis said Michael Miller used his fists and a brass lamp to beat his grandfather to death. ``All we're saying is that it was a domestic disturbance _ obviously,'' Francis said. ``We don't know what it was about.'' Isidore Miller, former president of appliance maker Rival Manufacturing Co., was pronounced dead in his Kansas City home Friday night. His wife, Evelyn, suffered minor injuries when she tried to intervene in the fight, police said. A neighbor, Frank Titterington, said Mrs. Miller called for help when her grandson allegedy began beating her husband. Michael Miller apparently had been visiting his grandparents for several days, but had not stayed there regularly since he was a small child, Titterington said. Isidore Miller was Rival president from 1964 to 1986, when the company was acquired by the New York investment banking firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. During Miller's tenure, Rival developed and introduced the Crock-Pot. Rival's current president, Thomas Manning, said the company's business quadrupled after the slow-cooker's debut. Miller continued as a consultant to the company after the buyout, Manning said.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth of July Fare Cuts Announced
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has reduced fares for the Fourth of July travel period by up to 51 percent, offering tickets at $119 or less each way to anywhere in the U.S. mainland, the company said Saturday. The non-refundable sale fares of $119, $99, $79 and $49 apply to travel that begins July 1, 2, 4, 6 or 7 with returns on July 4 or later. There are no other minimum stay requirements. Among a sample of sale fares were: New York-Los Angeles, $119, a 44 percent savings from the regular fare of $213; Denver-Boston, $99, a 48 percent savings from the regular $192 fare; Cleveland-Seattle, $99, a 51 percent savings from the $203 regular fare; Denver-Chicago, $79, a 44 percent savings from the $140 regular fare; Newark, N.J.-Buffalo, N.Y., $49, a 36 percent savings from the $76 regular fare. The airline said tickets must be purchased by June 28 and within 24 hours of making a reservation. A Continental statement said hundreds of thousands of seats would be available at the sale fares. July Fourth falls on a Wednesday so little business travel will occur during the holiday week and seats that would normally be used by business travelers will be available to vacationers.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes During Show At Base, Pilot Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `A retired ...,' to CORRECT name of plane to `Douglas A-20 Havoc,' sted `Douglass A-20 Havack.'
DOC.TEXT: A World War II-era fighter plane crashed Saturday during an air show at Dyess Air Force Base, killing the pilot, authorities said. The plane crashed next to a runway at 1:05 p.m., said Sgt. Nickie Forge, a spokesman for the base near Abilene. Retired Lt. Col. Jack Morgan, who was announcing the air show, saw the plane crash nose-first. ``It had taken off and had flown one pass down the runway and was circling back to come in for a second pass,'' he said. ``As he was turning back toward the field, the airplane appeared to lose control and it went into the ground.'' The plane didn't burn, said Mark Jeffries, who was covering the air show for radio station KTLC. The rest of the show was canceled after the crash, which occurred during the base's annual Big Country Appreciation Day. The plane did not crash near the crowd, authorities said. The pilot was identified as Donald Vincent Knapp, 58, of Abilene. The privately owned plane was a World War II-era P-51 Mustang, a single- engine two-seater, said a duty officer at the Federal Aviation Administration's regional office in Fort Worth, who declined to give his name. An FAA investigator was en route to the crash site. The cause was not immediately known. The pilot and plane had been flying ``in support of'' the Confederate Air Show, Forge said in a statement. The non-profit Confederate Air Force restores and flies military aircraft. Its Harlingen headquarters and museum are Texas' 10th most popular tourist attraction. The group, which recently announced plans to move to Midland, owns 145 restored airplanes from World War II and stages air shows worldwide. A retired airline pilot, Max Gardner, died in October 1988 when a Confederate plane he was flying, a twin-engine Douglas A-20 Havoc attack bomber, crashed into a cornfield during an air show in Harlingen.

DOC.HEAD: Liberals Elect Opponent of Meech Lake as Party President
With AM-Canada, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Liberal Party Saturday elected as its leader Jean Chretien, an opponent of a failed constitutional reform that would have recognized the distinct culture of Quebec. Chretien, 56, topped Montreal Member of Parliament Paul Martin 2,652 votes to 1,176. He succeeds Party Leader John Turner, who beat Chretien for the top job in 1984 then led the Liberals through two election thrashings. Chretien, a lawyer, was elected to an indefinite term. He is not a Member of Parliament and must stand in a not yet set by-election. Earlier, the party congress chose another opponent of the so-called Meech Lake accords as president, purely an administrative role. Former Cabinet minister Don Johnston defeated former minister, John Roberts 1118 votes to 958. Johnston succeeds Michel Robert for a two-year term. The 350,000-member party is Canada's main opposition group. The party convention came as Canada smarted from the defeat of the Meech Lake accord that would have designated Quebec a ``distinct society.'' The constitutional amendment was aimed at winning Quebec's signature on the 1982 constitution and prevent any secessionist move by the province. Chretien, from Quebec, now has the formidable task of rebuilding links with his province and healing a party deeply divided over the Meech Lake accord that died Saturday. The Meech Lake accord was strongly backed by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his Progressive Conservative Party. The agreement had to be passed by the federal government and the legislatures of all 10 provinces by midnight Saturday. But a decision by Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells on Friday to shelve debate in his province's legislature on the constitutional amendment effectively killed it. Johnston, a Montreal tax lawyer, left the Liberal party three years ago over its support of the Meech Lake accords and sat in Parliament as an independent. He resigned from politics the next year. Johnston said reduction of the federal party's $3.5-million debt will be his top priority as party leader.

DOC.HEAD: Green Bay Inundated
DOC.TEXT: Water reached the tops of street signs, and 200 homes along a river were evacuated Saturday as nearly 5 inches of rain inundated this city in 24 hours. Police rescued three people who fell into the swollen East River when their canoe capsized. Rescuers spent more than two hours freeing one of the three, a teen-age girl, who was pinned in a pile of logs that flood waters stacked against a bridge. The logs acted like a dam, contributing to flooding of homes for about two blocks on either side of the river. Mayor Sam Halloin declared the neighborhood a disaster area. The city Fire Department and the Brown County Sheriff's Department evacuated homes along the river. About 100 of the evacuees were rescued by boat and taken to emergency shelters. A brisk northwesterly wind Saturday pushed waters from Lake Michigan into the mouth of the Fox River at Green Bay, preventing the high waters of the tributary East River from subsiding, said Ted Van Rossum, Brown County emergency government director. ``Because water hasn't receded yet, we may have to evacuate some more people,'' Van Rossum said. ``But right now, we're playing a waiting game.'' Water reached the tops of street signs and covered fences at a municipal park. County officials said damage could reach millions of dollars. The National Weather Service said 4.88 inches fell in Green Bay in 24 hours, the heaviest rainfall for a 24-hour period since 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Opposition Figures Without Charges
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday arrested without charges two bodyguards of a leading opposition politician and disrupted a news conference held to announce their detentions. The moves marked the third consecutive day police have interfered with attempts by the media to cover an informal campaign to legalize opposition parties in this one-party state. In an apparent effort to stop opposition politicians from addressing the press, Kenya's police chief said he ordered officers to halt news conferences deemed illegal and make arrests without warrants, The Standard newspaper reported. ``We do not need to wait around wasting time waiting for a warrant of arrest while these people go on with their illegal meetings,'' The Standard quoted police chief Philip Kilonzo as saying. Kilonzo was not available for comment, his office said Saturday. Kenneth Matiba, a former cabinet minister and a leading advocate of political pluralism, said the arrest of his bodyguards was part of a harassment campaign against the loose alliance of lawyers, politicians and church leaders pressing for democratic reforms. President Daniel arap Moi, who has ruled since 1978, has vowed to stay in power and has threatened to hunt down ``like rats'' people who he says are trying to divide the nation.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Mediator Reports Progress in Salvadoran Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. mediator said Saturday that Salvadoran government and rebel negotiators had made progress toward resolving one key issue in their peace talks _ the role of the armed forces. But U.N. mediator Alvaro de Soto and representatives of both sides cautioned that no agreements had been reached after five days of talks in this resort town 40 miles south of Mexico City. ``We have advanced considerably on the subject of the armed forces,'' Soto said. He declined to elaborate, citing rules of confidentiality agreed upon by the two sides. Soto said the negotiators had discussed rebel demands that notorious human rights violators be purged from the ranks of the armed forces. He said the discussions had now moved on to the role of the Civil Defense forces, a combat-equipped volunteer force which has been accused by international human rights groups of abusing the civilian population. Miguel Saenz, a member of the rebel delegation, said Saturday's session had produced ``advances ... but I wouldn't call them considerable. ``There are no agreements. The progress is, in fact, that previous days were characterized by much generalization, and now we're getting down to more concrete matters,'' he said. Oscar Santamaria, chief of the government delegation, said he agreed with Soto that considerable progress had been made. Although the government has not agreed to rebel demands to dissolve the Civil Defense forces, Santamaria said its role could be changed to make it a relief or public service organization acting entirely in ``the civilian field.'' Members of both delegations say the current round of talks offer better prospects for progress, albeit slight, towards ending El Salvador's 10-year-old civil war than four previous tries at negotiations between 1984 and 1989. Meanwhile, in San Salvador, the capital, an estimated 2,000 people took part in a peace march, urging the rebel Farabundo Marti Liberation Front (FMLN) and the government to end the war in which about 72,000 people have died. The rebels have demanded that human rights violators be punished and removed from the army's ranks as a necessary pre-condition to a peace agreement. Although international rights organizations say military and military-linked death squads have been responsible for slaying up to 30,000 people, no officer has ever been convicted or even tried for rights abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Leftists Clash With Police Near Neo-Nazi Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto BER06
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of leftist radicals clashed with riot police near the headquarters of a neo-Nazi group, and at least 16 officers were injured, East Berlin police said Sunday. The masked radicals, hurling firebombs and wielding clubs, battled with police late Saturday in the strife-ridden Lichtenberg section of the city, a police spokesman said. Four people were arrested and 16 police officers were injured, some seriously, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He said none of the rioters were injured. Police used tear gas and water cannons to break up the roving bands of leftists. The clash came hours after 4,000 leftists from both East Berlin and West Berlin demonstrated in the same neighborhood. The group was protesting recent attacks by right-wing radicals on the large number of foreigners living in the area. ``Nazis go away, foreigners can stay,'' the group of demonstrators shouted, many of them wearing black masks or hoods and wielding wooden clubs and iron bars. The group marched on an apartment house where members of the neo-Nazi group National Alternative have made their headquarters. But thousands of police blocked intersections and the group, marching while a sound system hooked to a van played thundering punk rock music, veered in another direction. There were no incidents immediately after the demonstration broke up. A few of the neo-Nazi skinheads stood on the balcony of the apartment draped with banners bearing fascist slogans. Later, police said the crowd of leftists rampaged through the street and battled the remaining police. Four police vans were also burned and a small cigarette kiosk was plundered in the riot, the government news service ADN reported. Neo-Nazi skinheads have staged several attacks on foreigners, leftists and homosexuals in recent months. Members of the group have been squatting in the rundown building in Lichtenberg. Lichtenberg, a working class district where many Vietnamese, Mozambicans and other foreigners live, has become a flashpoint for extremist violence by rightists and leftist radicals. East Germany has become increasingly tense as it faces soaring unemployment caused by its quick shift from a Socialist economy to a free market. East Germany and West Germany are to merge their economies in one week.

DOC.HEAD: Title Sale: Buddy, Could You Spare a Line?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th pvs, `The owner...' to UPDATE with background on title. Pickup 6th pvs, `William Shakespeare...'
DOC.TEXT: Shakespeare fans with ready cash and a taste for grandeur will have a chance to buy a piece of history when the title of Lord of the Manor, Stratford-upon-Avon, is auctioned on July 19. The title, which dates from the end of the seventh century, is Britain's most expensive, having been sold two years ago for $150,500. It will be part of a sale of English literature, history books and manuscripts at Sotheby's auction house in London, the company announced in a sale catalog issued Friday. Sotheby's did not say who owned the title. Lordships of the manor are the oldest titles in England, pre-dating the Norman Conquest of 1066, but their significance is largely symbolic today and they carry no rights to land, houses or a seat in the House of Lords. The owner does not become a lord, but can write Lord of the Manor of Stratford-upon-Avon after his or her name. The Sunday Times said the seller of the title was Donald Wilson, a commoner, who bought it from Lord Sackville. ``The rapidity with which the title has been put back on the market suggests that this quaint industry _ the selling of lordships _ is becoming a speculators' game,'' the newspaper said. David Williamson, co-editor of Debrett's Peerage, was quoted by the Sunday Times as saying: ``I think it is ridiculous. People are paying huge prices because they think they can call themselves `Lord,' but they can't. These titles mean nothing.'' The Sunday Times said sales of titles are expected to raise nearly $7 million this year, double the 1989 figure. William Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564, spent much of his life there and was buried in 1616 in Holy Trinity church. The manor was the keystone of the English feudal system, and the lord of the manor was the most important person in village affairs. Traditionally, the lord gave his people protection in return for services, and throughout the Middle Ages, the English nobility based its power on the ownership of land through the manor. The powers of the lord gradually diminished as those of the king grew. The title at Stratford-upon-Avon is first mentioned as land belonging to Ethelard, sub-king of the Hwicca tribe, who granted it to Egwin, who was third Bishop of Worcester, from 693 to 714. The title passed to successive bishops of Worcester for centuries until 1549, when it passed to John Dudley, Earl of Warwick. On the death in 1553 of King Edward VI, Dudley tried to put his daughter-in-law, Lady Jane Grey, on the throne. But he failed and was executed the following year. The title has also been held by the 3rd Duke of Dorset _ a British ambassador to the Court of Versailles (remembered for taking an English cricket team to France as the 1789 Revolution was erupting). Another title holder was Lionel Edward, 3rd Lord Sackville, uncle of a Vita Sackville-West, a leading light in the Bloomsbury literary movement of 1920s London.

DOC.HEAD: Concert Sets Liberation Tempo Before Mandela Speaks
With AM-Mandela, Bjt ^LaserPhoto BX15
DOC.TEXT: Entertainers from a cross-section of the music industry performed at the Esplanade Saturday, setting the tempo for the 221,000 people waiting to see and hear Nelson Mandela's liberation message. The South African group Ladysmith Black Mambazo interrupted its European tour, and flew from London for the event. Ladysmith performed alone, and later with singer Paul Simon. They had performed on Simon's ``Graceland'' album. ``There are many messages surrounding the image and the man, Nelson Mandela, but to me the one that is so powerful is that a moral position cannot be broken and will prevail,'' Simon said before his performance. Among other entertainers performing for free at the concert were Jackson Browne, Bobby McFerrin, Michelle Shocked and South Africa's Johnny Clegg & Savuka. A group of about 50 children paid tribute to Mandela by singing the national anthem of his African National Congress. Mandela praised Massachusetts for being the first state in the U.S. to divest all interests and funds from South Africa in 1977. ``Together with you, we have added a page to the universal struggle for human rights,'' he said. ``Sisters and brothers, given the illustrious history of this city, it is only natural that we consider ourselves visiting our second home,'' Mandela said. After the speech, a tribute to Mandela composed by Hugh Masekela rang out from the public-address system. The man honored in Africa and Europe for his struggle against apartheid in South Africa danced to the beat, pumping his fist in the air.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Photographer Jack D. Miller
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper photographer Jack D. Miller died of cancer Friday. He was 64. Miller worked for eight California newspapers, including The Orange County Register, where he began as a photographer in 1968 and in recent years managed the photo processing laboratory. Other papers where he worked included the Garden Grove News, Long Beach Press Telegram, Los Angeles Times and Bellflower Herald Enterprise.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys for German Church Say Family Is Hiding Treasures
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for an East German church trying to recover medieval treasures stolen during World War II allege that a Texas family moved or hid some of the items in the last two weeks. In court documents, the attorneys accuse relatives of Joe T. Meador of Whitewright of moving the articles from bank vaults in Dallas and Whitewright so the lawyers wouldn't find them. Meador, who died in 1980, allegedly stole the items, including centuries-old manuscripts of the Gospels, from the church in Quedlinburg at the end of World War II. Motions filed in federal court Friday allege that Meador's siblings, Jack Meador and Jane Meador Cook, ``have been linked to more than half'' of about 18 artworks taken from a mine-shaft hiding place near Quedlinburg in 1945. The Meadors allegedly inherited the trove, valued in the millions, when their brother died of cancer. Raymond A. Krell, a Houston attorney for the Meadors, did not return phone calls Saturday from The Associated Press. Alan Harris, an attorney for the church, declined to comment on the motions Saturday. No court action was taken Friday on the motions. The church filed a lawsuit Monday after three weeks of negotiations with the family reached an impasse. The lawsuit, which also names the First National Bank of Whitewright as a defendant, seeks unspecified damages. The bank has held some of the artwork for at least the last three months, its lawyer said. A U.S. State Department legal adviser said this week that the lawsuit was filed after East German officials learned the treasures were about to be moved to Switzerland, where secrecy laws would make them impossible to trace or recover. U.S. District Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater granted a 10-day temporary restraining order Monday barring movement of the trove, pending a decision in the case. But he denied a plea by church lawyers that the items be placed in court custody for safekeeping. On Tuesday, he ordered the church be allowed to examine, photograph and inventory treasures being stored in vaults at the Whitewright bank and the First Interstate Bank of Dallas. During an examination Thursday of Mrs. Cook's safe-deposit boxes in Dallas, only one item believed to be a Quedlinburg treasure was found, the church contends. Mrs. Cook removed several of the other items last week, the church says, and an unidentified person rented a new safe-deposit box and ``placed certain items'' into it. The objects were not identified.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Mayor Received Guns From Contractors
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Alex Daoud bought, via the city Police Department, four handguns from firearms companies competing for a lucrative contract to arm the police force, a newspaper reported Saturday. Daoud obtained at least two Sigarms Inc. semiautomatic handguns from a Vero Beach dealer before voting in September for purchase of $153,000 worth of Sigarms guns, the Miami Herald reported. Daoud received a third weapon _ at half-price and allegedly in violation of federal gun laws prohibiting interstate sales of weapons without firearms transaction reports _ from Glock Inc., a Georgia distributor competing for the same contract, the Herald reported. Daoud bought another weapon from Sigarms that was delivered seven weeks after the September vote, the paper reported. Daoud has refused to comment on the gun purchases or other financial deals with city contractors that have made him the focus of a federal investigation into allegations he used his public office for private gain. Several other Miami Beach officials, including the purchasing director and former police chief, say the transactions appear improper and could pose a conflict of interest. ``I don't like the ethics of buying from suppliers the city is doing business with,'' said Edward Davis, the purchasing director. Daoud placed his gun orders through police Sgt. John Clements, who runs the department's shooting range and was in charge of contracting for the force, the Herald reported. ``He was probably trying to get a discounted price, the price a police officer would get,'' Clements told the Herald. ``In retrospect, it was bad judgment. If I had to do it over again, I wouldn't do it. But at the time I didn't think there was anything wrong with it.'' Karl Walter, a vice president in Glock's Georgia office, and Thomas Boyle, an executive with Sig Sauer's U.S. distributor, denied they were trying to get an edge in the competition for the city gun contract and said they were only reacting to the mayor's requests for pistols. ``He asked and I said `Yes,'' said Boyle, who told Davis that Daoud only paid for the guns last week, the Herald said.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Jewish Rabbis Consider Support For Homosexual Colleagues
DOC.TEXT: Several dozen Reform Jewish rabbis around the nation are homosexual, rabbis acknowledge, and for the first time in the religion's 4,000-year history they may gain official support. At the annual meeting of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, which starts Sunday, Reform rabbis from around the nation will decide whether to stand behind colleagues who have kept their homosexuality secret. The rabbis serve some 1.5 million Reform Jews in the United States. A four-year study prepared by a committee under Rabbi Selig Salkowitz, of Union Temple in Brooklyn, supports gay and lesbian rabbis while affirming heterosexual, monogamous, procreative marriage as the ideal Jewish union. A proposed resolution, to be put to a vote Monday, says gay or lesbian rabbis are not condemned or unacceptable under Reform Judaism, but notes they may not be acceptable to all congregations. It will still be up to the rabbis if they wish to come out of the closet. ``The Committee urges that all rabbis, regardless of sexual orientation, be accorded the opportunity to fulfill the sacred vocation which they have chosen ... Sexual orientation is irrelevant to the human worth of a person,'' the resolution says. It is expected to pass, conference executive vice president Rabbi Joseph Glaser has said. Gay and lesbian rabbis _ though not publicly acknowleged as such _ and their supporters raised the issue with the conference to support their admittance to Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, which ordains about 40 rabbis a year from campuses in Cincinnati, New York, Los Angeles and Jerusalem. Salkowitz said probably less than 10 percent of the 1,560 Reform rabbis nationwide are homosexual, reflecting some estimates of the number of homosexuals in the general population. Rabbi Gary Zola, national dean of admissions for the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, since 1982, estimated there were probably under 5 percent. ``The college officially does not know whether or not people it has admitted have or haven't been (homosexual). Unofficially we know that some must be,'' Zola said. The college's policy has been not to bring up the subject of sexual orientation when screening candidates, and that policy will not change, Zola said. He was unaware of anyone who had been accepted to the rabbinical college who had professed to being homosexual. The conference can refuse to place and congregations can dismiss a rabbi, but a homosexual rabbi cannot lose his or her ordination, which represents an attainment of learning, not a sanctification by God, as in the priesthood. Ancient Jewish law is uniformly against homosexuality. The first reference, in Leviticus, states that ``with a man shalt thou not lie as with a woman; it is an abomination.'' Reform Judaism is not strictly bound by ancient Jewish law, but allows for thousands of years of social change that have occurred since Moses' time. It was the first branch of Judaism to ordain women as rabbis, in 1972. The Conservative movement ordained its first woman rabbi in 1985, but still opposes homosexual rabbis. Orthodox Jews do not allow women or homosexual rabbis.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Family Survives Week Lost in Cave
DOC.TEXT: A man and two sons _ lost in a cave without food, water or light for most of a week _ were rescued Saturday, officials said. Gary William Lutes, 37, and sons Gary Jr., 13, and Timothy, 9, of Tampa, Fla., were rescued at 2 a.m., then hospitalized for dehydration. Lutes said the three became lost Monday when their lamps went out, leaving them in total darkness in New Trout Cave in Pendleton County in eastern West Virginia. ``We had been exploring for about an hour and a half, and we were supposed to have another half an hour,'' Lutes said in a telephone interview from Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Harrisonburg, Va. The three had left their pack with food and water on a side trail when their lamps started going out, said Lutes, who had explored caves for the past 20 years without becoming lost. ``We would have had to crawl on our hands and knees, and we could have gone in circles or in the wrong direction,'' Lutes said. ``We decided the best thing to do was sit down and wait for someone to find us.'' The search didn't start until Thursday, when the three were to meet with family members in Powhatan, Va. When they didn't arrive, family members contacted authorities and local and regional cave explorers started looking for the Luteses. Rescuers entered the cave late Friday and found the family's pack at 12:30 a.m. Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Bells And Banners Welcome Mandela Into Boston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela receiving honorary degree at dinner; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Mandela and his ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XJFK1, BX5,6,7,8,9,11,15; LaserColor BX8
DOC.TEXT: Ecstatic crowds welcomed Nelson Mandela on Saturday in Boston, a city he saluted as inspiring the kind of freedom he is trying to win in his native South Africa. Mandela spoke to high school students in a predominantly black neighborhood, was the guest of honor at a luncheon at the John F. Kennedy Library, then went to the Esplanade for a concert to benefit his African National Congress. Mandela's busy public day ended at a fund-raising reception at the Copley Plaza Hotel, where he spoke and accepted an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Northeastern University. The degree was awarded to him in absentia two years ago while he was imprisoned. The Mandelas were to spend the night at the Copley. Mandela and his entourage arrived at Logan International Airport from New York shortly before 11 a.m. to the chants and screams of supporters. The crowd waved the ANC banner of black, green and gold and danced a traditional South African dance. Mandela joined in a few steps. He praised Boston for its role in the American Revolution and its leadership in the anti-apartheid movement. ``It was here that the Boston Tea Party served notice that the citizens of this country would not live under domination by the British,'' Mandela said. ``That was the establishment of a fundamental principle which has inspired democracies and democrats, freedom fighters, revolutionaries all over the world.'' At the luncheon at the Kennedy Library, Mandela was presented with a bust of the late president by Sen. Edward Kennedy. Flanked by Kennedy family members, including former first lady Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Mandela praised the senator for pushing for sanctions against South Africa. He cited Kennedy's trip to South Africa and his unsuccessful effort to visit Mandela in prison, which Mandela said nonetheless gave the ``black prisoners in a white South Africa ... a lot of strength and hope.'' Later, on the grassy Esplanade on the banks of the Charles River, Mandela danced to a song written in his honor before a crowd of 221,000. He again thanked those in Boston and beyond for fighting apartheid. ``It was you who rallied around our cause at a time when we thought ourselves all alone. For all this we are very grateful to you in Massachusetts, in Connecticut and the entire new England area,'' he said, as thousands waved ANC flags and banners of black, green and gold.
