After the speech, strains of a tribute to Mandela composed by Hugh Masekela rang out from speakers and Mandela danced, grinning broadly. Jackson Browne, Paul Simon and Ladysmith Black Mambazo also performed. Mandela's wife, Winnie, led the crowd in chants and apologized for not appearing at a tribute held earlier at St. Paul's Cathedral. ``I understand one of the fascists telephoned and made a bomb threat. I'm very sorry,'' she said. Organizers of the tribute said someone had called a bomb threat into the cathedral at noon. A bomb squad swept through and pronounced the site safe before letting the audience in. But the State Department told Mrs. Mandela through an ANC representative not to go to the event, said Judie Blair, a spokeswoman for a local anti-apartheid group, adding she did not know why. The Mandelas' daughter, Zenani Dlamini, 31, who lives in Boston with her husband, went to the cathedral without her mother. Mandela's daughter by his first marriage, Makaziwe, 36, who attends the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, did not attend Saturday's public events but was expected to meet with her father privately Sunday morning, said Janet Levine, a South African exiled writer who lives in Boston. Earlier Saturday, Mandela urged students _ who had been waiting several hours in a high school gymnasium without air conditioning to hear him speak _ not to drop out of school. He called education ``the most powerful weapon which we can use in order to prepare our youth in their role as leaders of tomorrow.'' ``If there is any appeal I could make is that the young people of Boston and, indeed young people in the United States, must take it upon themselves to ensure they receive the highest education possible so they can represent us as future leaders,'' he told the cheering crowd. Standing before a hand-painted mural of him, Mandela concluded with words that have marked many of his speeches in the United States: ``Just remember, we respect you. We admire you. And, above all, we love you.'' After Mandela's 10-minute speech, Paul Goodnight, 44, of Boston's predominantly black Roxbury section said: ``I feel great about the energy that is out here because of him. Yeah, it was a short visit, but I appreciate someone coming here and stirring us up.'' Crowds lined Mandela's motorcade route through Roxbury and their response to Mandela's quick wave was enthusiastic. ``People are ready for him. He was in jail for so many years and he came out with so much love. After 27 years, I know he is a child of God,'' said Joycelyn Patterson, a resident who waited for Mandela's limousine to drive by. The 71-year-old deputy head of the African National Congress is on a grueling six-week tour of 14 countries aimed at raising money and keeping international pressure on South Africa's government to end its policy of racial separation. He was scheduled to leave for Washington on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Government Warns of GM Seat Belt Problems
DOC.TEXT: Owners of 1.6 million Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird cars should check their seat belt release buttons for damage that could lead to belt failure, the government said Friday. General Motors Corp. plans a recall of 1984 to 1990 Carmaros and Firebirds to replace or repair the belts free of charge, the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration said, adding that damaged belt buckles should be replaced immediately. The problem is caused when the red plastic push-button weakens from prolonged exposure to radiation and heat from the sun, the agency said. ``This may cause the safety belt to latch improperly or not at all, greatly increasing the risk of injury in a crash,'' it said. NHTSA Administrator Jerry Curry said if a safety belt on one of the affected cars does not latch or release properly, the car should be taken in for repair. If there is no damage to any of the car's four belts, owners can await recall letters from GM, he said. Owners of vehicles that don't need immediate attention will be sent follow-up letters by the manufacturer for buckle replacement as parts become available, NHTSA said. The problem has been investigated by the government since August. Curry said GM voluntarily is conducting the recall.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Moves Toward ``Shadow'' Senator Spot
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson took the first steps Friday to run for a ceremonial District of Columbia ``shadow'' Senator post. City Board of Elections spokeswoman Leona Agouridis said Jackson's aide Dee Hunter picked up the qualifying forms for Jackson, who previously flirted with running as a candidate in the mayoral Democratic primary. Jackson, interviewed in New York by Washington television station WUSA-TV, said he is giving the idea ``serious consideration.'' A top Jackson aide said the two-time Democratic presidential hopeful is ``strongly considering'' running for the job. ``He hasn't made up his mind yet, but he is giving this some serious thought,'' said the aide, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. ``He thinks it may be the best way to advance statehood.'' In recent months, Jackson has said gaining statehood for the nation's capital is his top priority. Under the ``shadow'' concept, the city will send three representatives _ equivalents to two senators and a congressman _ to lobby on behalf of statehood for the district on Capitol Hill. The delegation, which does not receive city funding, will have no other official function. Jackson has until July 5 to gather the 2,000 petition signatures he needs to place his name on the ballot, and must file other preliminary papers with the city's campaign finance office by next Friday, Agouridis said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats Move to Avert Civil Rights Filibuster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEDEs with 2 new grafs; SUBS 9th graf with 2 new grafs to CLARIFY that motion was to shut off filibuster on bringing up the bill, not debate on the bill itself. ^By MIKE ROBINSON
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell moved Friday to head off a filibuster over a major bill to combat job discrimination and said he hoped to bring the measure to the floor next week. But it appeared likely that opponents of the measure still would be able to force postponement of any vote on final passage until next month if they failed to reach a compromise with sponsors. Mitchell told the Senate that ``positive and productive'' negotiations between the Bush administration and Senate sponsors are in progress but moved to shut off debate in case they failed to yield agreement. Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas replied that GOP lawmakers would not be ``stampeded'' into approving such a measure during the visit to Capitol Hill next week of South African leader Nelson Mandela. ``It's pretty obvious what is happening here _ they want to have a bill pending when Mr. Mandela is addressing a joint meeting of Congress'' on Tuesday, Dole told the Senate. The bill aims at overturning six job-discrimination decisions that the Supreme Court handed down last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harrassment in the workplace to requiring employers whose hiring patterns do not reflect local demographics to show that their practices are necessary for business reasons. The Bush administration has been threatening a presidential veto of the measure produced by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. But talks between sponsors and the administration have been going on with an eye toward resolving the problems. The administration says the bill that emerged from committee would usher in the use of racial hiring quotas on the part of employers who would be fearful of lawsuits otherwise. Senate sponsors led by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., disagree and note that the measure says nothing about quotas. Mitchell's move Friday was not designed to shut off a filibuster actually in progress but to assure that no such delaying tactics could be used to block floor action before next week's Fourth of July recess. Mitchell's action if approved would shut off debate on a motion to proceed to floor action on the bill. But opponents of the bill could still force delay of a final passage vote until after the recess. He set a vote Tuesday on whether to shut off debate but left open the possibility that agreement could still be reached. ``It is my fervent hope that we will be able to reach an agreement that will be satisfactory to all concerned,'' Mitchell said. As a result of the negotiations, he said, ``the issues have been significantly narrowed on that matter and there will hopefully be an agreement which will permit us to act in a relatively concise period of time and that is of course an objective that we all share.'' Dole said he objected to the notion of using the Mandela visit to bring pressure on the Senate to push through the civil rights measure. ``I know there must be temptation,'' he said. He said there was no ``opposition to civil rights on this side of the aisle'' but that a number of concerns about the specifics of the bill remained. ``Maybe by next week we will have that worked out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President Plays Golf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush stopped for a round of golf Friday at a country club near Frederick, Md., as he headed for a weekend at Camp David. The president flew by helicopter to the Holly Hills Country Club with Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears, author Dan Jenkins and Rep. Marty Russo, D-Ill. Bush greeted golfers at the clubhouse and stopped to sign some scorecards. Bush was to remain until Sunday at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Flood Dead Rises to 23; Crane Begins Sifting River Debris
DOC.TEXT: Cranes on barges began scooping away a mass of debris floating beside an Ohio River dam Friday after the body of a 23rd victim of last week's flash flood was found, officials said. The body was found Thursday night near the Hannibal locks and dam among the rubble of homes and belongings destroyed by a wall of water which rushed down the Wegee and Pipe creeks more than 20 miles upstream near Shadyside on June 14, said Chuck Vogt, the Belmont County coroner's investigator. The number of people listed as missing dropped from 11 to 10 after the body was discovered and identified. The name of the latest victim was being withheld until relatives are notified, Vogt said. Steven Wright, an Army Corps of Engineers spokesman at the dam, said two cranes were assisting in the search. ``They are dipping their buckets very gently into the debris because we are searching for bodies out there. The material is being placed on another barge where people are going through it by hand,'' he said. Boards and pieces of trees accounted for most of the rubble, which floated on a surface area about the size of two city blocks. Also visible among the mass were toys, furniture, propane and heating oil tanks and dozens of tires. Last week's flooding was caused when 5{ inches of rain fell over a hilly area of eastern Ohio in 3{ hours. Three counties in the area were declared federal disaster areas as a result of the flooding the downpour caused. In Nebraska, weary residents told Gov. Kay Orr that they need help to deal with rats, illness and red tape in the aftermath of flooding. Mrs. Orr traveled to Rogers and Platte Center Thursday to assess the damage to northeastern Nebraska from floods and other storms that battered the state a week ago. Rain again fell over the saturated countryside Thursday as residents struggled with the cleanup chores.

DOC.HEAD: Unrest, Aging Wells Cause Decline in Soviet Oil Exports
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``The Soviets,'' to note U.S. decline, size of barrel.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet oil exports dropped nearly 10 percent last year, according to figures provided Friday by the CIA, raising concerns about domestic oil shortages and cuts in supply to Eastern Europe. The export drop reflected a decline in oil production caused by aging wells, labor unrest and bureaucratic chaos, U.S. officials said. The Soviet Union exported 3.69 million barrels of oil a day in 1989, down from 4.08 million in 1988, according to the newly compiled CIA figures. The decline matches the drop in oil production, although the Soviet Union is still the world's largest oil producer. Most of its oil is used at home. The export cuts were made in Soviet sales to Western Europe, surprising analysts who believed the Kremlin was so strapped for cash that it would have reduced supplies to Eastern Europe _ which pays for Soviet oil with goods, not money. So far this year, the Soviets have sharply cut supplies to their one-time communist allies in Eastern Europe, but they have promised to make up the shortfall by summer. U.S. government officials are uncertain whether this year's drop foretells a dramatic interruption in supplies to Eastern Europe, or whether such temporary cut-offs previously happened frequently but were unreported by the secretive former communist governments of the Soviet bloc. The U.S. officials predict a further decline in Soviet production unless the Kremlin opens the door to foreign investment in offshore drilling and in technology to salvage wells damaged by years of forced production in western Siberia and other regions. ``Without Western assistance, production will probably decline dramatically,'' said one U.S. official, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. The Soviets' oil problems are somewhat mirrored by the U.S. experience. Aging wells, environmental objections to offshore drilling and weak prices have led to a decline in U.S. production from 9 million barrels a day in 1985 to about 7.4 million barrels a day now, and an increase in imports as a percent of consumption from 31 percen to about 50 percent in the same period. A barrel is 42 gallons. U.S. companies are eager to sell their technology and know-how to the Soviets, but most are put off by bureaucratic red tape and by the difficulties in converting profits in rubles, the Soviet currency, into dollars. Furthermore, U.S. and other companies are concerned about making deals with the Soviet Ministry of Petroleum and Gas Industry, which has undergone several reorganizations in the past year as the Kremlin struggles with economic reforms. U.S. officials say Leonid Filimonov, currently in charge of the ministry, may lose his job this summer. Analysts and government officials attribute the Soviet problems to aging oil fields which no longer yield as much as before, wells which became water-logged because the Soviets wanted to increase production by forcibly injecting them with water, and a lack of funds for the technology needed to explore new offshore and Arctic Circle fields. In addition, the new openness in the Soviet Union has spawned labor unrest as oil field workers demand better living conditions. Ethnic unrest in several Soviet republics, especially Azarbaijan, has cut into the production of oil and natural gas equipment, officials say. U.S. officials are divided, however, on whether the reduction in Soviet exports will come at the expense of the Kremlin's newly democratic clients in Eastern Europe. The Soviet government announced several months ago that starting in 1991 it would only sell oil for cash. Eastern Europe, heavily indebted and trying to move from a communist to a free-market economy, relies on the Soviets for 70 percent of its oil. ``Faced with a very difficult choice of paying in valuable and scarce hard currency for their previously subsidized oil and gas imports from Moscow or buying those supplies'' from other sources, Hungary, Poland and Romania will probably opt for increasing their trade with Middle Eastern oil exporters, wrote Robert Copaken, a senior political economist at the Department of Energy. The Eastern Europeans could pay for the oil with goods they produce, although these have traditionally been too low in quality to effectively compete with Western goods, Copaken wrote in the June issue of the East-West Report, a newsletter. But a U.S. government official, speaking on condition he not be named, predicted that Eastern Europe probably can continue to rely on Soviet oil supplies in the short term. Eastern Europeans might work out an agreement whereby they will barter goods for oil at real market prices, rather than the heavily subsidized and unrealistic prices both sides enjoyed in the past, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Disaster Ranks With Deadliest of Recent Decades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1st graf to UPDATE death toll in Iran.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in northern Iran's devastating earthquake _ at least 36,000 according to Iranian officials _ makes it one of the deadliest quakes of the past 20 years. Here is a brief look at the other great killer quakes of recent decades and the destruction they left behind:
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET ARMENIA, DEC. 7, 1988, 25,000 dead
DOC.TEXT: An earthquke measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale nearly leveled the city of Leninakan, population 290,000. At least 32 mountain villages were destroyed. Much of the death and destruction was blamed of the flimsiness of the buildings, even though most had been built in the past 15 years.
DOC.HEAD: IRAN, SEPT. 16, 1978, 25,000 dead.
DOC.TEXT: A 7.7 quake destroyed the city of Tabas in eastern Iran. The ancient city was an oasis stopover on the Silk Route between China and Europe, but in 90 seconds it was gone. The main tremor and the hundreds of aftershocks wreaked such havoc that the exact death toll will never be known.
DOC.HEAD: CHINA, JULY 28, 1976, official figure 200,000 dead.
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake, 7.8-8.2 on the Richter scale, followed by a second tremor of 7.9 devastated 20 square miles of the city of Tangshan. The Chinese government kept foreigners from visiting the site, and did not acknowledge the extent of the disaster until a decade later. Unofficial estimates put the death toll at as many as 800,000.
DOC.HEAD: GUATEMALA, FEB. 4, 1976, 22,778 dead.
DOC.TEXT: The quake measuring 7.5 struck at 3 a.m., cracking buildings in Guatemala City, tumbling adobe-brick houses, trapping their sleeping inhabitants. More than 75,000 people were injured and more than a million left homeless.
DOC.HEAD: PERU, MAY 31, 1970, 66,794 dead.
DOC.TEXT: The greatest damage occurred in the canyon city of Yungay. This was a ``vertical'' quake, a violent up-and-down motion rather than the more usual side-to-side shaking. The quake, registering 7.7, sent a huge slice of the mountain downward at an estimated 140 miles an hour, sweeping away everything and everyone in its path. A mile away, the rebuilt city of Ranrahirca, wiped out by a landslide in 1962, was again destroyed.

DOC.HEAD: Convictions on 30 Greylord Counts Vacated in Judge's Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has partly overturned the conviction of former Cook County Circuit Judge John F. Reynolds stemming from the Operation Greylord investigation of judicial corruption, his attorney said Friday. U.S. District Judge William T. Hart vacated Reynolds' convictions on 30 counts of mail fraud, ruling that the mail-fraud statute was improperly applied in Reynolds' case, said attorney Jeffrey Steinback. Still standing are Reynolds' convictions on six counts of racketeering conspiracy and a subsequent conviction on perjury, Steinback said. Operation Greylord was an undercover FBI ``sting'' operation that uncovered judicial corruption and resulted in convictions of judges, other court officials, and one state legislator. Reynolds, convicted in 1986 and ordered to repay $33,000 in bribes for fixing cases, has served four years of a 10-year prison sentence on the mail-fraud and conspiracy convictions. He also is serving a two-year consecutive sentence for perjury, Steinback said Friday. ``We're obviously pleased with the determination'' by Hart, said Steinback, who said his 59-year-old client is incarcerated at a federal minimum-security facility in Big Spring, Texas. A message left with the U.S. attorney's office was not returned late Friday afternoon. Reynolds' mail-fraud convictions were vacated Monday, and for the same reason mail-fraud convictions were overturned in 1988 in the case of Reginald Holzer, another judge found guilty in the Greylord probe, Steinback said. Both involved allegations that the defendants had defrauded citizens of ``intangible rights,'' such as good government, by their actions. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 1987 that the fraud in such cases had to involve loss of tangible assets, such as money or property. Steinback said a status hearing in Reynolds' case is scheduled for July 5, and he will decide afterward whether to seek a reduced sentence for his client. Reynolds could be released as early as six months from now even without a reduced sentence, Steinback said.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Group Pushing Vegetarian Diet Meets At Steakhouse
DOC.TEXT: An animal-rights group that hopes to change Americans' meat-eating ways scheduled a meeting here Saturday at the Black Angus steakhouse. The ``Animal Rights 101'' meeting is sponsored by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, a group based in Washington, D.C. Sue Brebner, outreach coordinator for the group, said society currently treats animals as ``things and slaves.'' The class is supposed to help individuals adopt a cruelty-free lifestyle, which including a meat-free diet, she said. The Black Angus breed of beef cattle is noted for high yield of quality steaks.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Ofelia Heads for Taiwan; 29 Dead in the Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Ofelia headed for Taiwan on Saturday after battering the northern Philippines with heavy winds and rain. At least 29 people were killed and more than 30,000 others were forced to flee their homes, officials said. At 5 a.m. Saturday, Ofelia was estimated to be 95 miles northwest of Batanes island, the country's northernmost province, forecasters said. Ofelia, with winds of up to 75 mph, was moving north-northwest at 12 mph toward the southern portion of Taiwan, weather forecaster Alan Mescallado said. Casualty figures compiled by the Red Cross and other relief agencies showed that at least 29 people died and more than 30,600 fled their homes as the storm cut a swath of destruction through Luzon island. Hardest hit was La Union, about 150 miles northwest of Manila, where at least 22 people drowned or were crushed to death in landslides. In Pangasinan, west of La Union, two people were electrocuted. In the Manila suburb of Pasig, three children died when a concrete wall collapsed on their shanty. Lightning killed two people during a thunderstorm spawned by Ofelia in Lanao del Sur province on Mindanao island, about 520 miles south of Manila. Mescallado said weather conditions in Luzon were expected to improve as Ofelia moved across the Luzon Strait separating the Philippines from Taiwan.

A hard-line critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was elected head of the Russian republic's Communist Party today, increasing the probability of a split in party ranks. Delegates attending a party conference gave Ivan Polozkov 1,396 votes in a run-off election Friday night, giving him a victory over Oleg Lobov, who garnered 1,066 votes, according to official results announced this morning. The victory of Polozkov, who rejects Gorbachev's call for the party to relinquish its control over the economy, could turn the Russian Communist Party into a power base for traditional hard-liners. Polozkov immediately took the podium and made a conciliatory speech, saying he would ``do everything to consolidate, to meld together our Russian organizations, from the first days of its (the party's) activity. Believe me, I'll do everything for that.''

Iran is deliberately underreporting the number of casualties from Thursday's massive earthquake out of fear of a political backlash, leaders of a group seeking to overthrow the country's Islamic leadership say. ``The regime is very much fearful of public outrage,'' said Shahin Gobadi, spokesman for the People's Mojahedin of Iran. ``They're very much afraid of the political aftershocks.'' As Gobadi spoke Friday, members of the organization denounced Iran's government at a noisy rally held in a park across the street from the White House. Northern Iran was stuck Thursday by an earthquake measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter Scale. Iran has told the United Nations that the death toll is at least 36,000, but Gobadi said his organization has received estimates closer to 100,000.

A battle between the timber industry and environmentalists over the northern spotted owl may move to court now that the Interior Department has decided to curtail logging to protect the bird. John Turner, director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, announced his decision Friday to list the brown, reclusive owl as a threatened species, jeopardizing thousands of logging jobs in the Pacific Northwest. Ralph Saperstein, vice president of the Western Forest Industries Association, said his Portland-based group plans a lawsuit demanding review of scientific studies Turner used in making his decision. ``We feel they used selective scientific information,'' Saperstein said.

Women dominated a protest that brought 140 arrests outside the international AIDS conference to dramatize activists' complaints that research is too male-oriented. ``We're here because women with AIDS are not getting access to drug treatment trials,'' said Kate Bollard, a member of Seattle's chapter of ACT UP, the AIDS activist group. ``Women are being only looked at as people who transmit the virus, not as people who have the virus.'' The Friday arrests came after several hundred protesters blocked traffic in a downtown shopping district. They brought total arrests during four days of protest to 299 at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS at the Moscone Center, which has been shielded from protesters by tight security. The only incident inside came Friday morning when demonstrators held up a banner reading, ``NIAID: Form a Women's Committee,'' during a speech by an official with the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

An international committee is calling for much tighter job exposure standards after finding that radiation is three times more dangerous than was believed little more than a decade ago. The International Commission on Radiological Protection said Friday it would recommend a 60 percent reduction in job standards, from an annual dose of 5 rem to 2 rem. A rem is a standard measure of dose from powerful ionizing radiation like X-rays or nuclear radioactivity. Doses often are expressed in millirem, or thousandths of a rem. A chest X-ray from an up-to-date machine will expose the patient to about 20 millirems. For long-term exposure of the general public, the commission is maintaining its current recommendation of no more than 100 millirem per year on average. But it is suggesting that the averaging period be five years instead of a lifetime.

The Soviet Union is shifting nuclear warheads out of its rebellious Baltic and southern states and into less volatile parts of the Russian republic, U.S. officials say. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the moves reflected Moscow's concerns about nationalist and ethnic tensions that could lead to attempts by rebel forces to take control of a nuclear weapons storage depot. Private specialists on the Soviet military said the United States should view the development as reassuring because it indicates Kremlin authorities are taking precautions in the face of political instability in non-Russian republics. ``It's at least as much in our interest as in the Soviets' interest that their nuclear weapons not fall into the wrong hands,'' said Matthew Bunn, a senior research analyst at the Arms Control Association.

DOC.HEAD: Program Gets Parents Into Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 26th graf with 2 grafs to expand on mandatory school age and CORRECT year kindergarten was implemented, ``The school xxx''
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Carlos Sheriff brought home a red-and-white folder every week telling his mother everything she needed to know about his education. So did nearly 160,000 other students in two states. Those folders have become a trademark of a program that seeks to assist schools in getting parents involved in the education of their children. School districts in Mississippi and California are participating in the Quality Education Project, and negotiations are underway to establish programs in Illinois. Carlos completed sixth grade this spring in a Jackson, Miss., school participating in the project. His mother, Juanita Sheriff, said, ``I really like that red folder because then I can see what he's doing (each week) _ if he's not doing as well as I think he should, even if he's been a little talkative.'' ``You can send back comments. I tell them `you have my permission to take him behind the green board' (for a whipping). Or, I tell them to give him some extra work as punishment.'' Nancy Honig, president of the project, says increased parental involvement is a key to improving and sustaining academic achievement. ``There's a lot of talk now about parental involvement but no one really knows what that means,'' said Ms. Honig who developed the program in 1982 as a grass-roots movement to improve California's public school system. ``It sounds so simple. I mean it's not sexy at all, parental involvement. People want to talk about curriculum reform, drug abuse babies _ those are all important issues _ but here is an issue where we have a window of opportunity to address and nothing is happening. Everyone's researching, not acting.'' The project has several objectives: _Get parents to actively support the school. _Encourage school administrators to institute activities that would keep parents informed about their children's progress and about what's going on in the school. _Train school administrators to work with parents. _Train teachers in the specifics of enlisting parent support at home for the school's efforts. _Train parents in what to do at home to further educational process, both at home and at school. _Get civic, business and religious groups to support the schools and their program of parental involvement. _Promote reading at home as a key way for parents to help their children with school work. Seven districts in Mississippi, comprising 28 elementary schools with 16,000 children, and 32 districts in California, with 143,358 students in some 230 schools, have signed on for the program. The school districts usually take the first step, asking QEP to assess their needs and come up with solutions. While the goals are the same, the programs are tailored for the individual school district. QEP will train someone from the area, and pay the person, to implement the program. ``We knew we couldn't change attitudes through lectures,'' said Honig. ``We had to find an easily replicated, hands on program. Why we're successful? It's not just because we have the tools. It's because we don't send the wrong person in to do the job. ``We would never hire a non-Mississippian to work in Mississippi. If we worked in New York City, we would hire someone who grew up in the project area and became educated. People relate to people with similar backgrounds.'' Bettie McKinley, principal of Isable Elementary School in Jackson, Miss., said the program ``serves to intensify the relationship between the school, home and community. It seeks to draw the community into the school to make it feel more involved. . .. It has made my job easier in some ways.'' McKinley's school joined the program in February. Ivy Lovelady, Mississippi program director, said Gov. Ray Mabus and the state education superintendent invited QEP into the school system. Federal funding was obtained last fall to implement the parent-school partnership program. The needs are great, said Lovelady, citing the statistics of a representative Mississippi school district: 98 percent of the students are black, 95 percent live in poverty, 65 percent drop out of school before finishing high school and 35 percent have parents who are illiterate. The school system had begun to make substantive changes even before QEP entered the state. Students were required to attend school through age 14, beginning in 1985. That was raised to 16 the following year. Kindergartens were introduced in the 1983 school year, although attendance is not mandatory. The state legislature has passed a bill that would require students to begin attending school at age 5, but still is considering a funding measure to implement the law. In the seven Mississippi districts participating in QEP, parents, teachers and administrators all sign ``performance contracts.'' Parents pledge to provide a quiet place for study every night, encourage the completion of homework every day, make sure their children get plenty of rest and get to school on time every day, to attend various school events and parent-teacher conferences and spend at least 15 minutes per day reading with their children. In return, the principal and teacher pledge to provide a safe place for students, teach all the necessary concepts for academic achievement and keep parents abreast of the students' progress. Most teachers send home with each child each week a personal folder with the week's work enclosed, as well as notes, announcements and other messages. Parental participation in the Mississippi has grown from 5 percent to about 20 percent since the project was implemented, Lovelady said.. ``We are able to get the parents out,'' said Lovelady. ``We are able to get the parents educated. We are able to get staff to communicate with the parents.

DOC.HEAD: Decade After Crash, Truth Still Elusive
DOC.TEXT: Did a terrorist plant a bomb or did a missile go astray in an aerial dogfight? Was there a bungled investigation or an international coverup of what caused the mysterious jetliner crash that killed 81 people? Ten years after a DC-9 on a domestic flight blew apart in twilight skies and fell into the sea near the tiny island of Ustica, the questions remain unanswered. Many theories have been advanced, but little information has been revealed. A complicating factor is judicial secrecy, which forbids disclosure until the investigation leads to indictments or closure of the case. In May, an official panel of five experts who said in March 1989 that a missile had struck the plane re-examined the evidence and split between missile and bomb. Premier Giulio Andreotti declared recently: ``The more I read about it, the less I understand. It's very disturbing, this interweaving of suspicions and rumors.'' A week earlier, a state television report claimed authorities ignored or forgot radar data from a station in Tuscany. The report interpreted the data as indicating the DC-9, bound for Sicily, was caught in an engagement between French and Libyan jet fighters, but gave no proof. It joined a multitude of sensational, unsubtantiated theories that have arisen over the years. Some contended a Libyan aircraft with Col. Moammar Gadhafi aboard was above Sicily shortly before the crash. One spoke of Gadhafi's favorite air force pilot chasing a defector across the skies; in another, U.S. jets fired a missile that hit the airliner by mistake. French, U.S. and NATO officials have denied any military activity in the skies that night. Gadhafi has blamed the United States, but offered no evidence. Discovery of a crashed Libyan MiG fighter in the Calabrian mountains, almost due west of where the DC-9 went down, bolstered claims of a Libyan connection. Doctors who performed an autopsy on the pilot first gave the date of death as July 18, then as late June, then switched back to the later date. Investigators suspect air force officials of manipulating, hiding or destroying evidence and of lying about what happened that Friday when, 57 minutes into the flight and without a hint of trouble, the plane disappeared from radar screens while flying from Bologna to Palermo. The DC-9 of Itavia, a small private carrier, carried 77 passengers, including 11 children and two infants, and a crew of four. School vacations had begun and many passengers were businessmen joining their families for the weekend. Italy was plagued by terrorism in 1980 and a bomb first seemed the likely cause. A few months after the crash, however, Transport Minister Rino Formica told Parliament a missile was suspected. In 1987, the government yielded to the outcries of relatives and engaged salvagers, who raised part of the wreckage. Evidence studied by several official investigations indicated the kind of explosive found in corpses and wreckage was used to make missiles. Examination of the fuselage indicated the aircraft was struck from the outside, according to news reports. Still, investigating commissions have differed. In May 1989, two months after the commission report that a missile was to blame, another commission appointed by Ciriaco De Mita, then premier, decided a bomb could not be ruled out. This spring, when two members of the first commmission reversed themselves and concluded a bomb was responsible, an association of victim's relatives, joined by some politicians, protested that the two had ties to a state-owned company involved in making missiles for the air force. After the protest and the television report about the radar tapes, investigating magistrate Vincenzo Bucarelli announced that an October deadline to close the case would be lifted. ``Every time we got close to the truth, someone pushed us back, but I think we have finally succeeded in getting politicians'' on our side, said Daria Bonfietti, who heads the association of victims' relatives. Her brother, Alberto, was killed in the crash. The Ustica mystery has been compared to other unsolved cases in Italy, including assassinations of Mafia investigators and terrorist bombings, including one in a Milan bank 21 years ago. Corriere della Sera, a leading daily, said in an editorial: ``A country without truth. Evidently, around so many Italian mysteries, there's an invincible force capable of confusing the ideas of experts, playing with the efforts of the magistrate's office, mocking the appeals of the head of state. It's this force, in reality, that struck the Itavia jet, massacring 81 people and the sense of justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Cutbacks Worry Economy-Watchers
DOC.TEXT: Optimists on the economic and investment outlook have grown increasingly worried of late that the American consumer might let them down. The prime source of their concern is the government's monthly statistics on retail sales, which have posted declines in each of the last three months. They fell 0.4 percent in March, 0.9 percent in April and 0.7 percent in May. As economists have been quick to point out, the last three-month run of lower sales reports came in the 1981-82 recession. Many observers want to see more data before they hit the alarm button. The latest numbers, they say, may have been skewed by quirky weather patterns or some other aberration. Nevertheless, almost all agree that the figures have sketched out a picture of potential trouble that is hard to ignore. If anybody packs the wallop necessary to knock the long economic expansion off track, they say, it is U.S. consumers, who account for two-thirds of the country's gross national product. ``The role of the consumer in the U.S. economy is akin to that of Atlas in Greek mythology,'' says James Grant in the current issue of his commentary Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ``The consumer is the indispensable man, woman and child. Let him stop borrowing (and therefore stop spending) and the GNP would be in jeopardy.'' Or in the words of David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities Inc. in New York: ``This downturn in consumer spending is crucial. Modest growth in consumer spending is essential to keep the economy from slipping into recession. ``American consumers' demands for goods and services have been a main prop to global production and provide much of the motive for business investment in plant and equipment. ``If consumers sustain this recent spending pace much longer, other countries' economies will also be slow and curtail their demand for U.S. goods. In addition, U.S. companies would question the need to go ahead with their planned capital outlays. ``Under that combination of circumstances, the eight-year-old expansion would come to an end.'' One consoling thought shared by Resler and many of his counterparts: The sales figures in the spring might have looked quite a bit different without the influence of a strange sequence in the weather. First of all, an unusually balmy January and February may have stolen business away from March and April. Then, exceptional rain in May might have further discouraged shopping. But a close look at the statistics ``suggests that there's more going on than just the effects of unusual weather patterns,'' concluded Maury Harris, economist at PaineWebber Inc. ``The labor market is softening. The housing recession is starting to have ripple effects on retail sales,'' Harris said. Should the weak pattern in consumer spending continue to show up in the June data and beyond, most analysts' hopes that an economywide business slump could be averted rest with the Federal Reserve. Said Jack Lavery at Merrill Lynch: ``We expect the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy soon. An accommodative Fed and help from exports should keep the economy out of recession.'' Other analysts are not so confident of the intentions of the Fed and its chairman, Alan Greenspan. ``Tight money is the cornerstone of Alan Greenspan's relentless campaign against inflation,'' said H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. ``He is following a high-risk strategy.''

DOC.HEAD: ``The Fantasticks'' Hits the Road for 30th Anniversary National Tour
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Try to remember 30 years ago when ``The Fantasticks'' opened off-Broadway and went on to make theater history as the world's longest-running musical. Now, a new version of this simple parable about romantic illusions is about to begin a 40-city national tour, with a full orchestra, a chorus and Robert Goulet starring as the narrator. It was to have opened here at the 2,741-seat Orpheum Theatre Monday night, but slow ticket sales caused theater owners to cancel. ``You need the bodies to make these things work,'' Orpheum manager Fred Krohn said. ``Every year at this time we seem to have a lull in sales.'' Krohn said none of the shows was more than half sold when the decision was made Thursday to cancel the run. Michael Sterling, a publicist for the tour, said the show will move to the State Fair Music Hall in Dallas, its next scheduled stop, and play from July 3-July 15. The musical is part of a 15-week season there, and tickets were sold as part of a package. ``It'll be a new discovery,'' said lyricist Tom Jones, who wrote ``The Fantasticks'' with composer Harvey Schmidt in 1959. ``I believe it's going to be a revelation for people who've never seen it or even more so, for people who've only seen it in an amateur production.'' Since opening at the 153-seat Sullivan Street Playhouse in Greenwich Village on May 3, 1960, ``The Fantasticks'' has run for more than 12,500 performances. In addition to being the world's longest-running musical and the longest-running show in American theater history, ``The Fantasticks'' is the most frequently produced musical in the world. A favorite college and amateur production, ``The Fantasticks'' has been staged more than 11,000 times in the United States and more than 700 times in 68 other countries. The musical, best known for the song ``Try to Remember,'' is based on an 1894 play ``Les Romanesque'' by Edmond Rostand. The story is a reverse ``Romeo and Juliet'' in which parents invent a feud to bring their children together. A boy and a girl find love at the end of Act 1, then separate and become disillusioned before understanding each other at the end of Act 2. With its eight-member cast and sparse scenery, ``The Fantasticks'' usually is performed in an intimate setting with piano and harp accompaniment. For the show's first national tour, a 16-piece orchestra and a seven-member chorus with orchestrations by Hollywood conductor Jack Elliott were added, a new song was written, and new sets and costumes were designed by the show's original designer, Ed Wittstein. ``The Fantasticks'' originally cost $16,500 to stage in 1960. The cost of the 30th anniversary national tour is close to $1 million. Jones believes the play's message won't be lost in a big production. ``I feel it enhances the piece,'' he said. In 1987, the Peking Opera performed ``The Fantasticks'' in a 6,000-seat auditorium. The next year, Jones and Schmidt directed a production that toured Japan in theaters of 1,000 seats or more. ``We found that in every instance, the places where we expanded (the musical) not only didn't take away from the show but they helped it. They clarified it and made it more fun,'' Jones said. Jones calls ``The Fantasticks'' a celebration of the theater. The musical borrows such devices as the Oriental invisible propman, stock comic figures from Italian commedia del l'arte and a narrator from Greek theater. ``When you go to the theater, you want to have an experience that's different from this experience of watching television or going to a film,'' Jones said. Universal themes in ``The Fantasticks'' may account for its popularity, he said. ``It has to do with growing up, with letting go of some romantic romanticism and settling for more everyday life. It's an attempt to celebrate young love and romanticize it and mock it at the same time.'' Goulet, who debuted on Broadway in 1960 as Lancelot in ``Camelot,'' was the authors' first choice to play the narrator, El Gallo, in the tour. ``He's very right for it. First of all, he's been signing and recording `Try to Remember' for 25 years or more,'' Jones said. Goulet has starred in traveling productions of ``On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,'' ``Carousel'' and ``South Pacific.'' ``It's hard to find a star name who can actually deliver material like he can,'' Schmidt said. As the narrator, Goulet portrays a matinee-idol vision of what the girl and the boy believe a dashing hero should be. For the role of El Gallo, Jones said he wanted ``a bullfighter who's been gored, and Robert has been gored. And he's experienced, and he's been burned a little bit.'' Goulet sees the role as that of a combination swashbuckler, poet and teacher. ``I like the role. I like the show itself,'' Goulet said. ``It offers some poetry. It's a classroom, in a sense, to help people to lead saner and more honest lives.'' Jones hopes the tour results in a television film, a videocassette and a new album. The musical has not been recorded in English since the original off-Broadway cast recording, and a TV adaptation starring Ricardo Montalban as El Gallo and John Davidson as the boy has not been shown since its 1964 telecast. ``People are going to rediscover `The Fantasticks.' And though they may have liked it before, I think there'll be a whole new vision of it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Loggers Vs. Nature: The Human Cost of Preserving Ancient Forests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: updates with decision to protect spotted owls and deletes incorrect references to Redding, Calif., redwood forests and to oldest and largest trees on earth; SUBS 32nd graf, ``Environmental reforms ...,'' to CORRECT first name to Ron sted Rod; PICKS UP 33rd graf pvs, ``President Bush ...''
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Loggers in this Olympic Peninsula town have always known that the supply of huge ancient trees they depend on would start to run out some day. They just didn't expect it this summer. And if you had told them their whining chain saws and rumbling log trucks would be silenced by a fluffy 22-ounce owl, they probably would have laughed themselves right off a stump. Nobody's laughing now in Neilton. It's one of dozens of Pacific Northwest towns suddenly facing economic ruin during what was supposed to be the timber industry's biggest boom in a decade. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on Friday declared the northern spotted owl a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act, saying the bird might become extinct if its habitat in old-growth forests is not protected. Officials plan to hold off releasing a protection plan for the owl until later this week. But under one scenario proposed earlier this year by a team of federal scientists, timber harvests could be reduced by nearly half in the old-growth national forests of Washington, Oregon and Northern California. Those bans could cost 28,000 jobs in the region over 10 years and tear apart timber towns with increased rates of violence, divorce and suicide, a federal study predicts. Neilton, a tightly knit village of 400 surrounded by the Olympic National Forest, has felt the pinch since January 1989, when the U.S. Forest Service began slowing down timber sales to protect nesting areas of the secretive owl in anticipation of preservation measures. Existing contracts have kept some Neilton loggers in business, but most of those will run out this summer, forest service officials said. The agency scrambled to find a few old-growth parcels outside critical owl habitats for cutting this fall, but loggers say those trees will keep them working only a few months. One mill that produces cedar shingles for roofing already has closed here, and another is struggling to find enough raw material. School enrollment has declined 12 percent since September. Almost every house in town has a sign in the window proclaiming, ``This family supported by timber dollars.'' But many residents fear they'll soon be replaced by ``For Sale'' signs. ``It's been pretty slim, and I know it's going to get slimmer,'' said Stanley Metcalf, 52, who now runs only two of his six log-hauling trucks. ``Everybody in town is worried about their homes, their families, their businesses.'' In some timber towns, worry has turned to anger. Loggers have rallied in noisy protests from Redding, Calif., to Aberdeen, Wash. Environmentalists consider the Northwest's ancient forests precious national resources that clean the air and trap flood waters, all while providing opportunities for solace and recreation. They say the towering evergreens, 1,000 years and older, anchor a complex ecosystem that supports a diversity of wildlife absent in younger forests. ``We have strong scientific evidence that an indicator of the health of the ecosystem (the northern spotted owl) is in very grave peril, and that tells us that the ecosystem is in grave peril,'' said Melanie Rowland, an attorney for the Wilderness Society. But Charlie Miller, who has been in the logging business for 40 years, sees the big trees differently. ``They're overripe,'' he said. ``Those trees should have been logged years ago. Our forest is just like a corn field in Nebraska. When that corn field is ripe, you've got to cut it.'' Forty years ago, Miller had plenty of support for his views. In 1952, a forest service researcher called the ancient forests ``biological deserts,'' and foresters saw nothing wrong with cutting old trees that had slowed their growth to make way for new stands of rapidly growing trees. The philosophy fit well with commercial interests, which valued the old-growth trees for their tight grain, durability and lack of knots. Old-growth forests on private lands disappeared first. After World War II, cutting on the Northwest's 12 national forests increased to fill the gap. Concerns about over-harvesting surfaced in the late 1960s, about the same time as researchers discovered that ancient forests were hardly biological deserts. But the cutting continued. Since the early 1970s, environmental groups pressured the fish and wildlife service to declare the owl threatened. After years of delays, lawsuits finally forced the agency to take a closer look at the owl population. Today, nobody knows exactly how much remains of the West Coast's original 17 million acres of old-growth forest. Federal estimates range from 3.2 million to 7.1 million acres scattered in patches up and down the Pacific Coast, and estimates by industry and environmentalists vary even more. And researchers don't know how many owls there are, but they estimate the owl has lost 80 percent of its habitat since 1800. Even without the owl, recent developments have already reduced the amount of national forest old-growth timber available to loggers. Additions to the wilderness preservation system have taken land out of logging. And this month, the forest service announced plans to reduce logging by 46 percent in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, Washington's largest national forest. ``This is public land, and that is what the timber industry is forgetting,'' said Rowland, the Wilderness Society attorney. ``I bridle when they say it is their forest. It simply is not.'' As the region becomes more urbanized and diversified, what's best for the timber industry is no longer necessarily what's best for the Northwest, she said. Logging and milling account for just 6 percent of total employment in Oregon, 2 percent in Washington, and less than one-half percent in California, according to state officials. It's understandable why Congress would not worry about the loss of 28,000 jobs over such a large region, said Bill Pickell, head of the Washington State Contract Loggers Association. But the jobs to be lost are concentrated in isolated towns, which often have no way to replace them, he said. ``We'll have Appalachia West out here,'' Pickell said. State officials in Washington and Oregon are urging federal agencies to phase in any logging bans to let the industry adjust to less-desirable, young trees. There have also been calls for federal aid to the loggers. ``Environmental reforms do not come free,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. ``Working families ... don't have the resources to prepare for changes forced by new environmental laws. There is a real moral obligation for the government to assist those families.'' President Bush disagrees. He said earlier this month that while he is concerned about timber workers, he would oppose federal help for job retraining. Other relief may be on the way. Congress is considering measures to restrict or ban exports of raw timber, thereby increasing the supply available to local mills. But at this point, loggers have little patience for government promises, said Neilton resident Duane Sim, and the fight could get even nastier. ``I'm not going to say what we're going to do,'' Sim said. ``But you can bet we're not going to just roll over.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP's Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Medellin Is a Clean, Quiet City
With BC-Terror in Medellin
DOC.TEXT: Many people who don't live in Medellin think it is a city of drugs, crime and murder where the people walk in fear. Not so. Drugs are scarcely used in the home of the world's most powerful cocaine cartel. As in other Colombian cities, children respect their parents and are reverent to the elderly. All schools, public and private, require their students to wear clean, neatly pressed uniforms, and to respect their teachers. Girls under age 15 are chaperroned on dates. Speech is formal and respect is the rule in most personal relationships. Even in the heat of a traffic dispute, men call each other sir. Graffiti is seldom obscene. It is more likely to address labor disputes, guerrillas or the war on drugs. People dress neatly. Many gardeners, who are paid less than $50 a month, arrive at work in suits and change in the garage. Medellin is a clean city, on the rolling hills of an Andean valley, where men with pushbrooms sweep the streets. There are Spanish churches and colonial houses with red-tiled roofs, modern shopping centers and high-rise buildings, new freeways and old flower stalls. People are kind. They will help a visitor who gets lost, answer questions about Medellin and its customs. They speak with regret of their city's reputation.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 1

DOC.HEAD: Vanguards Become Victims, But Forces of Change Irresistible
DOC.TEXT: The drama of changing China has had touches of the heroic and the farcical. Too often, it is haunted by tragedy. It is a story that in the past four years, indeed over the past 40, has been marked by consistent themes. The forces of change, given center stage, speak out and are suppressed. The suppressors relax their vigilance and the adversaries rise again.

June, 1986. Shao Yanxiang, a poet, says it is ``the best period of literary creation'' in modern Chinese history. Anyone ``can write the way he wants'' and the ``100 Flowers'' concept of free expression introduced by Mao Tse-tung in 1956 has finally come true. Mao may have expressed the concept, but those who took his advice and spoke out were persecuted. Mao's successor, Deng Xiaoping, allowed a brief flirtation with free expression in the 1979 Democracy Wall movement. Some who bared their souls are still in prison. In 1986, however, the state-run movie industry awards prizes to ``The Black Cannon Incident,'' a scathing indictment of bureaucratic stupidity. Zhang Xianliang's semi-autobiographical novel ``Half of Man Is Woman'' shocks Chinese readers with its frank look at political repression and sexual desire. Rambo, Superman and Pavarotti play to overflow crowds. Chinese are cast as eunuchs and Red Guards in the film ``Last Emperor.'' The door to the West appears firmly open.

January, 1987. Thousands of students demanding democratic reform trudge through the snow-covered midnight streets of Beijing to Tiananmen Square. Asked if he is afraid of the police, one replies, ``We are students. They would never hurt us.'' The student movement, constrained by harsh winter weather and lack of leadership, is short-lived, but the repercussions are serious. Hu Yaobang, Deng's heir apparent, is purged as Communist Party chief for his pro-student leanings. A chilling campaign is launched against ``bourgeois liberalization,'' or attraction to Western ideas. Old socialist heroes are resurrected, such as the late footsoldier Lei Feng, a cartoon-like figure who devoted his life to doing good deeds and loving the party. A new anti-hero, astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, is discovered and kicked out of the party for telling students to question their leaders. Sartre and Lawrence are pulled off bookshelves and writers are told to write for the masses. ``There has been nothing worth reading twice,'' one said later in the year. ``Most writers are very cautious and keep their work on a very small scale.''

November, 1987. Proponents of reform triumph. Premier Zhao Ziyang, who favors reform, is named party chief at a national congress. His mentor, Deng, gives up most of his posts and forces aging conservatives to retire. Zhao, asked about infighting between conservative and reform groups, says: ``The two factions have merged into one.'' A star of the congress is Guan Guangmei, a middle-aged woman who took over eight moribund state-run food shops in a northern city and built a thriving business. ``I will not be a capitalist,'' she says, ``but the state allows some people to get prosperous.''

June, 1988. Deng's market-oriented reforms appear entrenched. China must push ahead with price reform, the party newspaper Party's People's Daily says, to avoid ``rampant black markets, heavier burdens of government subsidies and worsening of the social mood.'' ``Socialism is not a cake that can be ordered and there is no fixed pattern for socialism,'' says social scientist Li Honglin. In a year, Li will be imprisoned for making such statements.

February, 1989. President Bush, after meeting Chinese leaders in Beijing, expresses confidence that, ``when future generations of Chinese and Americans look back upon this time, they'll say that the winds of change blew favorably upon our lands.'' Chinese leaders, possibly distracted by growing economic problems and moves by conservative Premier Li Peng to slow down reform, evince a startling tolerance of political and artistic expression. Economists propose radical changes in the system, intellectuals sign letters calling for the release of political prisoners and state television broadcasts a documentary questioning the very essence of Chinese culture. ``None of us knows how long this will last,'' says self-described ``free artist'' Yang Wei, ``but it's a good time to be creating.'' An avant-garde art show, preceded by an exhibit of nude paintings at Beijing's main museum, features a waterbed filled with dead fish, huge balloons shaped like breasts and a woman artist who shoots her own work with a BB gun. Tolerance has its limits. Police forcibly prevent Fang Lizhi from attending a banquet given by Bush. Fang says of the government: ``It is weak and it is frightened. All I wanted to do was shake the hands of the president and Mrs. Bush.''

May, 1989. An elderly woman blocks the path of a truck carrying soldiers ordered to end the pro-democracy demonstrations, which had drawn crowds of up to 1 million. She says to the soldiers: ``The students are very weak. How can you have the heart to suppress them? Beijing supports them. If you advance, it will be over my body.'' Two weeks later, on June 3, the soldiers advance over the bodies of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of unarmed people. Deng praises the army for quelling a ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' intended to overthrow the party and the socialist system. Thousands of political activists are imprisoned. Zhao is purged and accused of supporting student agitators. Millions of students and workers face long hours of political indoctrination, hearing over and over again that ``without the Communist Party there would be no new China. Only socialism can save China.'' Lei Feng, the supermodel, returns with a vengeance. Class struggle and imperialist threats are revived and, according to official reports, students rush to bookstores to buy the works of Marx and Lenin. Artists are told their works must be based on the idea of ``from the masses, to the masses.''

October, 1989. Tiananmen Square, four months after the demonstrators were driven out, is taken over by 100,000 soldiers, workers and students who dance and sing paeans on the 40th anniversary of Communist Party rule in China. Deng and other leaders watch from the rostrum of Tiananmen Gate as 30,000 fireworks explode in the sky. Thousands of police and soldiers patrol nearby streets to keep uninvited guests away and prevent sabotage. Many are in riot gear, carrying automatic rifles and electric prods.

June, 1990. Thousands of armed police seal roads around Beijing universities to prevent commemoration of the first anniversary of the military crackdown. Students, powerless but defiant, break bottles and hold a small campus demonstration. ``Millions of Beijing residents peacefully spent this Monday in busy work and pleasant rest,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said. Tiananmen Square, still guarded by several thousand soldiers, is closed to the public for four days leading up to the anniversary. A Beijing court, citing the need to ensure social stability and ``severely attack criminal elements'' before the Asian Games in Beijing in September, orders the mass execution of 11 convicted criminals.

No one predicts when the current ideological spasm will give way to a new period in which ideas are encouraged rather than suppressed. Some say it may take the death of Deng and a subsequent political crisis. China has continued to change, in both profound and humble ways. In four years, its 1.1 billion people have been introduced to stock markets, bankruptcy, contract labor, private housing, compulsory education through the 9th grade and opinion polls. They have Kentucky Fried Chicken off Tiananmen Square, Mickey Mouse on television every Sunday. Golf courses are built next to the Ming Tombs and Hilton Hotels rise in the hearts of ancient cities. Free markets, run by 17 million private entrepreneurs, continue to thrive. Beijing residents who once ate cabbage all winter now have cucumbers, green peppers, carrots and broccoli. Peasants are saving for TVs, city people for video players and telephones. The leaders in Beijing can force people to study Mao, but they can no longer halt the national drive for richer and freer lives. That's irreversible.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Japan-Corporate Giants
Nationalist Ishihara Says Japan Should Just Say `No'
DOC.TEXT: Japan's foremost political gadfly, conservative lawmaker Shintaro Ishihara, has replied to critics of his bestselling tract ``The Japan That Can Say No.'' He has come back with a sequel: ``Nonetheless, Japan Can Still Say No.'' The ``No'' in both is to what he says is American domination left over from the 1945-52 Allied occupation of Japan after its defeat in World War II. As the two nations marked the 30th anniversary of their revised mutual security treaty Saturday, Ishihara is repeating his calls for Japan to set out on a new course, independent of U.S. influence. The security treaty should be revised, Ishihara says. He also wants the entire constitution revised, mainly because it was imposed by the Americans, and also because it was translated into ``ugly Japanese.'' ``The Japanese have a character flaw of lacking spiritual independence because the Americans forced us to accept the postwar constitution,'' he says. ``After the war, Americans pulled the fangs of `ghost' Japan and in their place they gave us a pair of uncomfortable fake teeth _ the Japan-U.S. Defense Treaty and the Japanese constitution,'' Ishihara writes. ``It's time for Japanese to wipe away the postwar consciousness that has prevented them from standing up to the United States.'' Ishihara's views are shared by few political commentators, but his notoriety as a flamboyant politician and commentator have made him a popular author. Less than a month after its debut, ``Japan Can Still Say No'' has become a bestseller. Kobunsha, the publisher, says 350,000 copies have been sold since it was released in May. Ishihara's first ``No'' book has sold 1.1 million copies since January 1989. Bootleg translations of the first book, which was co-authored by Sony Corp. Chairman Akio Morita, raised a considerable stir in Washington. In the book, both blamed American management for declining U.S. competitiveness. Morita later said he regretted his collaboration with Ishihara, and refused to agree to an official English translation. The English version, minus Morita's contribution, is due sometime this fall. The second book is co-authored by an authoritative military analyst, Kazuhisa Ogawa, and by Shoichi Watanabe, a professor of Japanese culture at Tokyo's Sophia University _ two commentators who share Ishihara's nationalistic views. It repeats Ishihara's assertion that U.S. criticism of Japan stems from racism. ``A major factor behind the hysterical American reaction to Mr. Ishihara's points is that they came from non-white people that Americans consider to be inferior,'' Watanabe writes. ``Japan-bashing results from two misunderstandings,'' he says. The first is a mistaken belief that the Japanese are a warlike people and the second is the conviction, based on wartime stories of atrocity, that they are ``brutal monsters,'' he adds. ``The age of Western civilization is finished,'' Watanabe declares in an essay followed by Ishihara's comments on how Japan's culture is more advanced than Western cultures. The authors portray World War II as an albatross around the neck of modern Japan. ``You really can't say Japan is an independent country,'' writes co-author Ogawa. ``Japan really is a 51st American state ... It's as if the Japanese surrendered their national identity and pride almost a half century ago.'' Ishihara and Ogawa argue that the U.S. defense umbrella over Japan actually is of greater value to the United States' global military strategy than to the Japanese. Ishihara has stood by his suggestion that Tokyo manipulate the military balance of power by selling the microchips used to target nuclear missiles to the Soviet Union instead of the United States. Japan also should demand the return of at least one of four U.S. air bases in the Tokyo region, to help relieve severe congestion at local airports, he says. On June 22, Ishihara and a group of 15 other lawmakers proposed 109 recommendations for drastically changing U.S. policies. He said Japan's suggestions to the United States in talks on trade and economic practices, due to conclude Tuesday in Tokyo, had been ``rather modest.'' ``The United States has presented detailed demands to Japan. We thought it would be appropriate to propose our own ideas,'' Ishihara said. They suggested that the United States spend 5 percent of its gross national product on education, adopt management styles prevalent in Japan, establish tax-free savings accounts and enact harsher punishments for criminals. Ishihara has been raising eyebrows since 1956, when at age 24 he published his first bestseller, a novel called ``Season of the Sun.'' The story of a group of affluent, pleasure-seeking youths who reject the abashed, gloomy postwar mentality of their elders won the Akutagawa Prize, Japan's top literary award. A familiar figure on Japanese television, he is viewed by some as a possible contender for prime minister. But his outspoken views have left him well outside the conformist political mainstream. ``Among the informed Japanese public, the overwhelming opinion is that Mr. Ishihara is a troublemaker,'' says Tokyo University professor Seizaburo Sato. ``If Tokyo were to sever its security ties with Washington, it would automatically be cut off from the Western camp, regardless of how much of an economic foothold it might have gained in Western countries,'' said Yoshihisa Komori, bureau chief of the right-leaning Sankei Shimbun in Washington, D.C. Ishihara's books are typical of a genre that is flourishing as Japan grapples with the implications of its newfound status as a world economic power. Few Japanese authors share Ishihara's disdain for the United States, but all question where their nation should head in the next century.

DOC.HEAD: IBM To Try Home Computer Market _ Again _ After PCjr's Flop
DOC.TEXT: IBM's last attempt at a low-priced computer designed for home use could be a model for a business-school study of marketing disasters. The PCjr was introduced in November 1983 with one of the biggest marketing blitzes in computer industry history. But it turned into one of the biggest embarrassments ever for the world's largest computer company. PCjr suffered from a toylike keyboard _ which later was replaced with a larger one _ and limited computing power. It was priced too steeply for home computer users, but did not offer enough performance to compete with machines in its price range. International Business Machines Corp. yanked PCjr from the market a year and a half later, as 200,000 of the machines sat unsold in warehouses. On Tuesday, IBM will try again to tap the home computer market. This time, the Armonk, N.Y.-based company reportedly has taken great pains to avoid some bad reruns. The low-end model of the new four-model line will sell for under $1,000 _ possibly for as little as $650 in discount houses _ according to industry analysts. The computers will use one of the most popular microprocessors, Intel Corp.'s 80286 chip, making them compatible with scores of software packages used in business. And they will have adequate, though not overwhelming, memory. Some, or possibly all, of the models will contain a built-in modem, which allows computers to hook up to distant computers or data services, such as CompuServe, via telephone lines. The machines are expected to include a popular software package from Microsoft Corp. that combines a word processor, a spreadsheet and a communications program to run the modem, analysts said. The computers also are expected to have a built-in program that will link them via phone lines to Prodigy, a computer service that provides such things as home banking, shopping and airline reservations, said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Prodigy is a joint venture between IBM and Sears, Roebuck and Co. Sears is expected to be among the major sellers of the new computers, along with other mass merchandisers and possibly traditional computer stores, Martin said. Though IBM never comments on unannounced products, one of its top executives told industry analysts several months ago that the company wants to tap the potential market among the millions of people who have little or no experience with computers. Critics say other computer makers have tried to sell to that market for years, with less-than-overwhelming success. But IBM apparently believes these millions have been exposed to enough information about computers that they now will be willing to take the plunge, said Bruce Stephen, an analyst at International Data Corp., a research firm in Framingham, Mass. ``The thrust of this seems to be going after the family,'' Stephen said. ``They sense that there is some kind of perceived demand that increasingly families view a computer as a necessary home appliance.'' IBM could market the computers as a way for families to keep track of personal finances and taxes, to do shopping and investing, and to use educational software, Stephen said. But he noted that families are offered many other expensive temptations, such as camcorders and large-screen TVs, and that with consumer spending down, this may be the wrong time to launch such a product. Critics say the new line, which some reports say will be called the PS-1 (IBM's major full-sized personal computer line is the PS-2), may have some of the same drawbacks as the PCjr. For example, the new home PCs are said to lack so-called expansion slots that would allow customers to increase the machines' memory or hook them to a computer network. In addition, the keyboards will not be full-sized, analysts say, though they will be more acceptable than the rubberized ``chiclet'' keyboards that helped do in the PCjr. Some analysts say those design limitations were intentional, to avoid cannibalizing sales of IBM's higher-priced PCs. That could be a major issue with the specialized computer stores that sell IBM's conventional computers, Martin said.

DOC.HEAD: Some See Summer Setback for Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Though the calendar and the weather may say the time is ripe, Wall Street isn't exactly brimming with talk of the traditional ``summer rally'' right now. The phrase is sure to come up in the weeks ahead as brokers seek ways to stir up business in what is usually the slowest season for buying and selling investments. But given the already lofty level of stock prices and the questionable state of the business outlook, many analysts are far more concerned with whether a ``correction'' might be due before Labor Day. ``In some respects, current stock market pricing represents nearly as great an overvaluation as we saw in the summer of 1987,'' say analysts at Wright Investors' Service in Bridgeport, Conn., in their current appraisal of the outlook. ``The bull market has lasted nearly eight years and is getting tired,'' maintains Rao Chalasani at Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. in Cleveland. These refrains, of course, have been heard many times before since stocks began climbing in early August 1982. And even with events like the market crash in the fall of 1987, doubt and caution have not been popular commodities on Wall Street for a long time. Nevertheless, forecasters in the bearish camp say warning signals are plain to see these days in statistical gauges of the market such as price-earnings ratios. At recent levels, Chalasani calculates, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index traded at about 14 times estimated earnings-per-share for its component companies over the next year. That puts it at the high end of the range in which it has fluctuated for the past decade and a half. ``Certainly today's higher market P-E levels are partly warranted by the big drop in U.S. inflation and interest rates since 1981 and the `shortage of equities' which resulted from the leveraged buyouts of the past several years,'' Wright's analysts observe. ``But now, as economic and corporate fundamentals stagnate _ or, more likely, deteriorate _ one doubts that today's multiples can truly be justified.'' Such misgivings made their presence felt in the market during the past week, sending prices sharply lower. At the close on Friday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials stood at 2,857.18, down 78.71 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 3.62 to 194.24; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 8.22 to 459.33, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 4.74 at 359.29. Volume on the Big Board averaged 143.39 million shares a day, against 155.29 million the week before. Once the '80s bull market got rolling, Chalasani points out, it fell into a pattern of strong advances punctuated by setbacks every third year _ first 1984, then 1987. Now, he says, ``the market has gone through more than two years without a 10 percent correction.'' Similarly, from Wright's view, ``history suggests that from these high price-value levels below-average returns are likely for equities in the period ahead. ``Perhaps history is not the proper guide,'' the firm adds. ``Perhaps the stock market has entered into a period in which, for reasons of changing demographics or a thaw in the cold war or a `shortage of equities' or what have you, higher stock market valuations are appropriate. ``Whatever the merits of these `new era' arguments, one has only to recall the last time such thinking was in fashion, the summer of 1987, to become dubious.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions June 23-24
