DOC.HEAD: SEC Loses in Court, Still Battling in Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission suffered another in a series of legal setbacks this past week just as officials are trying to push legislation through Congress to expand the Wall Street watchdog's authority. On Monday, the U.S. Supreme Court let stand a lower court ruling that gave regulatory control of hybrid financial products called index participations to the rival Commodity Futures Trading Commission, rather than the SEC. Previously, in unrelated cases, a federal appeals court in New York narrowed a rule the SEC used to prosecute people for insider trading, and another court in Washington struck down an SEC rule that sought to protect equal shareholder voting rights. In Monday's decision, the high court let stand a ruling by an appeals court in Chicago that only the CFTC has the authority to regulate a new form of financial trading called index participations, or IPs. Index participations allow an investor to speculate in the fluctuations of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. The Chicago appeals court ruled that IPs contained elements of both a security and a futures contract but under the exclusivity clause of the Commodity Exchange Act, which created the CFTC, products with even the slightest aspect of a futures contract come under CFTC jurisdiction. Meanwhile, the Bush administration is trying to push through Congress legislation that would give the SEC authority over stock index futures _ a futures contract that allows investors to speculate in the performance of a large group of stocks, like the Standard & Poors 500, without buying the underlying stock. The proposal has been introduced in the House as a separate bill while supporters in the Senate plan to include it as an amendement to pending CFTC legislation. Despite stiff oppositon by leaders of the Senate Agriculture Committee and strong administration lobbying, the measure has been delayed from going to the floor for a vote as both sides jockey for undecided votes. ``Everyone's counting heads. The question is: who's going to force it (a vote) first?'' said a Senate committee staffer who spoke on the condition of anonymity. On Friday, the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee announced it would hold a hearing on the issue July 11. An ad hoc securities industry group which supports the administration proposal says the delay is helping their cause. ``I think right now it's a toss-up. A week ago I'd say we were a decided underdog,'' Joseph R. Hardiman, president and chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers, said Thursday. ``Give us more time and I think we'll prevail,'' added Hardiman, who is part of the Coalition for Intermarket Coordination. But will the recent legal setbacks impact the pending legislation? Partisans on either side of the issue generally say the impact won't be decisive but supports their contention. ``I think the court is saying `Fix the stupid law,''' said Nicholas A. Giordano, president of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. ``They're saying we have a crazy quilt of regulation in this country and that no sensible person would have done it this way if he was starting from scratch. ``No other country in the world does it this way. So somehow we've gotten ourselves into this fix. Let's correct it. And I think that's what the court decisions are saying to us and that's what we're trying to do.'' But Robert Mackay, director of the Center for Study of Futures and Options Markets in Falls Church, Va., said, ``I don't think the court said that in the IPs case.'' Rather, said Mackay, the court ruling ``confirms that the CFTC was reading the Commodity Exchange Act properly.'' Mackay, a professor of finance at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, thinks shifting stock index futures control to the more restrictive SEC is a bad idea. Although he believes the ruling will have little effect on Congress, he said: ``The SEC has been overreaching in jurisdictional issues and the courts told them that. That's the message.'' But Alan Bromberg, a securities law expert at Southern Methodist University, thinks both sides will see whatever they want in the decision. ``I think it's going to be an impetus to the (SEC) group but its also going to add ammunition to the CFTC supporters. Its really going to be a lobbying fight between the commodity exchanges and the securities industry.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _Philip Morris Cos. agreed to acquire the Swiss coffee and chocolate giant Jacobs Suchard AG for $3.8 billion in a cash deal that will create the third-largest food company in Europe. At the same time, the Zurich Stock Exchange said it was considering whether to conduct an insider-trading investigation because details of the merger surfaced in the local media while Swiss markets were still open. _The Supreme Court ruled that the federal agency which guarantees Americans' pensions, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., can force LTV Corp. to reassume liability for more than $2 billion in employee pension plans the company stoped funding three years ago. The ruling could impede the Dallas-based steel and energy giant's move out of federal bankruptcy proceedings. _The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. economy grew at its second slowest pace in 3{ years during the first quarter of 1990. The gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ rose at a revised 1.9 percent annual rate during that period, the agency said.
